('62', 0, 1, 2, 45) 1. A CASE FOR FASTING 1
('62', 0, 2, 3, 69) One who describes himself as a Harjian worker writes a long letter of which I give the following substance: With the Chairman of the local Harijan Seva Sangh and a sister I went the other day to a village.
('62', 0, 2, 4, 275) We were in a bullock cart.
('62', 0, 2, 5, 302) On the way the Chairman and the sister were engaged in conver sation exch anging jokes.
('62', 0, 2, 6, 390) The sister seemed to be fatigued and lay in the Chair man’s lap.
('62', 0, 2, 7, 455) This familiarity somewhat startled me.
('62', 0, 2, 8, 494) On returning we were to take the train to the city from which we had started.
('62', 0, 2, 9, 572) We had to wait for a few hours at the station.
('62', 0, 2, 10, 619) The Chairman and the sister occu pied a bench.
('62', 0, 2, 11, 666) I sat on the platform ground.
('62', 0, 2, 12, 696) It was a moonlight night.
('62', 0, 2, 13, 722) I had a mind to test them, for I thought that there was some thing wrong with them.
('62', 0, 2, 14, 806) I, therefore, pretended that I would sleep and told the Chairman: ‘We have yet to wait for some time.
('62', 0, 2, 15, 908) If you don’t mind I would sleep for a while.
('62', 0, 2, 16, 953) I am tired.
('62', 0, 2, 17, 965) Will you wake me up when the train arrives?’ Hearing this, the Chairman seemed to be delighted over my proposal and he readily permitted me to sleep.
('62', 0, 2, 18, 1115) I lay down and pretended that I was in deep sleep.
('62', 0, 2, 19, 1166) In order to make sure that I was asleep he called out.
('62', 0, 2, 20, 1221) Not having any response from me he felt free to take what liberties he liked with the sister.
('62', 0, 2, 21, 1315) They quietly went into a cluster of trees near by.
('62', 0, 2, 22, 1366) After some time they returned and when the time for the train drew near, he woke me up.
('62', 0, 2, 23, 1454) I did not like this indecency between the Chairman and the sister.
('62', 0, 2, 24, 1521) I recalled your 21 days’ fast and the rea sons which you had given for it.
('62', 0, 2, 25, 1596) I took some of the co workers into confidence.
('62', 0, 2, 26, 1643) They tackled the Chairman, but he put on a bold front and not only denied the charge of indecency but charged me with jealousy and designs upon the Chairmanship of the local organi zation.
('62', 0, 2, 27, 1832) What am I to do in the circumstance ?
('62', 0, 2, 28, 1870) I have omitted unnecessary details from the letter.
('62', 0, 2, 29, 1922) let not the reader try to guess the names of the actors and the scene of the tra gedy.
('62', 0, 2, 30, 2009) Idle curiosity should be avoided.
('62', 0, 2, 31, 2043) I am drawing public atten tion to my correspondent’s letter to serve as a warning to all Harijan workers.
('62', 0, 2, 32, 2149) Let us, therefore, examine it.
('62', 0, 2, 33, 2180) In the first instance, the correspondent did wrong in wishing to test his companions and exposing them to temptation.
('62', 0, 2, 34, 2298) It is always a bad business to become detectives over co workers; and if, without
('62', 0, 3, 35, 2380) 1 The Gujarati original appeared in Harijanbandhu, 8 10 1933.
('62', 1, 0, 1, 2442) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 2
('62', 1, 1, 2, 2482) wishing it, we discover any moral or other lapses on their part, our business should be not to gossip about them, but immediately to draw, in a gentle manner, the companions’ attention to them.
('62', 1, 1, 3, 2676) Had my correspondent, when he first scented danger, put the Chairman on his guard, he would have saved him from the lapse, assuming, of course, that the correspondent has given a true version of the tragedy.
('62', 1, 1, 4, 2884) But, instead of taking the straight course, he adopted the crooked course of testing the couple.
('62', 1, 1, 5, 2981) We are all fallible human beings ever exposed to temptations.
('62', 1, 1, 6, 3043) Fortunately for us, ‘there’s many a slip ’twixt the cup and the lip’.
('62', 1, 1, 7, 3113) Very few are saved from succumbing to temptations, if there is no external interruption.
('62', 1, 1, 8, 3202) There is no certainty that the corres pondent himself, exposed to the same temptation, might not have fallen as the Chairman is said by him to have fallen.
('62', 1, 1, 9, 3358) Indeed, had he been a little thoughtful, a little considerate towards his companions, he could have prevented their complete fall, by giving up the pretence of sleeping and gently pulling them up.
('62', 1, 1, 10, 3555) I know cases in which such warnings have proved the saving of people.
('62', 1, 1, 11, 3625) Thus, it seems to me that this Harijan worker signally failed in his duty towards his friends and fellow workers.
('62', 1, 1, 12, 3739) He has, however, asked the question, what he could do.
('62', 1, 1, 13, 3794) I do not propose to answer the question from his standpoint.
('62', 1, 1, 14, 3855) Evi dently he is anxious to know, not how the parties can be brought to repentance, but how they can be exposed, and the charges against him disproved.
('62', 1, 1, 15, 4007) It is none of his business to expose his companions, as it was none of his business to tempt them to fall but his business now is undoubtedly to give a private notice to the chairman that he would have to undertake a fast till the Chairman confesses his guilt, or if that is beyond his capacity, to undertake a fairly prolonged fast, so as to bring home the guilt to the parties.
('62', 1, 1, 16, 4387) Such a fast cannot be taken publicly.
('62', 1, 1, 17, 4425) It is highly likely that the Chairman and the sister will realize the grievousness of their guilt, but it is not at all unlikely that they might harden their hearts and ignore the fast.
('62', 1, 1, 18, 4611) That ought not to be a matter of any concern for my correspondent.
('62', 1, 1, 19, 4678) He will have done his penance for having made himself a detective over his friend and it will be some relief to him from the oppression of the charge brought against him of jealousy and ambition to become the Chairman of the local Seva Sangh.
('62', 1, 1, 20, 4921) It is hardly necessary to emphasize the obvious truth that the fast, if it is at all taken, should be taken only if the Harijan worker believes in its necessity and efficacy and if he can take it with a clean heart.
('62', 1, 1, 21, 5137) It may be that the parties charged by my correspondent have
('62', 2, 0, 1, 5197) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 3
('62', 2, 1, 2, 5242) not erred.
('62', 2, 1, 3, 5253) Let us hope that they have not.
('62', 2, 1, 4, 5285) But I know that such errors have occurred before now.
('62', 2, 1, 5, 5339) Let the incident described here serve as a warning to all workers.
('62', 2, 1, 6, 5406) It furnishes, in my opinion, a clear case for fasting.
('62', 2, 1, 7, 5461) Harijan service is no sinecure; it is a movement for bringing about a revolutionary change in the mentality of millions of human beings.
('62', 2, 1, 8, 5598) It is like walking on the edge of a sword and, therefore, requires the greatest vigilance over self on the part of the workers.
('62', 2, 1, 9, 5726) Harijan, 27 10 1933
('62', 2, 2, 10, 5746) 2. PREFACE TO “GITAPRAVESHIKA” 1
('62', 2, 3, 11, 5779) WARDHA, October 8, 1933 This selection 2 of shlokas for the Gitapraveshika was made last year (1932) in Yeravda Mandir.
('62', 2, 3, 12, 5899) My third son Ramdas was in the same jail.
('62', 2, 3, 13, 5941) The authorities permitted me to meet or write to him occasionally.
('62', 2, 3, 14, 6008) Ramadas used to read the Gita but could not understand it fully.
('62', 2, 3, 15, 6073) Ramdas does not lack bhaktibhava 3; he has the shraddha 4 too.
('62', 2, 3, 16, 6136) I selected simple and devotional verses from the Gita and sent them over to him so as to help him.
('62', 2, 3, 17, 6235) Ramdas liked the collection.
('62', 2, 3, 18, 6264) I further encouraged him by calling the selection “Ramagita” 5. Baba Raghavdas 6 happened to see the collection when it was with Kakasaheb; he went through it and felt it would prove useful to Harijan workers.
('62', 2, 3, 19, 6474) With that in view he asked for my permission to haveit published.
('62', 2, 3, 20, 6540) Being no pundit myself I could not decide if the collection was worthy of publication.
('62', 2, 3, 21, 6627) Vinoba, Kakasaheb and Balakrishna 7 of the Ashram were all here.
('62', 2, 3, 22, 6692) All the three are devoted students of the Gita.
('62', 2, 3, 23, 6740) I told the Baba that I had no objection to the collection being published provided the three Ashram inmates

('62', 3, 1, 2, 7358) approved of it.
('62', 3, 1, 3, 7374) All the three had consultation among themselves and advised me, with a view to increasing its utility, to omit three of the verses and to add four new ones.
('62', 3, 1, 4, 7531) The collection thus revised is now presented to men and women workers as well as to other lovers of the Gita.
('62', 3, 1, 5, 7641) I hope—and it is also my intention—that the collection will be read as an introduction and nothing more and that a study of the Gita as a whole will be undertaken only after it had been fairly digested.
('62', 3, 1, 6, 7844) All the same it should be remembered that merely memorizing or knowing the meaning of the Praveshika or [even] the whole of the Gita is not going to help realize the atman.
('62', 3, 1, 7, 8017) The Gita is to be put into practice.
('62', 3, 1, 8, 8054) When one has knowledge of its techincal phraseology and has taken to heart its central idea of non attachment, it becomes easier to understand the Gita.

('62', 3, 2, 10, 8247) 3. LETTER TO AMRITLAL V. THAKKAR Unrevised October 8, 1933
('62', 3, 3, 11, 8306) DEAR THAKKAR BAPA, I have your letter about the amounts of Harijan fund received by me.
('62', 3, 3, 12, 8394) I have the account from Mathuradas.
('62', 3, 3, 13, 8430) I am simply waiting for Chimanlal who is expected to reach here shortly.
('62', 3, 3, 14, 8503) As soon as he comes I shall attend to the matter.
('62', 3, 3, 15, 8553) I have also your letter about the tour.
('62', 3, 3, 16, 8593) Your second letter has crossed mine.
('62', 3, 3, 17, 8630) I am quite clear in my mind that the whole of the Cen tral Provinces should be finished at once.
('62', 3, 3, 18, 8727) I do not mind the cold weather of the Punjab.
('62', 3, 3, 19, 8773) Therefore it does not matter where I am during the cold weather.
('62', 3, 3, 20, 8838) Nor do I mind the hot weather.
('62', 3, 3, 21, 8869) What you have to guard against is the rainy season.
('62', 3, 3, 22, 8921) Therefore, June and July should be given to those provinces where the rains do not set in early.
('62', 3, 3, 23, 9018) I was considerably relieved as you must have been to find Bakhale withdrawing from the Municipal contest.
('62', 3, 3, 24, 9124) We will now discuss with Mr. Kodanda Rao the principle underlying the advice that you and I tendered.
('62', 3, 3, 25, 9226) I have told him that I would welcome the discussion.
('62', 3, 3, 26, 9279) BAPU SJT.

('62', 4, 1, 2, 9431) 4. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('62', 4, 2, 3, 9456) October 8, 1933
('62', 4, 3, 4, 9472) MY DEAR GHANSHYAMDAS, I have your letter 1. The difficulty you raise is there and it was in anticipation of it that I suggested the formation of a trust board.
('62', 4, 3, 5, 9632) My idea is that the property should be held by these trustees permanently, under very defined conditions, with the right even to sell.
('62', 4, 3, 6, 9767) You and Thakkar Bapa should be permanent members, irrespective of what happens to the popular organization.
('62', 4, 3, 7, 9875) This proposal disposes of the question from which has arisen the larger one that I am not prepared to discuss in this letter for want of time.
('62', 4, 3, 8, 10018) Meanwhile I would ask you to study the constitution of the All India Spinners’ Association.
('62', 4, 3, 9, 10110) We may postpone the discussion till we meet, and seeing that I am here up to the 7th of Novemeber, it might be possible for you to come, even if it be for that one question.
('62', 4, 3, 10, 10284) You have referred to the proposed hostel in Delhi.
('62', 4, 3, 11, 10335) In view of our possessing the Ashram ground and buildings, do you think there is any urgency for the Delhi proposal?
('62', 4, 3, 12, 10452) Should we not wait and see how the Sabarmati plan progresses before venturing upon another big scheme?
('62', 4, 3, 13, 10555) I am inclined to think that we ought to concentrate our atten tion upon making the Sabarmati scheme a thorough success and it will tax the energy of many of us to make it so.
('62', 4, 3, 14, 10730) I hope you are keeping well.
('62', 4, 3, 15, 10759) What about the nose?
('62', 4, 3, 16, 10780) Weather in Delhi ought to be very fine at this time of the year.
('62', 4, 4, 17, 10845) C.W. 7938 and 7939. Courtesy : G. D. Birla.
('62', 4, 4, 18, 10889) Also In the Shadow of the Mahatma, pp.
('62', 4, 5, 19, 10928) 1 Dated october 5, which, inter alia, read : So far we have no property.
('62', 4, 5, 20, 11001) But by the acceptance of your offer we will shortly be in possession of a valuable peroperty.
('62', 4, 5, 21, 11095) The question will thus immediately arise as to who will be the owner of this property.
('62', 4, 5, 22, 11182) Will it be the Harijan Mandal ?
('62', 4, 5, 23, 11214) If so, then the Harijan Mandal would for all practical purposes mean the persons by whose sufferance it exists and there is no such thing as sufferance in our socitey so far.
('62', 4, 5, 24, 11389) Therefore, we have to decide what sort of constitution we are to have in future.

('62', 5, 7, 9, 11716) 6. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, WARDHA 1
('62', 5, 8, 10, 11754) October 8, 1933 Till yesterday I had no idea that I would have to face a large assembly like this, nor did I imagine that I would have to make a speech.
('62', 5, 8, 11, 11907) I cannot speak very loudly.
('62', 5, 8, 12, 11935) Doctor friends have advised me not to try it.
('62', 5, 8, 13, 11981) That is why I have jotted down a few points.
('62', 5, 8, 14, 12026) You are aware that till the 3rd of August next year I wish to engage myself mainly in Harijan work.
('62', 5, 8, 15, 12126) I have tried to study Hinduism since my youth and have endeavoured to shape my conduct according to what I was taught in my childhood.
('62', 5, 8, 16, 12261) I have studied the Hindu scriptures to the best fo my ability.
('62', 5, 8, 17, 12324) I have studied the sacred books of other religions also with reverence.
('62', 5, 8, 18, 12396) Right from my childhood I have believed that untouchability as we know it today has no place in Hinduism and that it is a great evil which has somehow entered it.
('62', 5, 8, 19, 12559) Study and experience have confirmed me in this view.
('62', 5, 8, 20, 12612) I am convinced that Hinduism will perish if we do not get rid of this evil of untouchability.
('62', 5, 8, 21, 12706) Removal of untouchability does not mean merely that we should touch the people whom we regard as untouchables.
('62', 5, 8, 22, 12817) Of course we should touch them, whenever necessary, with love.
('62', 5, 8, 23, 12880) But removal of untouchability means much more than that.
('62', 5, 8, 24, 12937) It means that we should give up the feeling of high and low.
('62', 5, 8, 25, 12998) In a sense the feeling of high and low is found prevailing in all countries.
('62', 5, 8, 26, 13075) But is cannot be said that this
('62', 5, 9, 27, 13107) 1 Owing to his weak state of health Gandhiji himself did not speak.
('62', 5, 9, 28, 13175) The speech, which was in Hindi, was read out at the meeting.
('62', 5, 9, 29, 13236) No Hindi report being available, this has been translated from Chandrashankar Shukla’s weekly letter.
('62', 6, 0, 1, 13338) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 7
('62', 6, 1, 2, 13383) feeling is part of any religion.
('62', 6, 1, 3, 13416) It is asserted that it is part of Hindusm; but if we examine objectively the fundamental principles of Hinduism, we can see that it too does not sanction such a feeling.
('62', 6, 1, 4, 13586) It is true, of course, that our daily conduct is strongly influenced by this notion, and we have been taught to believe that it is a special feature of Hinduism.
('62', 6, 1, 5, 13748) One of the principles of Hinduism is that we should not do to others what we would not like to be done to ourselves.
('62', 6, 1, 6, 13865) In another verse having the same meaning, it is stated that we should regard all living creatures as we regard ourselves.
('62', 6, 1, 7, 13987) How the feeling of high and low crept into such a religion is beyond my understanding.
('62', 6, 1, 8, 14074) In other words, it is the duty of every Hindu to fulfil completely the pledge that the leaders had taken on behalf of the Hindu community on 25th 1 September last year at a meeting in Bombay presided over by Malaviyaji Maharaj.
('62', 6, 1, 9, 14302) I hope that all of you who have come here will keep that pledge.
('62', 6, 1, 10, 14367) It was categorically stated in that Resolution that the Harijans have the same right as the other Hindus to the use of public temples, public wells and public schools.
('62', 6, 1, 11, 14535) When vast numbers of caste Hindus undergo change of heart and we fully appreciate and follow the dharma of compassion, not only will there be unity between them and Harijans but we shall also live in amity with followers of other faiths and the present antagonisms will completely disappear.
('62', 6, 1, 12, 14827) I pray to God that He grant us enough strength to purify ourselves thus and that the evil of untouchability that has crept into Hinduism be completely abolished.
('62', 6, 1, 13, 14989) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 15 10 1933

('62', 6, 2, 15, 15056) The resolution drafted by Gandhiji and agreed upon by other leaders at Poona on Spetember 24, 1932, was formally adopted at Bombay the following day.

('62', 9, 1, 2, 18603) 10. LETTER TO F. MARY BARR
('62', 9, 2, 3, 18630) October 9, 1933
('62', 9, 3, 4, 18646) MARY, I had full report yeaterday of your misbehaviour.
('62', 9, 3, 5, 18702) The doctors say you have a spleen.
('62', 9, 3, 6, 18737) It points to a diet of milk and fruit and greens.

('62', 11, 3, 8, 21904) WARDHA, October 10, 1933 CHI.
('62', 11, 3, 9, 21934) MATHURADAS, I have received your letters.
('62', 11, 3, 10, 21976) I can see that you do not want me to write anything to Gokhale right now.
('62', 11, 3, 11, 22050) I have seen Gokhale’s letter in the Chronicle today.
('62', 11, 3, 12, 22103) Your letter to Thakkar Bapa is full of anger.
('62', 11, 3, 13, 22149) You seem to have lost sight of one rule.
('62', 11, 3, 14, 22190) You ought not to read in letters what isscored off.
('62', 11, 3, 15, 22242) And if you happen to read it, you ought not to read any meaning in it.
('62', 11, 3, 16, 22313) A person should be given a chance to modify his views.
('62', 11, 3, 17, 22368) It is sheer ignorance to attribute wickedness even to the most wicked thought once it has been modified.
('62', 11, 3, 18, 22473) The world would not go on in peace even for a minute if we started throwing our views at one an other.
('62', 11, 3, 19, 22576) I think you have been unnecessarily angry.
('62', 11, 3, 20, 22619) Thakkar Bapa de serves to be complimented on his alertness.
('62', 11, 3, 21, 22679) Moreover, his age and his dedicated service of so many years give him a right to say a great deal.
('62', 11, 3, 22, 22778) When he says something, there is no sting behind it.
('62', 11, 3, 23, 22831) If there is anybody’s mistake in this, one might say it is on my part.
('62', 11, 3, 24, 22902) I have written at this length because I would not like even a trace of anger in you.
('62', 11, 4, 25, 22987) Now for the Ashram.
('62', 11, 4, 26, 23007) I think you are mistaken in the matter.
('62', 11, 4, 27, 23047) If the Government does not take possession and we allow the land to re main untended it means we are harbouring a feeling of revenge.
('62', 11, 4, 28, 23181) It would be an unnatural situation.
('62', 11, 4, 29, 23217) There was nothing to prevent the Government from taking possession of the land and letting it lie fallow.
('62', 11, 4, 30, 23323) But on what ground can we allow the land to remain fallow if the government does not take it over?
('62', 11, 4, 31, 23422) In that case, why should we not burn down our movable property?
('62', 11, 4, 32, 23486) According to what you are saying,
('62', 11, 5, 33, 23520) 1 Extracts from this letter appear in "Letter to Mathurdas Trikumji”, 11 10 1933 2 Vide also “Letter to Amritlal V. Thakkar”, 10 10 1933
('62', 12, 0, 1, 23657) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 13
('62', 12, 1, 2, 23703) those who burnt their crops acted wisely.
('62', 12, 1, 3, 23745) I am convinced that the Satyagraha Ashram will fulfil its purpose if the land is donated to Harijans.
('62', 12, 1, 4, 23847) This is of greater moment than if the land was to remain with the Government.
('62', 12, 1, 5, 23925) Even if it should go to the Government, we would always want to claim it back in the end.
('62', 12, 1, 6, 24015) But in this case, the Ashram inmates gave it up for good and placed themselves in the hands of God.
('62', 12, 1, 7, 24115) If we examine the problem from this point of view, it would be clear that the path adopted alone does credit to a satyagrahi.
('62', 12, 1, 8, 24241) There has been no place here for greed for money.
('62', 12, 1, 9, 24291) It was merely a matter of what was right, that is, of non violence.

('62', 13, 8, 23, 26637) 16. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI
('62', 13, 9, 24, 26671) October 11, 1933 And now regarding the Ashram.
('62', 13, 9, 25, 26718) You are completely on the wrong track in this matter.
('62', 13, 9, 26, 26772) To let the buildings and the land fall into ruins if the Government does not take possession of them would be vindictive and unnatural.
('62', 13, 9, 27, 26908) If the Government had taken over the Ashram and then let it fall into ruin, we would have had nothing to say against it.
('62', 13, 9, 28, 27029) But on what principle can we let the land be ruined if the Government does not take over?
('62', 13, 9, 29, 27119) If we do that, why should we also not
('62', 14, 0, 1, 27157) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 15
('62', 14, 1, 2, 27203) burn the movable property?
('62', 14, 1, 3, 27230) According to the principle which you apply, those who burnt their crops acted wisely.
('62', 14, 1, 4, 27316) I am convinced that by offering the Ashram land to the cause of Harijans, we shall have completely fulfilled the aim for which the Ashram existed.
('62', 14, 1, 5, 27463) Its aim will have been fulfilled better in this manner than by its remaining in the possession of the Government.
('62', 14, 1, 6, 27577) In handing over the Ashram to the Government, we secretly hoped that one day we would get back its possesion.
('62', 14, 1, 7, 27687) But by taking the step that we have taken, the inmates of the Ashram have given up their claim permanently and trusted their future wholly to God.
('62', 14, 1, 8, 27834) From whatever point of view we look at the matter, we find that the course we have adopted is the only right one for satyagrahis.
('62', 14, 1, 9, 27964) The desire to save property has been no motive at all in this transaction.
('62', 14, 1, 10, 28039) It was only a question of what was right and consistent with ahimsa.
('62', 14, 1, 11, 28108) The Government may let the whole country be ruined, but we should not if we can help.
('62', 14, 1, 12, 28194) If this does not satisfy you, you may ask me again.
('62', 14, 1, 13, 28246) It shouldn’t be difficult to satisfy your doubts in this matter.
('62', 14, 2, 14, 28311) [From Gujarati]

('62', 15, 1, 2, 29020) 18. LETTER TO H. K. HALES
('62', 15, 2, 3, 29046) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, WARDHA, October 12, 1933
('62', 15, 3, 4, 29090) DEAR FRIEND, You will pardon me for being a little late in acknowledging your letter of 6th inst.
('62', 15, 3, 5, 29188) The fact is that my capacity for dealing with the in creasing correspondence is limited.
('62', 15, 3, 6, 29277) With reference to the suggestion made by you, evidently you do not recognize my limitations.
('62', 15, 3, 7, 29370) In the first instance, I am not at all sure whether the Government would favour the idea of my visiting Midnapore and if it did, whether it would give me a free hand to work in the manner I might think best.
('62', 15, 3, 8, 29578) Above all, you know the view that I have expressed.
('62', 15, 3, 9, 29630) 1 Even a confirmed peace maker like me can have no chance whatsoever if I have to address only one party of violence.
('62', 15, 3, 10, 29748) I regard both the Government and the terrorists as representing vio lence; that of the terrorists is unorganized, insane and wholly ineffec tive from my standpoint, and that of the Government is orga nized, deliberate and blasting though also wholly ineffective again from my standpoint.
('62', 15, 3, 11, 30036) I should have short shrift from the terrorists if I could have no influence with the superior party of violence.
('62', 15, 3, 12, 30149) Even so, do not for one moment believe that because I do not go to Midnapore I exert no influence over the terrorists.
('62', 15, 3, 13, 30268) It may be a negative kind.
('62', 15, 3, 14, 30295) I know what handicap I am working under.
('62', 15, 3, 15, 30336) But I have boundless confidence in my creed of non violence and in the end, not so distant as many people may imagine, non violence will visibly succeed.
('62', 15, 3, 16, 30490) Yours sincerely,
('62', 15, 4, 17, 30507) M. K. GANDHI H. K. HALES, ESQ., M. P. 53 GALSTAUN BLDGS RUSSEL STREET, CALCUTTA

('62', 18, 1, 2, 33246) 23. NOTES
('62', 18, 2, 3, 33256) MANY THANKS From friends all over India and from the West I have had many telegrams of the birthday greetings.
('62', 18, 2, 4, 33367) I am deeply thankful to them for these.
('62', 18, 2, 5, 33407) They will excuse me for my inability to send personal acknow ledgements.
('62', 18, 2, 6, 33480) I would have these friends to pray that God may make me worthy of their greetings.
('62', 18, 2, 7, 33563) I know that the senders expect that I should be rendering some service to humanity.
('62', 18, 2, 8, 33647) The wish is always persent.
('62', 18, 2, 9, 33675) God alone knows how far I succeed in the effort.
('62', 18, 2, 10, 33724) FORTHCOMING TOUR
('62', 18, 3, 11, 33741) If all goes well, my forthcoming tour for the Harijan cause should commence as from 8th November.
('62', 18, 3, 12, 33839) I am said to be making substantial progress and Dr. Khare, who is just now in charge, is of opinion that I could safely commence the tour from the date ment ioned.
('62', 18, 3, 13, 34003) But this does not mean that I can cope with crowded pro grammes as I used to before.
('62', 18, 3, 14, 34088) It is proposed to avoid travelling for two consecutive days, preferably Sundays and Mondays, in the week, to enable me to deal with Harijan editing and correspondence.
('62', 18, 3, 15, 34256) As usual I shall make collections wherever I am taken.
('62', 18, 3, 16, 34311) I should like to meet sanatanists at all places.
('62', 18, 3, 17, 34360) I have no doubt that much opposition to the movement is due to misunderstanding.
('62', 18, 3, 18, 34441) Naturally I must meet Harijans everywhere and there must be on the programme visits to Harijan quarters.
('62', 18, 3, 19, 34546) Late hours should be avoided.
('62', 18, 3, 20, 34576) Those places that feel tempted, in spite of the handicaps suggested here, to send invitations should send them to Thakkar Bapa as early as possible, so as to avoid alterations in the programme and disappointment.
('62', 18, 3, 21, 34789) All spectacular demonstrations, not required for the cause itself, should be avoided.
('62', 18, 3, 22, 34875) Every pice should be economized.
('62', 18, 3, 23, 34908) If addresses are to be presented at all, they should contain a brief description of the work done and statistics regarding Harijans, their occupations and economic condi tion, instead of a recital of my many excellences, which may be ex pected to take care of themselves, if there are any.
('62', 18, 4, 24, 35198) WILL OTHER UNIVERSITIES FOLLOW?
('62', 18, 5, 25, 35230) N. K. Behere, a member of the Nagpur University and C.P. High School Board, writes to say that he moved a resolution that “students belonging to the Depressed Classes and the aboriginal tribes
('62', 19, 0, 1, 35423) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 20
('62', 19, 1, 2, 35464) should not be charged examination fees”, that he is glad to say that it was passed, with the addition of the clause—“up to the year 1940”— by the University and with a time limit of five years by the High School Board, and that, therefore, no examination fees will be charged against these students from the Matriculation to the M.A. or L.L.B. examinations for these periods, as far as the Central Provinces are concerned.
('62', 19, 1, 3, 35887) I congratulate the Nagpur University, the High School Board and the mover on the passing of the resolution.
('62', 19, 1, 4, 35995) The addition of the time limit does not detract anything from the resolution.
('62', 19, 1, 5, 36073) It is a token of the optimism of the members of the respective bodies.
('62', 19, 1, 6, 36144) They evidently think that in five to seven years the economic status of the classes exempted will have so improved that they will not need the exemption any longer.
('62', 19, 1, 7, 36309) May that optimism be justified !
('62', 19, 1, 8, 36342) Will the other Indian Univversities and Boards copy the excellent example set by those of the Central provinces ?
('62', 19, 1, 9, 36456) Harijan, 14 10 1933
('62', 19, 2, 10, 36476) 24. SLAVERY V. UNTOUCHABILITY
('62', 19, 3, 11, 36506) Deenabandhu Andrews writes : 1
('62', 19, 4, 12, 36537) A century ago a far more terrible form of ‘man’s inhumanity to man’ that ‘untouchability’ was abolished in the West.
('62', 19, 4, 13, 36654) Slavery made men and women into chattels, to be bought and sold and possessed by their owners.
('62', 19, 4, 14, 36749) Negroes from Africa were transported on ships like cattle and set to work in the sugar plantations just like beasts of burden .
('62', 19, 4, 15, 36877) The results of this slave traffic were to create a colour problem in America and elsewhere which has never yet been solved.
('62', 19, 4, 16, 37001) It has been doubted whether any great moral reform has ever been carried through from purely humanitarian motives.
('62', 19, 4, 17, 37116) The nearest to reach the standard was the abolition of slavery.
('62', 19, 4, 18, 37180) Great Britain paid £ 20,000,000 out of its own revenue in order to get rid of the evil.
('62', 19, 4, 19, 37268) Therefore, it is not right to say that in politics philanthropy never gains its own victory.
('62', 19, 4, 20, 37361) In the year 1833, philanthropy won.
('62', 19, 5, 21, 37397) What then will happen in 1933 ?
('62', 19, 5, 22, 37429) Surely if India could abolish altogether, within the present year, ‘untouchability’, .
('62', 19, 5, 23, 37516) that would be the greatest philanthropic act of all.
('62', 19, 5, 24, 37569) Would that Deenabandhu’s hope were fulfilled.
('62', 19, 5, 25, 37615) Unless a miracle happens, the wholesale conversion of millions will not take place
('62', 19, 6, 26, 37698) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('62', 20, 0, 1, 37735) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 21
('62', 20, 1, 2, 37781) during the remaining months of this year and, may be, for many more years to come.
('62', 20, 1, 3, 37864) But what is the meaning of the abolition of untouchability and what was the meaning of the abolition of slavery in 1833 ?
('62', 20, 1, 4, 37986) The abo lition of slavery was a legislative act.
('62', 20, 1, 5, 38035) The slavery of the heart was not abolished then and even the lapse of a century has hardly abolished it altogether.
('62', 20, 1, 6, 38151) This is written, not to belittle the great act of 1833, but to clear our minds and to understand the limitations of the effort of 1833. Now, in the sense in which slavery was abolished in 1833, untou chability was abolished in 1932 at that representative meeting of Hindus assembled in Bombay in September 1932, 1 under the Chair manship of Pandit Malaviyaji.
('62', 20, 1, 7, 38511) It was no bogus affair.
('62', 20, 1, 8, 38535) It was signalized by the immediate establishment of the All India Anti untouchability Board.
('62', 20, 1, 9, 38628) There has been an incessant campaign against untouchability going on ever since, throughout the length and breadth of the land as the pages of Harijan can amply prove.
('62', 20, 1, 10, 38796) One life is being definitely held as hostage for the due fulfilment of the solemn pledge of the Hindus.
('62', 20, 1, 11, 38900) Let no one underrate the effort of 1932 by saying that, whereas the abolition of 1833 was an act of a legislature, that of 1932 was an act of a voluntary association and, therefore, lacking sanction.
('62', 20, 1, 12, 39100) In the nature of things the act of 1932 could not well be otherwise.
('62', 20, 1, 13, 39169) Slavery was a matter of contract enforceable at law, Untouchability as a religious institution is, as Deenabandhu Andrews rightly says, “moral slavery”.
('62', 20, 1, 14, 39322) This could not be abolished by law.
('62', 20, 1, 15, 39358) The only way in which it could be formally abolished was adopted in Bombay.
('62', 20, 1, 16, 39434) Nor, as I have already shown, does the act lack sanction.
('62', 20, 1, 17, 39492) The sanction, it is true, is moral.
('62', 20, 1, 18, 39528) But moral sanctions are in the end far more potent than legal sanctions.
('62', 20, 1, 19, 39601) Let the reader note that the Bills sought to be passed by the Central Legislature are not intended to be acts of abolition at all.
('62', 20, 1, 20, 39732) One is meant to regulate temple entry by Harijans and the other to withdraw legal recognition of untouchability.
('62', 20, 1, 21, 39845) Neither affects the religious recognition and social practice.
('62', 20, 1, 22, 39908) That is the function of the religious and social reformer.
('62', 20, 1, 23, 39967) The Bills are very much needed to expedite reform; they cannot abolish untouchability.
('62', 20, 1, 24, 40054) Untouchability is not a matter of contract.
('62', 20, 1, 25, 40098) ‘Untouchables’ cannot be bought or sold.
('62', 20, 1, 26, 40139) Thus, I hope, it is clear that the abolition of untouchability analogous to that of slavery in 1833 definitely took place on 24th

('62', 21, 1, 2, 40381) September 1932. Its anniversary was duly celebrated on the 24th day of last September.
('62', 21, 1, 3, 40468) When the whole mass of Hindus will respond to the Resolution of Bombay will largely depend upon the earnestness of those who passed it and those who are now seeking to enforce it.
('62', 21, 1, 4, 40648) But that is a process of which it will not be possible to say it took place on a particular day.

('62', 21, 1, 7, 41219) A sinner is equal to the saint in the eye of God.

('62', 22, 1, 2, 41998) 25. WHAT ONE MAN CAN DO
('62', 22, 2, 3, 42022) A would be Harijan Sevak writes to the following effect: 1
('62', 22, 3, 4, 42081) I have little doubt that my correspondent missed a golden opportunity of serving both the poor sweeper and the ‘orthodox’ family.
('62', 22, 3, 5, 42211) He should have gently remonstrated with the mother of the ‘polluted’ girl and he would have drawn her wrath towards himself, even if he had not shamed her into repentance.
('62', 22, 3, 6, 42383) The sweeper would have felt the warmth of a friend in her need.
('62', 22, 3, 7, 42447) The mother and the other relatives of the girl would at least have been set athinking.
('62', 22, 3, 8, 42534) He would probably have been drawn into an argument.
('62', 22, 3, 9, 42586) Perhaps the whole village might have interested itself in the matter and if he had risen to the occasion, he would have laid a solid foundation for substantial service in the future.
('62', 22, 3, 10, 42769) Or he might have had a broken head.
('62', 22, 3, 11, 42805) That, too, would have been a good passport for further service.
('62', 22, 3, 12, 42869) It is clear to me that on such occasions, every lover of humanity should consider it his sacred duty to protect the helpless by tactful and gentle, yet coura geous, intervention.
('62', 22, 3, 13, 43048) Now for the general question.
('62', 22, 3, 14, 43078) Had we not lost self confidence, the question, what an insignificant man can do, would never have arisen.
('62', 22, 3, 15, 43184) No man is too insignificant for rendering personal service to those who may be in distress.
('62', 22, 3, 16, 43276) The art does not need previous training.
('62', 22, 3, 17, 43317) The ability to give effective help resides in every human being who has the will and the necessary courage.
('62', 22, 3, 18, 43425) Thus my correspondent could certainly go to the Harijan quarters of his village and befriend them in a variety of ways.
('62', 22, 3, 19, 43545) He could teach their children during his stay in the village.
('62', 22, 3, 20, 43607) He need not fear the interruption due to his absence.
('62', 22, 3, 21, 43661) For teaching does not mean only a knowledge of the three R’s.
('62', 22, 3, 22, 43723) It means many other things for Harijan humanity.
('62', 22, 3, 23, 43772) lessons in manners and sani tation are the indispensable preliminaries to the initiation into the three R’s.
('62', 22, 3, 24, 43881) The correspondent could take Harijan children for sight seeing, teach them innocent and even instructive games, could sweep and otherwise keep Harijan quarters clean, could find out cases of
('62', 22, 4, 25, 44072) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('62', 22, 4, 26, 44109) It described how a Harijan woman, who had touched a caste Hindu girl, was subjected to filthy abuse by caste Hindus.
('62', 22, 4, 27, 44226) He also wanted to know how he could be useful in such a village where superstition reigned supreme and Harijans were treated like beasts.

('62', 23, 1, 2, 44405) illness among the Harijans and procure medical aid.
('62', 23, 1, 3, 44457) He could take careful notes of their economic, social and other wants and transmit them to the Harijan Seva Sangh of his district or province, as the case might be, and thus become an effective link between the Harijans and the Seva Sangh.
('62', 23, 1, 4, 44697) I have by no means exhausted the list of possibilities of individual effort.
('62', 23, 1, 5, 44774) Mine is a mere illustrative list.
('62', 23, 1, 6, 44808) A resourceful sevak can multiply the possibilities endlessly.

('62', 24, 9, 17, 46767) [Before October 15, 1933] We require machinery on a large scale for the industries running on steam power, etc.
('62', 24, 9, 18, 46879) We do not have such machinery at present; we

('62', 25, 0, 1, 47289) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 26
('62', 25, 1, 2, 47330) can get it from other countries only on the terms acceptable to them.
('62', 25, 1, 3, 47400) We would also require experts to run such machines.
('62', 25, 1, 4, 47452) We do not have enough of them either.
('62', 25, 1, 5, 47490) At present, therefore, we shall have to import them from outside.
('62', 25, 1, 6, 47556) Nor do we have the capital required to meet the needs of a population of 30 crores.
('62', 25, 1, 7, 47640) Hence, even if it is possible to be self sufficient through industries run on steam power, etc., it would take a long time.
('62', 25, 1, 8, 47764) Moreover, if this source of tremendous energy is employed on a large scale in the country, it would lead to a great increase in the present unemployment.
('62', 25, 1, 9, 47918) It is said that in America every man gets the work of 36 slaves with the help of gigantic machines.
('62', 25, 1, 10, 48018) This means that with the help of these machines each person does the work of 36 persons.
('62', 25, 1, 11, 48107) If we estimate that the population of India will be 37 crores when it reaches such a stage, it would mean that 36 crores of them would remain unemployed.
('62', 25, 1, 12, 48261) In other words, to enable one crore of people in this country to be as rich as Americans, 36 crores would have to commit suicide, or else a Chenghiz Khan or a Ravana should wipe out 36 crores and distribute the country among the remaining one crore.
('62', 25, 1, 13, 48511) The per capita distribution of land in this country is two or three bighas only.
('62', 25, 1, 14, 48592) This much land is certainly not enough for one’s maintenance.
('62', 25, 1, 15, 48654) Everyone, there fore, must have some other occupation at home.
('62', 25, 1, 16, 48717) This is naturally the spinning wheel.
('62', 25, 1, 17, 48755) We require very little capital to make it universal.
('62', 25, 1, 18, 48808) Other requirements would be available in every village.
('62', 25, 1, 19, 48864) All that is necessary is a change of attitude among the people.
('62', 25, 1, 20, 48928) They must shake off their lethargy.
('62', 25, 1, 21, 48964) The solution of the economic problem of Harijans also lies in this.
('62', 25, 1, 22, 49032) If the machine age comes into vogue, all the Harijans would be included among those 36 crores.

('62', 25, 2, 24, 49169) 30. REPERCUSSIONS OF UNTOUCHABILITY
('62', 25, 3, 25, 49205) Some idea of the wide repercussions of untouchability can be had from the following letter 1 of Sjt.
('62', 25, 3, 26, 49306) Mulchand Parekh.
('62', 25, 4, 27, 49323) 1 Not translated here.
('62', 25, 4, 28, 49346) The correspondent had described an incident in which a shepherd was considered responsible for bringing about disease and death to cattle because of his association with Harijans and was threatened with ostracism or worse.
('62', 26, 0, 1, 49569) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 27
('62', 26, 1, 2, 49615) Is it any wonder if the cup of sorrow overflows when to such ignorance and resultant superstitions is added the dross of untouch ability?
('62', 26, 1, 3, 49753) There is only one remedy for it and that is that a Harijan worker should tolerantly look upon all these insults as symptoms of the same disease and proceed to find a solution for it.
('62', 26, 1, 4, 49936) He should gain access to the shepherd’s family, explain things to them with patience and remove their ignorance.
('62', 26, 1, 5, 50049) If any jealous person has taken advan tage of their superstitious nature, he should make a peaceful endea vour to persuade him.
('62', 26, 1, 6, 50177) These experiences suggest that the workers ought to go to the villages and share the people’s lives.
('62', 26, 1, 7, 50278) Moreover, the frightened shepherd needs to be reassured.
('62', 26, 1, 8, 50335) He sould be convinced about the futility of a boycott and he should be made to feel secure with our readiness to protect him in every way.

('62', 26, 2, 10, 50516) 31. LETTER TO MADAN MOHAN MALAVIYA
('62', 26, 3, 11, 50551) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, WARDHA, October 15, 1933
('62', 26, 4, 12, 50595) As all the energy that I have been able to regain has been given to the immediate work in hand, I have not been able to write to you.
('62', 26, 4, 13, 50729) There was nothing new I had to say and I knew that you would not misunderstand any action that I took.
('62', 26, 4, 14, 50832) I, therefore, did not send my explanation believing that, if anything I did required explanation, you would not hesitate to demand it of me.
('62', 26, 4, 15, 50973) I have kept myself informed of your health, or rather want of it, and I realized long ago that it was vain to plead with you that you should take this change or that.
('62', 26, 4, 16, 51140) In this as in other matters you are a law unto yourself.
('62', 26, 4, 17, 51197) I do, therefore, satisfy myself with praying that God, who has taken care of you all these long years and who has blessed you with energy of which the youth of India may well be jealous, will continue to take care of you, so long as He needs your services.
('62', 26, 4, 18, 51454) I write this letter with reference to your latest statement.
('62', 26, 4, 19, 51515) My own impression is that the All India Congress Committee, if it meets, will
('62', 27, 0, 1, 51593) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 28
('62', 27, 1, 2, 51634) by an overwhelming majority pass a resolution endorsing continuance of the civil resistance movement.
('62', 27, 1, 3, 51736) That being my conviction, I see no reason for convening a meeting for such a confirmation, because the confirmation will not accelerate the pace of civil resistance.
('62', 27, 1, 4, 51902) It has to take its own natural course.
('62', 27, 1, 5, 51941) But, if you believe that the All India Congress Committee will adopt a new programme and give up civil resistance, there is absolutely no reason whatsoever why you should not actively canvass for a requisition on receipt of which Jawaharlal is bound to convene a meeting.
('62', 27, 1, 6, 52213) And I would venture to submit that if you would promote a requisition you should also in consultation with the requisitionists chalk out a definite policy and programme which you will prosecute unflinchingly.
('62', 27, 1, 7, 52422) If this is not done and a mere requi sition is sent the meeting will simply end in a desultory dis cussion and ill thought out resolutions.
('62', 27, 1, 8, 52562) Whilst I would gladly attend any such meeting and say my say, I am not keen on attending such a meeting and I would gladly refrain from attending it, if my absence was, from the highest motives, desired by you or any body of responsible mem bers.

('62', 29, 2, 3, 54493) October 15, 1933
('62', 29, 3, 4, 54510) DEAR JANAKDHARI BABU, On going through the arrears of my correspondence, I came upon your letter of 28th August last.
('62', 29, 3, 5, 54628) But, before I came upon your letter I was often thinking of you, and only the other day I discussed about you with Jamnalalji.
('62', 29, 3, 6, 54755) Your children are so young that it is very difficult for any insti tution to take them without you and your wife.
('62', 29, 3, 7, 54869) That means you must find something there.
('62', 29, 3, 8, 54911) The first thing is that you must humble yourself and put yourself on a level with the common labourer and bring up your children to become labourers.
('62', 29, 3, 9, 55061) But even labourers should have education.
('62', 29, 3, 10, 55103) That education should be given by you.
('62', 29, 3, 11, 55142) Your wife should also labour.
('62', 29, 3, 12, 55172) If you will accommodate yourself to this life, a great load will be off your mind, which itself would soothe your nerves and much of the dyspepsia would also go under the stimulating effect of the new life, that is, if you take it joyously.
('62', 29, 3, 13, 55413) Unless we who have received a fairly liberal education effect a revolution in our life, we would simply remain parasites that we are—living on the sweat of the famishing peasant.
('62', 29, 3, 14, 55592) You should discuss this matter with Brijkishore Babu and others.
('62', 29, 3, 15, 55657) I would like you to be the pioneer of the new thought and the new movement, and yet it is really not new, for, I gave it currency when I returned to India in 1915, and have been trying to live in accordance with it, however imperfectly I might have done it.
('62', 29, 3, 16, 55915) You have, therefore, to perfect it.

('62', 34, 5, 11, 63493) 42. STATEMENT TO PRESS
('62', 34, 6, 12, 63516) WARDHAGANJ, October 17, 1933 I regret to have to inform the public that Shrimati N. dis appeared suddenly from the Wardha Ashram about ten days ago.
('62', 34, 6, 13, 63665) She had of late become more than usually unbalanced.
('62', 34, 6, 14, 63718) All the affec tion that parents, brothers or sisters could show was shown to her, but evi dently her fearful past proved too strong for her.
('62', 34, 6, 15, 63859) It is likely that she is again leading the old thoughtless, untruthful and unclean life.
('62', 34, 6, 16, 63948) I give this information to warn young men against tempting her, or being tempted by her.
('62', 34, 6, 17, 64037) I would like those who may come in contact with her not to give any financial aid.
('62', 34, 6, 18, 64120) She is hardly responsible for her actions, and it would be a deliverance for her, if some philan thropic institution would take charge of her.
('62', 34, 6, 19, 64263) If she sees this notice, I would have her to recall all the promises she made to herself and to me, and in humility to ask God to exorcise the devil that has possessed her.
('62', 34, 6, 20, 64436) She knows that if she asks truly, her prayer will not go in vain.
('62', 34, 6, 21, 64502) She had such experiences in her sane moments.
('62', 34, 6, 22, 64548) She was last heard of in Delhi.
('62', 34, 7, 23, 64580) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 18 10 1933

('62', 37, 3, 4, 68149) 46. SPEECH AT WEDDING OF PRABHUDAS GANDHI
('62', 37, 4, 5, 68191) WARDHAGANJ October 18, 1933 At the conclusion of the ceremony addressing the couple Gandhiji said that this was an inter provincial marriage and not an inter caste one.
('62', 37, 4, 6, 68360) He had no hesitation in advocating inter caste marriages under well defined limitations, for he believed that there was no varna or division in the original sense of the term and that limiting marriage to the same division or varna was never its distin guishing feature.
('62', 37, 4, 7, 68631) He drew the attention of the couple to the fact that marriage was not intended to indulge in one’s passions but to impose a restraint upon them.
('62', 37, 4, 8, 68776) He hoped that both of them would make service of the country their mission in life and then they would find that their joint life would be one of happiness, contentment and increasing self res traint.
('62', 37, 4, 9, 68977) It gave him much pleasure to find that the bride came from an Arya Samajist family.
('62', 37, 4, 10, 69061) His relations with the Arya Samajists, he con tinued, had always been intimate, although they knew that there were honest differences between them.
('62', 37, 4, 11, 69209) This marriage had brought them nearer.
('62', 37, 4, 12, 69248) The Bombay Chronicle, 19 10 1933

('62', 38, 2, 12, 70286) 48. LETTER TO PANNALAL JHAVERI
('62', 38, 3, 13, 70317) ASHRAM, WARDHA, October 19, 1933
('62', 38, 4, 14, 70350) PANNALAL, It seems your letter has crossed my postcard.
('62', 38, 4, 15, 70406) Your purity has so impressed me that anything you write or any step you take cannot hurt me.
('62', 38, 4, 16, 70499) By that I do not mean that I shall always agree with you on the rightness of your step.
('62', 38, 4, 17, 70587) But the more experience I gain the more I realize that there are as many concep tions of dharma as there are individuals.
('62', 38, 4, 18, 70709) The deeper I delve the grea ter is my comprehension of the dictum of the Gita : Better to die following one’s own faith.
('62', 38, 4, 19, 70830) I certainly wish you success in what you have considered your dharma.I personally did wish that when others slackened, you would be able better to understand satyagraha.
('62', 38, 4, 20, 71000) I hold that satyagraha has not yet manifested itself in India in its true form.
('62', 38, 4, 21, 71080) The duty of manifesting it devolves on you and me, that is, the inmates of the Ashram.
('62', 38, 4, 22, 71167) For you, civil disobedience cannot be a political matter.
('62', 38, 4, 23, 71225) It can only be a matter of dharma.
('62', 38, 4, 24, 71260) Dharma reveals itself in its true form only when there is despair all around.
('62', 38, 4, 25, 71338) If we join the crowd in offering prayers, it would not be an indication of our faith.
('62', 38, 4, 26, 71424) But it would in some measure be a test of our faith if when others lost faith in prayer a handful of us continued to offer prayers and derived joy from so doing.
('62', 38, 4, 27, 71586) But what is dharma to me may not be dharma to you.
('62', 38, 4, 28, 71637) Only what you see as dharma will be dharma to you.
('62', 38, 4, 29, 71688) I have only conveyed my views to you as an elder.
('62', 38, 4, 30, 71738) If your reason does not accept it, if it does not appeal to your heart, then do not act on it.
('62', 38, 4, 31, 71833) Individual civil disobedience must
('62', 39, 0, 1, 71868) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 40
('62', 39, 1, 2, 71909) be taken to mean perfection.
('62', 39, 1, 3, 71938) If you are starting a goshala, are you going to do it on your own, or is there any room for suggestions and guidance?

('62', 47, 4, 22, 89067) 56. AN M.A. IN A HURRY
('62', 47, 5, 23, 89090) An M. A. of Kerala writes a long letter from which I take the following paragraphs 4 of public importance : I can heartily endorse my correspondent’s statement that ‘there can be no peace for me or him and his friends, if untouchability con tinues in our country’.
('62', 47, 5, 24, 89355) My word also stands.
('62', 47, 5, 25, 89376) But untouchability will not be removed by force or, which is perhaps the same thing, by law, not will temples be opened by such means.
('62', 47, 5, 26, 89511) Legislation is badly re quired to remove legal obstruction which has been created by certain judicial decisions.
('62', 47, 5, 27, 89624) But if and when the two Bills are passed, untou chability lurking in the Hindu heart will not necessarily be removed
('62', 47, 6, 28, 89741) 1 Coarse silk for making blouse 2 A variety of khadi 3 This and the subscription is in Gandhiji’s own hand.
('62', 47, 6, 29, 89849) 4 Not reproduced here.
('62', 47, 6, 30, 89872) The correspondent had written about the continuing evil of utouchabilty, indifference of khadi workers towards Harijan work and villagers’ attitude towards Harijans, and suggested steps to instil courage, self confidence, etc., into Harijans.
('62', 48, 0, 1, 90115) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 49
('62', 48, 1, 2, 90161) nor will public temples be automatically opened.
('62', 48, 1, 3, 90210) Untouchability will go when the Hindu heart has melted, and the public temples will be opened when the worshippers have discovered that God is no res pector of persons and that He does not reside in temples which man’s insolence or ignorance has closed against any body of persons who are desirous of offering worship on the same terms as they.
('62', 48, 1, 4, 90555) The correspondent would throw the sole responsibility for opening the Guruvayur temple on me.
('62', 48, 1, 5, 90649) He should know that it is no one man’s work.
('62', 48, 1, 6, 90694) It will be done in God’s good time.
('62', 48, 1, 7, 90730) Workers can but work to the best of their ability.
('62', 48, 1, 8, 90781) Let him also know that Kelappan’s pledge is not exhausted.
('62', 48, 1, 9, 90840) His visit to Colombo is temporary.
('62', 48, 1, 10, 90875) Rajagopalachari works by prayer even though he is in prison.
('62', 48, 1, 11, 90936) Mad havan Nair, that great and true Kerala servant, is no more.
('62', 48, 1, 12, 91000) But I have no doubt that his spirit watches over our conduct and misconduct.
('62', 48, 1, 13, 91077) It will not rest till Hinduism is purified of the evil of untouchability.
('62', 48, 1, 14, 91151) And the correspondent may rest assured that, when the proper time comes and if God wills it, both Kelappan and I would again stake our lives for the opening, not only of the Guruvayur temple, but many others.
('62', 48, 1, 15, 91360) As to the khadi service, the correspondent’s complaint is wholly unjustified.
('62', 48, 1, 16, 91438) Those who are engaged in khadi service may not very well be expected to give their time to Harijan service.
('62', 48, 1, 17, 91546) But I know that the vast majority of them have no untouchability in their breasts and that they never miss an opportunity of rendering whatever personal service they can to Harijans.
('62', 48, 1, 18, 91729) There is no bar to taking Harijans in Khadi service.
('62', 48, 1, 19, 91782) Lastly I may state that several thousand Harijan families are being supported through the khadi organizations dotted over the whole country.
('62', 48, 1, 20, 91923) The correspondent is on surer ground in his complaints about villagers’ attitude in many parts of India.
('62', 48, 1, 21, 92028) The ignorance of the villa gers is colossal.
('62', 48, 1, 22, 92073) They are wedded to the idea of high and low.
('62', 48, 1, 23, 92118) Village workers are far too few for the numerous villages.
('62', 48, 1, 24, 92177) But there is no cause whatever for despair.
('62', 48, 1, 25, 92221) Villagers are waking up.
('62', 48, 1, 26, 92246) They have begun to realize that to deny to fellow beings the same status that they have for themselves is to deny God’s equal justice.
('62', 48, 1, 27, 92381) The correspondent has no notion of the silent but solid work that many workers are doing in and around villages.
('62', 48, 1, 28, 92494) This Harijan work being purely religious does not lend itself much to the spectacular.
('62', 48, 1, 29, 92581) It will prosper in exact proportion to the purity and penance of the workers.
('62', 48, 1, 30, 92659) It will be surely
('62', 49, 0, 1, 92677) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 50
('62', 49, 1, 2, 92718) retarded by the impurity, selfishness or mixed motives of workers.
('62', 49, 1, 3, 92785) As to putting life into Harijans, it will be there immediately the crushing dead weight of untouchability is lifted from off the heads of Harijans.
('62', 49, 1, 4, 92933) They should, of course, have, as they are having, religious and other instruction in the many schools that have been and are being opened.
('62', 49, 1, 5, 93072) Time is on our side and so is the time spirit.
('62', 49, 1, 6, 93119) No religion can possibly stand the blazing light of the world’s opinion that is being directed towards all religions, and still retain in it proved evils and superstitions.

('62', 49, 2, 8, 93312) 57. WHAT OF SWEEPERS IF .
('62', 49, 3, 9, 93338) An English friend referring to two ladies who are coming to India writes : 1
('62', 49, 4, 10, 93415) want to do their own “sweeper” work, even though it may get them into trouble with some of the local caste Hindus .
('62', 49, 4, 11, 93531) it may get them into difficulties with the local sweepers, who will complain .
('62', 49, 4, 12, 93610) that they are losing good work, and good wages.
('62', 49, 4, 13, 93658) Now, what is the right reply to that ?
('62', 49, 4, 14, 93697) Supposing that thousand of millions of caste Hindus and others, up and down India, resolved to do their own “sweeping”, as an act of penance and visible proof that they felt themselves no better than sweepers, many sweepers would lose their livelihood .
('62', 49, 4, 15, 93951) It is to some extent the old story (in a different form) of the displacement of labour as a result of social development.
('62', 49, 4, 16, 94073) I don’t remember seeing any comment of yours or anyone’s on this point in Harijan .
('62', 49, 4, 17, 94157) It is quite true that I have not discussed this question in these pages as a difficulty, as it has never arisen that way as yet.
('62', 49, 4, 18, 94286) In several places, including the late Ashram at Sabarmati and its branch at Wardha, the inmates have been doing their own sweeper work without the local sweepers being ruffled.
('62', 49, 4, 19, 94463) At Sabarmati, in the beginning stages, we had sweepers, who were paid a paltry sum.
('62', 49, 4, 20, 94547) It was not possi ble to pay them more for about two hours’ work which at best was never satisfactorily done.
('62', 49, 4, 21, 94656) They did not know the hygienic method.
('62', 49, 4, 22, 94695) They would not easily take to it Sanitary service is by no means a hereditary occupation of long standing.
('62', 49, 4, 23, 94802) All the evidence hitherto collected by me goes to show that before the Mohammedan conquest there were no professional sweepers; the Hindu social system, being based on rural conditions, did not necessitate such sanitary service as
('62', 49, 5, 24, 95033) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('62', 50, 0, 1, 95070) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 51
('62', 50, 1, 2, 95116) is indispensable in these days of rapid urban growth.
('62', 50, 1, 3, 95170) I do not, however, wish to convey the meaning that rural sanitation during the purely Hindu period was by any means perfect or even fairly satis factory.
('62', 50, 1, 4, 95324) On the contrary, it seems to have been very crude.
('62', 50, 1, 5, 95375) The highly scientific methods evolved and still being developed in the West are undoubtedly a recent and very beneficial growth.
('62', 50, 1, 6, 95504) Holding these views, I can only welcome the determination of the two English sisters to do their own sweeper work.
('62', 50, 1, 7, 95619) If I were in their place, I should invite the sweepers in the neighbourhood to give other service, if they were in want of employment, or to learn the hygienic and clean method of doing sanitary work if they were minded so to do.
('62', 50, 1, 8, 95849) Whether they took up some other work or no, whether they volunteered to learn better methods of sanitation or no, they could not harbour any feeling of being wronged for not being asked to do sanitary service for the sisters, for I would expect them to work for the betterment of Harijans in a hundred ways.
('62', 50, 1, 9, 96157) The difficulty can only, and must always, arise when things are done in a patronizing or selfish manner.
('62', 50, 1, 10, 96262) I would, for instance, be patronizing, if I offered now and then to work a little in a touch me not fashion, side by side with my sweeper, just in order to be able to declare at public meetings that even I did sweeping alongside my sweeper.
('62', 50, 1, 11, 96503) I would be acting selfishly if I did my own sweeping for the sake of keeping my closets cleaner than they would otherwise be and did not want to waste my time in teaching my sweeper the modern method or did not want to pay more for more efficient and more intelligent service.
('62', 50, 1, 12, 96780) But there never can be any offence taken when I serve my sweeper neighbours in a variety of ways and, by doing my own sweeping, teach them by example that sanitary service is not only not a mean occupation, but a perfectly honourable and most useful occupation which everyone should learn and many may follow with great benefit to society, if it is taken up in a humanitarian spirit.
('62', 50, 2, 13, 97164) Harijan, 21 10 1933

('62', 56, 10, 26, 106117) 69. INTERVIEW TO “UNATI” [Before October 22, 1933] 2
('62', 56, 11, 27, 106170) Q. Inspite of efforts on the part of social reformers, the standard of living of educated communities in Sind has been rising very rapidly; what would you advise under the circumsatnces ?
('62', 56, 12, 28, 106358) 1 Vimala, daughter of Chhaganlal Joshi 2 The report was released to the Press from Hyderabad (Sind) on this date.
('62', 57, 0, 1, 106472) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 58
('62', 57, 1, 2, 106513) A. I would advise those who think this is wrong to set an example by living simply and thinking and acting nobly.
('62', 57, 2, 3, 106627) Q. Young men believe that unless they are in a position to earn from Rs. 150 to 200 per month, they cannot even think of marriage.
('62', 57, 2, 4, 106758) At the same time, an ever in creasing number of them keep on imagining that it is legitimate to satisfy sexual instinct in some way or another without undertaking the obligations of married life; how do you view such a mentality ?
('62', 57, 3, 5, 106989) A. I can only look upon it with shame and deep regret.
('62', 57, 3, 6, 107044) Such mentality can only lead to suicide.
('62', 57, 3, 7, 107085) The only cure for it is for young men, who realize te enormity of the evil, to set their faces against it by showing the greatest purity in their own lives and correctness of conduct.
('62', 57, 4, 8, 107269) Q. What advice would you give to young girls who have perforce to remain unmarried or who are not in a mood to marry ?
('62', 57, 5, 9, 107388) A. Such girls should go out of their little communities or even Provinces in search of suitable deserving companions.
('62', 57, 5, 10, 107506) The sooner we get through the spirit of provincialism and exclusive caste, the better would it be for us.
('62', 57, 5, 11, 107612) I cannot understand why an educated Amil should be in search of an Amil companion and why he or she should not take a deserving companion from any part of India, the condition being, not selfish gratification of base animal passions, but search after spiri tual growth and national advancement.
('62', 57, 6, 12, 107907) Q. Would you not advise the Amil girls to break the barriers of Amilism and be prepared to marry any non Amil—be he a Bhaibund or a Bhatia or any other ?
('62', 57, 6, 13, 108061) What are your views on inter marriages between Sindhis and Gujaratis, etc.
('62', 57, 7, 14, 108136) A. Already answered above.
('62', 57, 8, 15, 108163) Q. If you hold that “man and woman should be given fullest opportunity for self expression”, would you advise that young girls and young boys should be given unfettered discretion in mixing or associating with each other, irrespective of parents’ knowledge or control ?
('62', 57, 8, 16, 108433) Also, should girls be allowed to move about as freely as boys do?
('62', 57, 9, 17, 108499) A. Most decidedly not.
('62', 57, 9, 18, 108522) I believe in the middle path.
('62', 57, 9, 19, 108552) Most boys and girls should be guided and allow themselves to be guided by their parents and guardians and the latter on their part should cherish and promote the independence of their boys and girls who may be under their guardianship or supervision.
('62', 57, 9, 20, 108803) If the youth of the country will remain pure they should avoid all secretiveness.
('62', 57, 10, 21, 108885) Q. It is maintained by the old people that in view of the peculiar conditions obtaining in Sind, it is not safe to discard purdah, but young men are naturally
('62', 58, 0, 1, 109044) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 59
('62', 58, 1, 2, 109090) against this system which they regard as highly pernicious.
('62', 58, 1, 3, 109150) What would you suggest
('62', 58, 2, 4, 109173) to avoid the clash on this point of difference between the young and the old ?
('62', 58, 2, 5, 109252) A. I have never believed in the purdah system.
('62', 58, 2, 6, 109299) I think it is fast going and the girls, who dare to tear the purdah and demonstrate to their neighbours that no harm has befallen them in any way whatever, will be most potent proofs for removing the prejudice or fear.
('62', 58, 2, 7, 109518) Tearing down the purdah does not mean that girls should wander about anywhere and everywhere.
('62', 58, 2, 8, 109612) It is the hiding of one’ face in the presence of men which I consider to be so highly injurious to one’s growth or self expression.
('62', 58, 2, 9, 109744) Modesty is the best protection and purdah.
('62', 58, 3, 10, 109787) Q. What are your views on co education ?
('62', 58, 4, 11, 109828) A. I believe in well regulated and well thought out co education.

('62', 58, 5, 13, 109927) 70. TALK WITH A FRIEND 1
('62', 58, 6, 14, 109952) [Before October 22, 1933] You are aware of the agreement 2 among the so called minority communities when the Round Table Conference was in progress in London.
('62', 58, 6, 15, 110111) The Harijans also were included among them.
('62', 58, 6, 16, 110155) I staked my life for them at that time.
('62', 58, 6, 17, 110195) 3 Being a far sighted man I realized that since some sort of a constitution was coming, if the Government acce pted the scheme contained in that agreement our relations with Harijans would come to an end and Hindu society would be perma nently divided.
('62', 58, 6, 18, 110448) Harijans would either separate from the rest of the Hindus and form a new community; or would merge in some other community; but they would not continue to belong to the Hindu fold.
('62', 58, 6, 19, 110630) I saw that this would mean the destruction of Hinduism.
('62', 58, 6, 20, 110686) It would be destroyed not because 60 million people would have left it, but because of the reasons driving them to that course.
('62', 58, 6, 21, 110814) Anyone is free to abandon Hinduism if he so chooses, but we, the caste Hindus, should not be the cause of their doing so.
('62', 58, 6, 22, 110936) I, therefore, felt that it was my dharma to prevent such a division even at the cost of my life.

('62', 59, 1, 4, 111638) If you believe that I had taken the right step in opposing the British Cabinet’s Award, all the other steps follow logically from it.
('62', 59, 2, 5, 111772) Q. Will you kindly explain that in more detail ?

('62', 59, 3, 7, 111850) succeed in getting the scheme of separate electorates for Harijans altered, but what
('62', 59, 4, 8, 111935) was the justification of the other steps ?
('62', 59, 5, 9, 111978) A. The desire to get the Cabinet Award amended was merely the originating cause of the fast.
('62', 59, 5, 10, 112071) But with its amendment a duty devolved on the caste Hindus.
('62', 59, 5, 11, 112131) Hence, when Sir Purushottamdas 1 and Sjt.
('62', 59, 5, 12, 112173) Ghan shyamdas visited me in jail, I told them that I would not be content merely with the amendment of the Cabinet Award and that the caste Hindus would have to do a great deal.
('62', 59, 5, 13, 112351) Then I embodied this in the form of a resolution.
('62', 59, 5, 14, 112401) It was passed at the Bombay Conference on Sep tember the 25th in almost the very words of my draft.
('62', 59, 5, 15, 112501) 3 It was stated therein that from then on no one would be regarded as an untouc hable in Hinduism and that all temples and other public places would be accessible to Harijans to the same extent that they were to the other Hindus.
('62', 59, 5, 16, 112731) When all the leaders came to me after the Resolution was passed, I pledged my life to the Harijan leaders for the implemen tation of the Resolution.
('62', 59, 5, 17, 112880) Hence it became incumbent upon me to take steps even in Yeravda jail.
('62', 59, 5, 18, 112950) I corresponded with the Govern ment to get the doors of the prison that had closed after that fast opened again, and told it that I would have to keep the caste Hindus awake to their duty, and that, therefore, I should not lose contact with them.
('62', 59, 5, 19, 113197) As a result of the correspondence, the Government granted me full per mission to carry on Harijan work from prison.
('62', 59, 5, 20, 113313) 4 Then I noticed some impurity among the Harijan workers and in consequence I had to resort to the 21 days’ fast.
('62', 59, 5, 21, 113427) Then I was imprisoned again in August and asked for the same facilities as before.
('62', 59, 5, 22, 113510) On their being refused, there followed another fast of 8 days.
('62', 59, 6, 23, 113573) Q. Can you say more about this impurity among the workers ?

('62', 61, 4, 12, 117151) 71. SEATS FOR HARIJANS 1
('62', 61, 5, 13, 117176) [Before October 22, 1933] To say that Harijans will not be able to use their franchise pro perly and will not be able to understand the interests of the country is to lay the axe at the very root of the principles of democracy.
('62', 61, 5, 14, 117404) It is like the imperialists telling us that we are not fit for democracy and will never learn the proper use of the franchise.
('62', 61, 5, 15, 117531) Mistakes will always be made.
('62', 61, 5, 16, 117561) We shall progress only through mistakes.
('62', 61, 5, 17, 117602) But does it mean that we should not have the right to vote ?
('62', 61, 5, 18, 117663) Exercise of the right of voting will in itself be an education for Harijans.
('62', 61, 5, 19, 117740) Nor would it be proper to say that they would not under stand national interests.
('62', 61, 5, 20, 117822) Their repre sentatives would be persons elected with our own votes.
('62', 61, 5, 21, 117890) For every Harijan seat, Harijans would elect four persons, and from among these four we shall have to elect one.
('62', 61, 5, 22, 118003) Would we not find even one person from among them who would understand the nation’s interests ?
('62', 61, 5, 23, 118099) If we really do not find such a person, then the fault would be ours for having neglected them to that extent.
('62', 61, 5, 24, 118210) The right way is to embrace them and win over their hearts by serving them.
('62', 61, 5, 25, 118286) It won’t help to distrust them.

('62', 64, 0, 1, 122479) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 65
('62', 64, 1, 2, 122525) I would answer them in the following order— (1) Any vow to be taken must be written out in precise terms.
('62', 64, 1, 3, 122631) It should be done in the presence of a witness , if available at the time.
('62', 64, 1, 4, 122706) If a doubt arises, it must be interpreted rigidly, not loosely.
('62', 64, 1, 5, 122770) Nothing should be appended to it, under the excuse of being left out, which would weaken it.
('62', 64, 1, 6, 122863) For instance, say, I pledge not to touch liquor.
('62', 64, 1, 7, 122912) No country has been mentioned in this pledge.
('62', 64, 1, 8, 122958) I then go to England and someone persuades me to take liquor on grounds of health.
('62', 64, 1, 9, 123041) Now, I cannot argue that since I happened to be in India at the time of taking the pledge it applied only to my stay there and that I was free to take liquor while abroad.
('62', 64, 1, 10, 123213) Nor can I permit myself to take liquor as a medicine on the ground that there was no mention of medicines in the pledge.
('62', 64, 1, 11, 123334) (2) As in the case of other activities, the time for prayer too must be fixed.
('62', 64, 1, 12, 123413) It matters little what time is fixed for it.
('62', 64, 1, 13, 123458) It is best to have it just before bed time and on waking up in the morning after cleaning one's teeth.
('62', 64, 1, 14, 123561) It is also necessary to have fixed hours of sleep.
('62', 64, 1, 15, 123612) No one can achieve concentration of mind all at once.
('62', 64, 1, 16, 123666) As the saying goes, "even hard black rocks can be cut with a rope." So concentration will automatically follow in the wake of regular praying.
('62', 64, 1, 17, 123809) So long as this is not attained, one should diligently continue to pray every day rather than worry about it.
('62', 64, 1, 18, 123919) “You should never accept defeat, even if you die.” (3) Never give up the practice of writing a diary once you have resolved to do so.
('62', 64, 1, 19, 124053) If not immediately, you will certainly realize its advantages later.
('62', 64, 1, 20, 124122) This habit itself will guard us against many of our shortcomings as the diary will be a permanent witness to these.
('62', 64, 1, 21, 124238) All the slips must be noted in the diary.
('62', 64, 1, 22, 124280) There is no need to condemn them.
('62', 64, 1, 23, 124314) Criticism is always taken for granted.
('62', 64, 1, 24, 124353) It is enough to mention, say, ‘Today I was angry with B; today I deceived A.’ There is no need to make observations like, ‘This was very unfortunate, ‘Oh me!
('62', 64, 1, 25, 124511) I must not repeat it.’ Words in praise of oneself should never be there.
('62', 64, 1, 26, 124584) It is enough to note down the work done and the slips committed.
('62', 64, 1, 27, 124649) The diary should not take note of other people’s faults.

('62', 64, 1, 29, 124753) Neither the language of the Gita, nor my own, is aphoritics.

('62', 64, 2, 31, 124899) (1) What are the factors to be considered before taking a vow and whether in can be modified afterwards?

('62', 65, 0, 1, 125082) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 66
('62', 65, 1, 2, 125123) write the language of the Gita, but I am far removed from it.
('62', 65, 1, 3, 125185) Whatever we read on a subject with which we have little familiarity, appears to us aphoristic.
('62', 65, 1, 4, 125280) Technical language is language which is adequate for the purposes of that subject alone.
('62', 65, 1, 5, 125369) To those who are not familair with it, it sounds aphoristic.
('62', 65, 1, 6, 125430) But this is one thing and the sutras 1 of Patanjali are another thing.
('62', 65, 1, 7, 125501) The latter leave many things unsaid.
('62', 65, 1, 8, 125538) This cannot be said of the Gita.
('62', 65, 1, 9, 125571) But here the author gives a new connotation to familiar expressions, which makes them difficult to understand.
('62', 65, 1, 10, 125682) My language has one quality, viz.
('62', 65, 1, 11, 125716) brevity.
('62', 65, 1, 12, 125725) However, it is imperfect, whereas the Gita is perfect.
('62', 65, 1, 13, 125780) When I say that my language is imperfect I do not imply that I have inadequate command over the language, although that too is true.
('62', 65, 1, 14, 125913) What is implied here is that my thoughts are imperfect.
('62', 65, 1, 15, 125969) Hence there is bound to be difficulty in understanding them.
('62', 65, 1, 16, 126030) As my thoughts mature, they will come to be expressed so as to be easily comprehended.
('62', 65, 1, 17, 126117) Having admitted this shortcoming in my language, I can still say that some readers do not make the fullest effort and then fail to understand even perfectly expressed ideas.
('62', 65, 1, 18, 126291) And then they blame me!
('62', 65, 1, 19, 126315) For example, let us take the instance cited by the correspondent himself.
('62', 65, 1, 20, 126389) Spinning is a tangible activity; it can therefore be actually demonstrated.
('62', 65, 1, 21, 126465) Agitation of the mind is intangible.
('62', 65, 1, 22, 126502) It is quite correct to say that restlessness can be got over by practice.
('62', 65, 1, 23, 126576) Today, we have no means for actually demonstrating [the truth of] this.
('62', 65, 1, 24, 126648) If we learn to reduce our thought processes to a visual image we would be able to obtain a picture of this practice too as we do of spinning.
('62', 65, 1, 25, 126790) At present we can only say that mental restlessness can be got rid of through diligent praying.
('62', 65, 1, 26, 126886) In this, one has to rely on the truthfulness of the student, i.e., his adherence to truth.
('62', 65, 1, 27, 126977) Who can know a person who pretends to pray while continuing to be agitated ?
('62', 65, 1, 28, 127054) Or, who is there to rebuke the individual who deceives himself every day and while praying daily makes many impossible plans ?
('62', 65, 1, 29, 127181) In other words, the success of practice depends entirely upon the sincerity of the aspirant.
('62', 65, 1, 30, 127274) If there is insincerity in spinning, it can be pointed out to the spinner, since it can be directly perceived.
('62', 65, 1, 31, 127385) (5) “You should be satisfied with whatever little you get” does not imply that a lazy person may rest satisfied with what he gets.
('62', 65, 1, 32, 127516) The implication is that one should be satisfied with what one gets after making constant and sincere effort.
('62', 65, 1, 33, 127625) That is to say that in addition to the utmost human effort, God in heaven has His say on the result.
('62', 65, 2, 34, 127726) 1 Yogasutras enunciated by Patanjanli.
('62', 66, 0, 1, 127765) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 67
('62', 66, 1, 2, 127811) Hence, there is absolutely no need to be despondent if the effort does not appear to bear fruit.
('62', 66, 1, 3, 127908) This is what the author of the Gita suggests.
