('62', 76, 1, 2, 142673) 93. LETTER TO JANAKIDEVI BAJAJ 1
('62', 76, 2, 3, 142706) October 25, 1933
('62', 76, 3, 4, 142723) DEAR SISTER, I must congratulate you on your proposed visit to Calcutta for the purpose of ending the custom of purdah among the sisters there.
('62', 76, 3, 5, 142867) Purdah is not only a superstitious obsession, I feel it also smacks of sin.
('62', 76, 3, 6, 142943) Purdah from whom ?
('62', 76, 3, 7, 142962) Are all men steeped in lust ?
('62', 76, 3, 8, 142992) Cannot a women retain her purity without observing purdah ?
('62', 76, 3, 9, 143052) Purity is a state of mind.
('62', 76, 3, 10, 143079) It ought to come spontaneously to all men.

('62', 81, 2, 13, 151627) 100. A TRAGEDY
('62', 81, 3, 14, 151642) The longer I live the more do I realize that the happiness which I enjoy and which so many friends envy persists inspite of tragedies of which I have always had my due share.
('62', 81, 3, 15, 151817) The latest is the disappearance of N. I have no doubt that her repentance was sincere.
('62', 81, 3, 16, 151904) She struggled bravely against her past, but it did appear to me on my coming to Wardha that the struggle was getting too severe for her.
('62', 81, 3, 17, 152041) She was becoming unhinged and losing control over herself.
('62', 81, 3, 18, 152100) Previously, in one of her letters from Wardha, she had hinted that she might become insane.
('62', 81, 3, 19, 152192) All the affection that could be shown to her was shown.
('62', 81, 3, 20, 152248) She was never insensible to it.
('62', 81, 3, 21, 152280) She was most responsive.
('62', 81, 3, 22, 152305) But she was also most impulsive.
('62', 81, 3, 23, 152338) She has gone away without any money or belongings.
('62', 81, 3, 24, 152389) The reports published about her in the Delhi Press are sensational manufactures and do her grave injustice.
('62', 81, 3, 25, 152497) She cannot be held responsible for her actions in her present mental state.
('62', 81, 3, 26, 152573) Her proper place is in a philanthropic institution or in an asylum.
('62', 81, 3, 27, 152641) Those who will throw a few silver piecess at her out of false compassion, or in order to get rid of her, will do her no kindness.
('62', 81, 3, 28, 152771) Being irresponsible, she has been squandering what she has received.
('62', 81, 3, 29, 152840) I would esteem it a favour if those who may come in contact with her will give me her address and show this writing to her.

('62', 82, 0, 1, 152984) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 83
('62', 82, 1, 2, 153030) 101. KHADI AND HARIJANS
('62', 82, 2, 3, 153054) Very few people have any notion of what khadi means to Harijans.
('62', 82, 2, 4, 153119) Simple weaving is almost an exclusive speciality of Harijans, and even though mill spinning and weaving have deprived many Harijans of a source of livelihood, thousands of them are still dependant upon weaving.
('62', 82, 2, 5, 153330) But a friend argues : “What is the use of keeping alive a perishing industry ?
('62', 82, 2, 6, 153409) Why not give them instead an industry that may be growing ?
('62', 82, 2, 7, 153469) Surely, you do not intend to confine them to worn out occupations even when you are devising all manner of means for their uplift otherwise.” Indeed, I have desire to confine Harijans, or for that matter, anybody, to spinning and weaving or to any one occupation, if they can be more profitably employed in any other; only I do not take the gloomy view of hand spinning and weaving which the objector takes.
('62', 82, 2, 8, 153877) I personally believe that hand ginning, hand carding, hand spinning and hand weaving have a brilliant future, at least in India.
('62', 82, 2, 9, 154006) If the millions are to live with any degree of comfort, the mills must seek main custom outside India.
('62', 82, 2, 10, 154109) The villagers must be induced to supplement their scanty resources by hand spinning, hand weaving, etc., assuming that millions of villagers could be better employed, for the indigenous mills to supply all the needs of the nation means long delay—several generations—and then, too, it must mean the need of big capital and dependence for machinery and technical skill upon foreign countries.
('62', 82, 2, 11, 154501) In the abstract, whilst there may be nothing wrong in depending upon foreign machinery and foreign skill, in practice it cannot but be a terrible handicap upon the mill industry.
('62', 82, 2, 12, 154680) So long as this industry has got to depend upon external help, it would be untrue to call it an indigenous industry.
('62', 82, 2, 13, 154797) On the other hand, khadi, as a village industry, requires very little capital.
('62', 82, 2, 14, 154876) The implements can all be manufactured in the villages them selves, and there is no lack of indigenous techincal skill.
('62', 82, 2, 15, 154996) The only thing necessary is to change the mentality of the people.
('62', 82, 2, 16, 155063) Inspite, therefore, of the most skilful arguments to the contrary, and of imposing statistics with regard to the output of mills, I remain con firmed in my opinion that khadi in India has a very big future.
('62', 82, 2, 17, 155270) What we may not do voluntarily and out of conviction, we shall be obliged to do through force of circumstances.
('62', 82, 2, 18, 155382) India has to live, that is, her millions have to live.
('62', 82, 2, 19, 155437) There is no difference of opinion as to the fact
('62', 83, 0, 1, 155486) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 84
('62', 83, 1, 2, 155527) that they are not living today.
('62', 83, 1, 3, 155559) They are merely existing.
('62', 83, 1, 4, 155585) There is no other country in the world where so many million of people have only partial employment and where, inspite of the civilization being predominantly rural, the holdings are rarely two acres per head.
('62', 83, 1, 5, 155795) To manufacture the whole of her cloth requirements through steam or electricity, or any other than the human power behind the wheel, is still further to deepen the unemployment of the population.
('62', 83, 1, 6, 155991) An indus trialized India must, therefore, mean utter extinction of many millions, including, naturally, Harijans, who occupy, to our utter shame, the lowest strata of society.
('62', 83, 1, 7, 156167) It is said that through highly industrialized processes every American owns what is equivalent to 36 slaves.
('62', 83, 1, 8, 156276) If we use America as our model, and if we allowed only 30 slaves to every Indian instead of 36, out of our 31 crores of human beings, 30 crores must perform hara kiri or be killed off.
('62', 83, 1, 9, 156461) I know that some enthusiastic patriots will not only not mind such a process, but they will welcome it.
('62', 83, 1, 10, 156565) They will say that it is better to have one crore of happy, contented, prosperous Indians, armed to the teeth, than to have 30 crores of unarmed creatures who can hardly walk.
('62', 83, 1, 11, 156741) I have no answer to that philosophy, because, being saturated with the Harijan mentality, I can only think in terms of the millions of villagers and can only make my happiness dependent upon that of the poorest amongst them, and want to live only if they can live.My very simple mind cannot go beyond the little spindle of the little wheel which I can carry about with me from place to place and which I can manufacture without difficulty.
('62', 83, 1, 12, 157181) In this con nection a friend sends me the following paragraph 1 which is going round the Press :
('62', 83, 2, 13, 157278) To relieve unemployment in certain industries the Nazis have ordered the stoppage of the use of machines which were displacing human labour.
('62', 83, 2, 14, 157419) Commenting on this interdiction the Manchester Guardian remarks : “There
('62', 83, 3, 15, 157492) has been a great deal of discussion about the effects of machinery in aggravating the unemployment crisis, but it has been left to the Nazis to do the logical thing and stop using it.
('62', 83, 3, 16, 157676) Mr. Gandhi’s efforts to replace the spinning frame by the hand wheel and the mechanical loom by the handloom are being paralleled closely in the German cigar and glass industries.” The Guardian concludes its remarks by observing that, if Ger many’s ‘ethics become mediaeval, there is no reason why her eco nomics should not become mediaeval also’.Replying to these
('62', 83, 4, 17, 158041) 1 From which only extracts are reproduced here.
('62', 84, 0, 1, 158089) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 85
('62', 84, 1, 2, 158135) comments, a correspondent writes in the Guardian : i
('62', 84, 2, 3, 158188) Hitler, Gandhi and others who in different ways are endeavouring to slow production to a point at which all goods are consumed may be reverting to mediaeval methods, but handicrafts are neither retrograde nor barbaric.
('62', 84, 2, 4, 158407) They are taught in every progressive elementary and secondary school .
('62', 84, 2, 5, 158478) So long as machinery promotes the happiness and the prosperity of the masses as well as the classes it is a beneficent agent.
('62', 84, 2, 6, 158604) But when it leads to the unemployment and starvation of millions, as is happening in the highly industrialized countries of the West, it becomes a curse.
('62', 84, 2, 7, 158758) Machinery exists for man, and not vice versa, and must be made subservient to the well being of the people and should not be allowed to become their master.
('62', 84, 2, 8, 158915) That the village industries in Germany are being revived at the point of the sword is not relevant here.
('62', 84, 2, 9, 159020) What is relevant is that a country, which has shown the highest techincal skill and is amongst the most advanced in the matter of industrialization, is trying to go back to village industries for solving the problem of her terrible un employment.

('62', 89, 1, 2, 167052) 109. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI 1
('62', 89, 2, 3, 167089) WARDHA, October 28, 1933 CHI.
('62', 89, 2, 4, 167119) MATHURADAS, I have your letter.
('62', 89, 2, 5, 167151) There is no question at all of asking forgiveness of Thakkar Bapa.
('62', 89, 2, 6, 167218) But be sure that there was no contempt in Thakkar Bapa’s language.
('62', 89, 2, 7, 167285) His language is not polite.
('62', 89, 2, 8, 167313) But I see him as the very embodiment of kindness.
('62', 89, 2, 9, 167363) My close association with him fills me with joy.
('62', 89, 2, 10, 167412) His love is boundless.
('62', 89, 2, 11, 167435) I can see it not in his letters but in his work.
('62', 89, 2, 12, 167484) I have come to believe that no one is lowly in his eyes.
('62', 89, 2, 13, 167541) How can I convince you of it?
('62', 89, 2, 14, 167571) You should come here and carry back a little comfort.
('62', 89, 2, 15, 167625) Why should your mind be in turmoil?
('62', 89, 2, 16, 167661) What wrong have you committed?
('62', 89, 2, 17, 167692) What does it matter what others think of you?
('62', 89, 2, 18, 167738) Why should it disturb you?
('62', 89, 2, 19, 167765) What is it that troubles you?
('62', 89, 2, 20, 167795) I can never believe that Thakkar Bapa’s letter could have distressed you so much.
('62', 89, 2, 21, 167877) Nobody has complained against your nature to make me consider you worthless.
('62', 89, 2, 22, 167954) And could you ever be worthy or unworthy in my eyes merely because someone says so?
('62', 89, 2, 23, 168038) Do I have to know you through others?
('62', 89, 2, 24, 168076) You must shake off your anguish.
('62', 89, 2, 25, 168109) Come here and lighten your heart.
('62', 89, 2, 26, 168143) Your misery makes me unhappy.
('62', 89, 2, 27, 168173) I am enclosing two letters from Harakhchand.
('62', 89, 2, 28, 168218) Read them.
('62', 89, 2, 29, 168229) If you like my suggestion about appointing him agent, and only in that case, you should place before the Committee the separate letter 2 I am enclosing on the subject.

('62', 90, 0, 1, 168633) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 91
('62', 90, 1, 2, 168679) 110. A TEACHER’S DOUBTS
('62', 90, 2, 3, 168703) A teacher was somewhat puzzled while explaining to his students my writings under Mangal Prabhat 1 and he has asked certain ques tions regarding them.
('62', 90, 2, 4, 168854) Here is the first one : 2
('62', 90, 3, 5, 168880) My experience to date suggests that one’s good lies in following the path which appears right to oneself.
('62', 90, 3, 6, 168986) One has to discover for one self the path followed by great men, and find for oneself who are great men.
('62', 90, 3, 7, 169091) A great man who appears a paragon to one individual may seem worthless to another.
('62', 90, 3, 8, 169174) There have been cases in which two individuals both regarding the same person as an authority interpret his words and actions in two opposite ways.
('62', 90, 3, 9, 169322) The story of Virochana and Indra 3 is well known.
('62', 90, 3, 10, 169372) At every step ‘I’ comes to the forefront.
('62', 90, 3, 11, 169414) But the task is not accomplished even by my saying this.
('62', 90, 3, 12, 169471) It cannot be claimed that what occurs to us is always the truth.
('62', 90, 3, 13, 169536) What appears to me as truth today, may appear to be untruth after a couple of days.
('62', 90, 3, 14, 169620) What is regarded as truth by a few has often been denounced by many.
('62', 90, 3, 15, 169689) Hence we come to this terrible conclusion : Man can have a glimpse of truth only after making mistakes, stumbling on the way and tread ing dangerous paths.
('62', 90, 3, 16, 169845) However, all this perplexity arises from a disregard of the prere quisites for the quest of truth.
('62', 90, 3, 17, 169944) Entitlement and eligibility are as much essential in the case of truth as in any other.
('62', 90, 3, 18, 170032) The person who wishes to see Truth in the form of God must observe the yamaniyamas 4. Anyone who has not thus attained eligibility lacks the “insight”; he is as good as blind.
('62', 90, 3, 19, 170208) Anyone who claims to have seen truth without so much as trying to develop the eye for catching a glimpse of it would look as ludicrous as one who presumes to impart knowledge of astronomy without having studied it.
('62', 90, 4, 20, 170423) 1 A collection of Gandhiji’s articles on Ashram observances written from the Yeravda Central Prison; vide “ 1st Footnote Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 18/22 1930 2 The question, not translated here, was whether the better course was to follow the path of truth according to one’ own lights or to follow in the footsteps of great men.
('62', 90, 4, 21, 170755) 3 Chhandogyopanishad, VIII.
('62', 90, 5, 22, 170783) 4 Rules and regulations enjoined by Shastras for spiritual aspirants
('62', 91, 0, 1, 170852) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 92
('62', 91, 1, 2, 170893) The teacher’s second question is as follows: 1
('62', 91, 2, 3, 170940) In saying “We have come to the border line, etc.’, my only intention was to say that we could now have an easy access to the subject.
('62', 91, 2, 4, 171074) While discussing truth, we inevitably come to non violence.
('62', 91, 2, 5, 171134) That there can be no truth without non violence has been proved to be as plain as the fact that two and two make four.
('62', 91, 2, 6, 171253) The teacher’s third question is as follows: 2
('62', 91, 3, 7, 171299) The sentence quoted here is a good example of my inadequate expression.
('62', 91, 3, 8, 171371) I remember having some difficulty while drafting the article.
('62', 91, 3, 9, 171433) I could not find the words I was looking for.
('62', 91, 3, 10, 171479) However, if my condition is pitiable, the teacher’s is no less so.
('62', 91, 3, 11, 171546) We all go on chanting the word ‘non violence’ but little do we inquire into its true nature.
('62', 91, 3, 12, 171639) We do not act in accordance with what it has been described to be, hence the language used with reference to it seems like a Chinese puzzle.
('62', 91, 3, 13, 171780) The teacher has used expressions like ‘destroying’,‘facing’, ‘difficulties’, ‘suffering’,‘winning them over’, etc., but they have failed to reveal their full meaning to him.
('62', 91, 3, 14, 171954) His very language suggests it.
('62', 91, 3, 15, 171985) I do not regard this as his failing.
('62', 91, 3, 16, 172022) This imperfection is almost universal.
('62', 91, 3, 17, 172061) By saying all this, I have put before the reader my difficulty and our ignorance of the subject.
('62', 91, 3, 18, 172158) I believe I quite understand what I want to say, but I have not yet struck upon the language which would aptly convey my meaning.
('62', 91, 3, 19, 172288) But I shall not accept defeat.
('62', 91, 3, 20, 172319) Success is sure to come with repeated efforts Non violence does not destroy, it sustains.
('62', 91, 3, 21, 172409) Hence it meets ‘difficulties’ by overcoming them.
('62', 91, 3, 22, 172459) My yarn often gets entangled.
('62', 91, 3, 23, 172489) If I cut it off, so much yarn goes waste.
('62', 91, 3, 24, 172531) Cutting it off is easy and the process is over in no time.
('62', 91, 3, 25, 172590) But, it does not lead me to truth.
('62', 91, 3, 26, 172625) I ‘face’ the knot disentangling it, which is time consuming.
('62', 91, 3, 27, 172686) But it saves the yarn and I learn a lesson in patience.
('62', 91, 3, 28, 172742) When the knot is disentangled, my joy knows no bounds.
('62', 91, 3, 29, 172797) I clear the way for other spinners.
('62', 91, 3, 30, 172833) I add to my knowledge.
('62', 91, 3, 31, 172856) I find that the time spent was not wasted, and thus I learn that the apparently easy and quick method of cutting up the knot was
('62', 91, 4, 32, 172985) 1 It was: “In the concluding part of your article on ‘Truth’ you say, ‘We have come to the border line beyond which lies ahimsa.’ Do you mean that the former is a means to the latter ?” 2 It read: “What do you mean when you say that one makes progress by putting up with difficulties, not by counteracting them ?
('62', 91, 4, 33, 173298) What is your definition of non violence in the restricted sense ?”
('62', 92, 0, 1, 173365) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 93
('62', 92, 1, 2, 173411) not correct and therefore not quick either.
('62', 92, 1, 3, 173455) While disen tangling the knot, not only did I face the difficulty but by living with it after having accepted it as such, I also learnt that I was the author of it.
('62', 92, 1, 4, 173620) The responsibility for its coming into being rested with me.
('62', 92, 1, 5, 173681) I believe I have shown through the above example how many virtues are acquired by suffering in this manner.
('62', 92, 1, 6, 173789) I think other in stances too could be easily interpreted to yield the essence of my writings.
('62', 92, 1, 7, 173883) Examples will be readly available.
('62', 92, 1, 8, 173918) But this does not imply that all the problems of non violence are capable of being solved.
('62', 92, 1, 9, 174009) Or that somebody has all the keys.
('62', 92, 1, 10, 174044) This philosophy has not yet reached perfection.
('62', 92, 1, 11, 174092) Could any be said to have done so ?
('62', 92, 1, 12, 174128) The knowledge of the scientist seems to be no more than the growing realization of his own ignorance.
('62', 92, 1, 13, 174230) Non violence is an abstruse science.
('62', 92, 1, 14, 174267) We shall have to make many experiments, many people will have to sacrifice themselves.
('62', 92, 1, 15, 174354) All that can be said with certainty at present is that non violence appears to be the only straight and the shortest path to realization of God in the form of Truth.
('62', 92, 1, 16, 174520) For a long time we have been treading the path of violence, but we seem to be going farther away from truth.
('62', 92, 1, 17, 174629) The killing of lower animals, small insects and even plants in volves violence and is, therefore, sinful too.
('62', 92, 1, 18, 174739) Nothing that is embodied can continue to do so without committing sin.
('62', 92, 1, 19, 174810) From the worldly standpoint, however, the minimum inevitable violence committed for preserving the body is not regarded as sin.
('62', 92, 1, 20, 174938) We can now define violence in its narrow connotation.
('62', 92, 1, 21, 174992) The wilful, wanton or arbitrary destruction of any living organism even smaller than an insect, is violence; not wishing, committing or abetting it is non violence.
('62', 92, 2, 22, 175157) [From Gujarati]
('62', 92, 3, 23, 175173) Harijanbandhu, 29 10 1933

('62', 109, 9, 15, 207188) 126. INTERVIEW WITH DR.
('62', 109, 9, 16, 207212) CONGER 2
('62', 109, 10, 17, 207221) November 2, 1933
('62', 109, 11, 18, 207238) CONGER : Is the hand of God behind good only, or is it behind evil also ?
('62', 109, 12, 19, 207312) GANDHIJI : It is behind good, but in God’s hand it is not mere good.
('62', 109, 12, 20, 207381) His hand is behind evil also, but there it is no longer evil.
('62', 109, 13, 21, 207443) 1 In his letters dated October 27 and 28 Satis Chandra Das Gupta had described the inhuman treatment meted out to his brother Kshitish Chandra Das Gupta and other persons in Hijli Jail for their refusal to salaam the jail authorities.
('62', 109, 13, 22, 207678) 2 This is reported by Chandrashankar Shukla who was at the time working as Secretary to Gandhiji and had kept notes of the interview which was later reproduced in his book Conversations with Mahatma Gandhi
('62', 110, 0, 1, 207884) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 111
('62', 110, 1, 2, 207931) Good” and “evil” are our own imperfect language.
('62', 110, 1, 3, 207980) God is above both good and evil.
('62', 110, 2, 4, 208013) Q. There is God’s will behind every one of our action, is it not ?
('62', 110, 2, 5, 208080) A. Even allowing that there is His will behind every action, man can say that certain things God allows, wills or prohibits.
('62', 110, 2, 6, 208205) All this is taken to mean His “will”.
('62', 110, 3, 7, 208243) Q. You said there was God’s inspiration behind your twenty one days’ fast.
('62', 110, 4, 8, 208318) have also spoken of “wrestling”.
('62', 110, 4, 9, 208351) What exactly do you mean to convey ?
('62', 110, 4, 10, 208388) A. These are the babblings of an imperfect man.
('62', 110, 4, 11, 208436) Man’s wrestling with God is like that of an infant’s wrestling with the mother.
('62', 110, 4, 12, 208516) The infant does wrestle with the mother; and when the mother gives it a feed the infant says : “I wrested it from her.”
('62', 110, 5, 13, 208636) Here Gandhiji gave the dictionary meanings of the words “wrestle” and “wrest”.
('62', 110, 5, 14, 208715) Similarly God, when He parts with something, does so with plea sure, if God has pleasure and pain.
('62', 110, 5, 15, 208814) A man who surrenders everything at His feet says to Him : “I will die, if you don’t give me a certain thing.”.
('62', 110, 5, 16, 208925) He defies and challenges God.
('62', 110, 5, 17, 208955) In millions of examples God lets such men reach the point of death.
('62', 110, 5, 18, 209023) Then we say that He has thoroughly tested the man.
('62', 110, 5, 19, 209074) That, however, is our own feeling.
('62', 110, 5, 20, 209109) If man can somehow know God’s way of putting things, I don’t know what He would say.
('62', 110, 5, 21, 209194) We foolish beings think that we have exhausted our strength in wrestling with Him.
('62', 110, 5, 22, 209277) With God there is neither wrestling nor wresting.
('62', 110, 5, 23, 209327) If God is just, He would not torture His devotee.
('62', 110, 6, 24, 209377) Q. Is God just or not ?
('62', 110, 6, 25, 209401) A. God is just.
('62', 110, 6, 26, 209417) Rather, He is not jut but merciful.
('62', 110, 6, 27, 209453) He is just because He is merciful.These, however, are echoes of our own weak feeling.
('62', 110, 6, 28, 209539) Man also sometimes talks of giving God His due.
('62', 110, 6, 29, 209587) But what can a slave give to the Master ?
('62', 110, 6, 30, 209629) In relation to God man is always a debtor, and never a creditor.
('62', 110, 7, 31, 209694) Q. Is faith necessary or effort ?
('62', 110, 7, 32, 209728) A. Really both faith and effort are necessary.
('62', 110, 8, 33, 209775) Q. Has man got a choice ?
('62', 110, 8, 34, 209801) A. Man has got a choice, but as much of it as a passenger on board a ship has.
('62', 110, 8, 35, 209880) It is just enough for him.
('62', 110, 8, 36, 209907) If we don’t use it, then we are practically dead.
('62', 110, 9, 37, 209957) Q. God has a purpose which He is working out in the world, is it not ?
('62', 111, 0, 1, 210028) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 112
('62', 111, 1, 2, 210070) A. I qualify the statement by saying that this is human speech.
('62', 111, 1, 3, 210134) I don’t know God’s purpose, because I am not God.
('62', 111, 1, 4, 210184) I am a man.
('62', 111, 1, 5, 210196) I therefore try to comprehend God and His purpose not through speech but through life.
('62', 111, 1, 6, 210283) I cannot deal with the hundreds of thousands of beings in the universe as a unit.
('62', 111, 1, 7, 210365) I cannot enter into the heart of every one of them, because they are infinite in number.
('62', 111, 1, 8, 210454) But God is all powerful.
('62', 111, 1, 9, 210479) Just as He has a purpose for the universe as a unit, He has a purpose for every particle of life too—for man as well as the ant.
('62', 111, 2, 10, 210608) Q. Is it a good purpose ?
('62', 111, 2, 11, 210634) A. It is a good purpose—but “good” in the way of our limited human speech.
('62', 111, 2, 12, 210709) The Sino Indian Journal, Gandhi Memorial Number, December 1948.
('62', 111, 3, 13, 210773) 127. NOTES
('62', 111, 4, 14, 210784) DISTRESS IN ROHTAK, PUNJAB 1
('62', 111, 5, 15, 210813) This is a tale of distress that ought to move philanthropists to action.
('62', 111, 5, 16, 210886) Any contributions sent to the Editor, Harijan, 8 c, Pycroft’s Road, Triplicane, Madras, will be acknowledged and forwarded the proper quarters.
('62', 111, 6, 17, 211030) THE FORTHCOMING TOUR “How would the collections, made during the forthcoming tour, be distributed ?” is the question put by several workers.
('62', 111, 6, 18, 211171) They will be handed to the Central Board with instructions to use them as far as may be for the province or the district or the taluk or the town, in which they may be collected.
('62', 111, 6, 19, 211350) Whilst this will be the general rule, I do contemplate receiving in some places large single donations which will be utilized for the Harijan cause wherever the need is the greatest.
('62', 111, 6, 20, 211533) It must be obvious that any rigid rule restricting the use of collections to the places where they are collected will defeat the very end of workers or donors for fear of the collections not being used in their districts or in the best manner possible.
('62', 111, 6, 21, 211786) They should realize that the Central Board has an efficient system of account keeping, that accounts are audited
('62', 111, 7, 22, 211899) 1 This was appended to Amritlal V. Thakkar’s appeal for contributions to the fund started by the Harijan Sevak Sangh for rehabilitating Harijans of Rohtak District where 21,000 houses were detroyed due to heavy rains in September 1933; vide “Letter to Amritlal V. Thakkar”, 10 10 1933

('62', 112, 2, 3, 212268) HIS LOVE FOR HARIJANS 1
('62', 112, 3, 4, 212292) In the hasty tribute 2 I paid to the memory of Vithalbhai Patel, I omitted to mention the unforgettable scene I witnessed at the Harijan quarters in Godhra, which place I visited in 1917 3 for its political conference.
('62', 112, 3, 5, 212511) There was a Harijan conference, too, held at the time, and I had invited the audience to come to the Harijan quarters and hold the conference there, if they were sincere in their professions.
('62', 112, 3, 6, 212703) 4 Whom should I see there if not Vithalbhai Patel, who was then a member of the Legislative Council, dressed in the peasant garb with a Sadhu’s topi on his head ?
('62', 112, 3, 7, 212866) 5 He mixed with the Harijans with the greatest free dom and I know that he evinced the greatest interest in the Harijan cause.
('62', 112, 3, 8, 212993) With him the sweeper was as good as any other person, no matter what his caste might be.
('62', 112, 3, 9, 213082) He never concealed his opinion or practice in order to please the orthodox.
('62', 112, 3, 10, 213158) Let me hope that on the 9th instant, when the last rites are performed, Harijan tears will freely mingle with those of the multitude who will pay homage to the memory of the deceased patriot.
('62', 112, 3, 11, 213350) Harijan, 3 11 1933

('62', 113, 1, 2, 214540) has been feeding 3,500 persons from 25 villages and doling out 7 seers (1 1 2 seers of Cuttack is equal to 4 lb.) of rice per month
('62', 113, 2, 3, 214672) per head and one cotton sheet, and husk for cattle.
('62', 113, 2, 4, 214724) Thus the Society has distributed Rs. 5,000 among these.
('62', 113, 2, 5, 214780) At another centre, the Society has been giving relief to 5,700 people from 27 villages; each person gets here 26 tolas of rice.
('62', 113, 2, 6, 214908) There is a big rush even for this little dole.
('62', 113, 2, 7, 214955) There are two central depots in Cuttack and two in Puri.
('62', 113, 2, 8, 215012) Nearly Rs. 15,000 have been spent there.
('62', 113, 2, 9, 215053) From Khandayta we went to Khadarda.
('62', 113, 2, 10, 215089) Half the number of houses belonging to Harijans have been razed to the ground.
('62', 113, 2, 11, 215168) Those that remained have become dilapidated.
('62', 113, 2, 12, 215213) There we saw a woman only half clad and in perfect destitution.
('62', 113, 2, 13, 215277) She com plained of want of work.
('62', 113, 2, 14, 215310) In a house nearby, we saw a sister lying on the damp floor and suffering from high fever.
('62', 113, 2, 15, 215400) These people will need clothes against the approaching cold weather.
('62', 113, 2, 16, 215469) From Khadarda we went to Jharpada.
('62', 113, 2, 17, 215504) There we saw eight volunteers working under most difficult circumstances.
('62', 113, 2, 18, 215578) They distributed medical relief among ailing people and they had rigged up a king of accommodation for admitting very bad cases.
('62', 113, 2, 19, 215707) You can imagine what sort of nursing these poor patients can get.

('62', 113, 2, 21, 215784) of rice (costing six pice) per week are issued to adults.
('62', 113, 2, 22, 215842) Half the rations are doled out to minors.

('62', 115, 1, 2, 219510) 129. TWO CRUEL CASES
('62', 115, 2, 3, 219531) The record of steady progress reported from week to week in these pages is perhaps more than balanced by the revelations of inhu manity towards Harijans that come to light from time to time.
('62', 115, 2, 4, 219722) At a village called Samarkha in the district of Kheda, Gujarat, the caste villagers are reported to have burnt the crops of Christian Harijans because one or more of them had the courage to draw water from a public well.
('62', 115, 2, 5, 219943) The case is now said to be pending before the Courts.
('62', 115, 2, 6, 219997) In the village of Dholka, in Ahmedabad District, caste men are reported to have horsewhipped some Harijans, two of them seriously because one of them had the temerity to bathe in a public tank.
('62', 115, 2, 7, 220191) These are not the only cases of their kind.
('62', 115, 2, 8, 220235) They are serious enough to have seen the light of day.
('62', 115, 2, 9, 220290) We have no knowledge of the many petty assaults committed upon innocent Harijans for the exer cise of human rights recognized by law.
('62', 115, 2, 10, 220424) These cases should open the eyes of sanatanists.
('62', 115, 2, 11, 220473) I have not known a single sanatanist defend such inhumanity.
('62', 115, 2, 12, 220534) Let them either co operate with the the reformers or act separately, but effectively, in preventing or dealing with such occurrences.
('62', 115, 2, 13, 220668) The duty before workers is clear.
('62', 115, 2, 14, 220702) They may not hesitate to take such cases to court, when it becomes necessary.
('62', 115, 2, 15, 220780) But, before so doing, they should make every attempt to bring the wrongdoers to a sense of the wrong done and to induce the to make adequate reparation.
('62', 115, 2, 16, 220933) I imagine that this can be done, if, for instance in the case of Samarkha, well known men and women from Nadiad or even Ahmedabad, if necessary, went to the village and reasoned with the wrongdoers who have inherited the habit of thinkng that caste Hindus may deal with Harijans as if they were mere chattels and not human beings.
('62', 115, 2, 17, 221264) This dark ignorance of the elementary rights of human beings can be dispelled by the light of public opinion playing upon the darkness.
('62', 115, 2, 18, 221400) I hope no Hindu thinks that he need not concern himself in the case of Christian Harijans.
('62', 115, 2, 19, 221491) These have surely the same rights with Hindu Harijans to public activities that caste men have.
('62', 115, 2, 20, 221587) If the latter do not want to make use of public institutions, it is open to them at their own expense to erect others, for their exclusive use.
('62', 115, 2, 21, 221731) Sects and communities do build separate schools and hospitals for themselves out of funds they themselves subscribe.
('62', 115, 2, 22, 221848) No one takes exception to these.
('62', 115, 2, 23, 221881) But no one has the right to prevent anyone else from using what belongs to the general public.
('62', 115, 2, 24, 221976) And then, it should be remembered that Christian
('62', 116, 0, 1, 222025) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 117
('62', 116, 1, 2, 222072) Harijans are our own creation.
('62', 116, 1, 3, 222103) The evil of untouchability has spread in quarters wholly unexpected.
('62', 116, 1, 4, 222172) We may not wince if now we have to pay the penalty for having harboured the evil for untold generations.
('62', 116, 2, 5, 222277) Harijan, 3 11 1933
('62', 116, 3, 6, 222296) 130. NO NEED FOR A TANNERY ?
('62', 116, 4, 7, 222325) A correspondent has raised the following question :
('62', 116, 5, 8, 222377) I can understand the removal of the offices of the Provincial or Central Board of the Servants of Untouchables Society to the Ashram donated for Harijan use.
('62', 116, 5, 9, 222535) I can also understand the hostel scheme and the one for establishing a Harijan colony.
('62', 116, 5, 10, 222622) But a tannery does not fit in, and if a tannery should be there, why not also a department for teaching scavenging and sanitation; for, it is as much a Harijan work as tanning ?
('62', 116, 5, 11, 222800) The fallacy of the argument lies in misunderstanding the pur pose of the proposed tannery.
('62', 116, 5, 12, 222891) It is that tanning should be a great national industry.
('62', 116, 5, 13, 222947) The leather constitutes an immense business, and instead of exporting raw hide, we should keep it in India and manufacture the various things we need.
('62', 116, 5, 14, 223098) It must mean a great addition to the wealth of the country.
('62', 116, 5, 15, 223158) Now tens of thousands of Harijans are engaged in tanning.
('62', 116, 5, 16, 223216) It is an honourable profession and a lucrative business, and can be much more lucrative if it is well organized.
('62', 116, 5, 17, 223329) But the tanning done in the villages is of the crudest type.
('62', 116, 5, 18, 223390) Moreover, all the processes are not performed in a hygienic or scientific manner.
('62', 116, 5, 19, 223472) If they were performed in a scientific manner, there would be no prejudices against cattle skinning and tanning as they exist today.
('62', 116, 5, 20, 223605) The idea, therefore, behind having a technological department at the new institution is to give dignity to the occupation, purging it of all crudeness and uncleanness.
('62', 116, 5, 21, 223773) Then, again, it is not as if only Harijans will be doing the work.
('62', 116, 5, 22, 223840) They will be doing it side by side with non Harijans.
('62', 116, 5, 23, 223894) No one will be forced to learn it and no one can dare suggest that no Harijan tanner would want to learn the scientific or the cleaner method.
('62', 116, 5, 24, 224037) Lastly, the reference to the technological department is merely by way of illustration.
('62', 116, 5, 25, 224125) If all goes well, there will be many other departments opened including even one for exploring the best method of rendering sanitary service in which all can take part.
('62', 116, 5, 26, 224294) Our indifference towards it has resulted in the increase of diseases and in insanitary habits becoming confirmed.
('62', 116, 5, 27, 224408) I am hoping that there will be no trade or profession neglected which can be of benefit to the Harijans, whether it has been hitherto followed by them or not.
('62', 116, 5, 28, 224567) Harijan, 3 11 1933

('62', 120, 2, 4, 229967) WHAT IS INNER VOICE ?
('62', 120, 3, 5, 229989) What you say is logically correct.
('62', 120, 3, 6, 230024) But if one does not have a clear idea as to what the inner voice means, the principle cannot be followed in practice.
('62', 120, 3, 7, 230142) I believe that the inner voice is perfect knowledge or realization of the Truth.
('62', 120, 3, 8, 230223) And because we do not see perfect Truth, because the truth that we see is imperfect, we look upon the seers of the world as our guides and follow them.
('62', 120, 3, 9, 230375) Definite rules have been laid down to help us realize truth, and we can know Truth only by following them.
('62', 120, 3, 10, 230482) Hence, just as we cannot know geometry without studying it , so also it is not possible for anybody to hear the inner voice without the necessary effort and training.
('62', 120, 3, 11, 230649) Hence, accor ding to my definition, a murderer cannot cite the inner voice in defence of his act.

('62', 121, 1, 2, 231956) 136. A WORKER’S PROBLEM
('62', 121, 2, 3, 231980) A worker serving the Harijan has sent a double stringed necklace made of gold, rudraksha and coral along with Rs. 13 8 0 which he had received on the occasion of his maternal uncle’s shraddha.
('62', 121, 2, 4, 232173) In an accompanying note the gentleman says.
('62', 121, 3, 5, 232217) The short and the straight reply to this is that one should not in the first place act against one’s principles in order to please anybody.
('62', 121, 3, 6, 232357) Once it becomes clear to us that what we are being persuaded to do is against our principle, there should be no question of giving in to anyone’s importunity.
('62', 121, 3, 7, 232516) But I know this reply will not satisfy my correspondent.
('62', 121, 3, 8, 232573) There is only one root cause of all human failings and that is our lack of faith in God.
('62', 121, 3, 9, 232662) Chanting His name or visiting temples, etc., as a matter of convention is no sign of our faith in God, but rather a symptom of lethargy or mental weakness.
('62', 121, 3, 10, 232818) Faith in God ought to be a matter of the heart.
('62', 121, 3, 11, 232866) And one who has it should find no need to satisfy another.
('62', 121, 3, 12, 232925) He who has satisfied God has triumphed; and, he who has not known him may please thousands, but is lost for ever inasmuch as he has to deny himself in trying to please one person after another.
('62', 121, 3, 13, 233119) God is the soul within, because He pervades every single atom.
('62', 121, 3, 14, 233182) And this is not only a belief but an established fact.
('62', 121, 3, 15, 233237) Some know Him as Nature rather than by the name of God.
('62', 121, 3, 16, 233293) Some know Him as the great Power.
('62', 121, 3, 17, 233327) Even modern scientists concede that there is a power hidden in each atom which sustains the universe.
('62', 121, 3, 18, 233429) Anyone who acts in subservience to this great Power will never be wanting in strength.
('62', 121, 3, 19, 233516) His will power will grow day after day.
('62', 121, 3, 20, 233556) It is well known that those experienced in the ways of the world have shown the means by which this force can be demons trated.
('62', 121, 3, 21, 233684) This power cannot but become manifest in anyone who adopts them.
('62', 121, 3, 22, 233749) As the Harijanbandhu has already referred to them 2 they need not be repeated here.
('62', 121, 3, 23, 233833) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 5 11 1933
('62', 121, 4, 24, 233874) 1 The letter is not translate here.
('62', 121, 4, 25, 233910) The correspondent had asked how one could get over the weakness which obliged one to act contrary to one’s principles in order to please others.
('62', 121, 4, 26, 234055) 2 Vide “Some Moral Posers”
('62', 122, 0, 1, 234082) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 123
('62', 122, 1, 2, 234129) 137. KUTCH HARIJAN WORKER BELABOURED
('62', 122, 2, 3, 234166) Bhai Gokuldas Khimji of Mandvi, Kutch, is a well known social and Harijan worker.
('62', 122, 2, 4, 234248) Writing about him a gentleman says that when I had gone to Kutch I had compared him to the docile cow.
('62', 122, 2, 5, 234351) I remember that occasion.
('62', 122, 2, 6, 234377) Gokuldas is indeed humble.
('62', 122, 2, 7, 234404) He serves wherever he can.
('62', 122, 2, 8, 234431) he just would not hurt anyone.
('62', 122, 2, 9, 234462) He has written to Bhai Parikshitlal, Secretary, Gujarat Anti untouchability League, as follows : 1
('62', 122, 3, 10, 234561) In this case, victory lies with the person who has been beaten up and not with those who beat him up.
('62', 122, 3, 11, 234663) The beating up of such humble workers as Gokuldas will generate a spiritual energy which will melt the core of caste Hindus and release the Harijans from bondage.
('62', 122, 3, 12, 234826) The saner sanatanist Hindus of Kutch ought to make efforts to stop such rowdyism.
('62', 122, 3, 13, 234908) Even if untouchability were dharma, it can be protected by spiritual strength.
('62', 122, 3, 14, 234987) I do not know if it was ever safeguarded by brute force.
('62', 122, 4, 15, 235044) [From Gujarati]
('62', 122, 5, 16, 235060) Harijanbandhu, 5 11 1933

('62', 124, 4, 9, 237778) 141. LETTER TO N. S. HARDIKAR
('62', 124, 5, 10, 237808) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, WARDHA, November 5, 1933
('62', 124, 6, 11, 237852) DEAR DR.
('62', 124, 6, 12, 237861) HARDIKAR 2, I have read your long letter to Jamnalalji and had a long chat with Sharma.
('62', 124, 6, 13, 237949) I have gone into the figures and have shown him how the budget should be reduced.
('62', 124, 6, 14, 238031) I have no time to reiterate the reasons.
('62', 124, 6, 15, 238072) In my view at the present moment and for one year your wants should not exceed Rs. 5,000. From Jalbhai’s letter it appears that Rs. 4,000 can easily be found.
('62', 124, 6, 16, 238231) A loan is needed for the balance.
('62', 124, 6, 17, 238265) But I have advised a donation rather than a loan, and it may be Rs. 2,000. So, if Jalbhai has difficulty in finding Rs. 4,000 and if you regulate your expenditure according to my revision, you should have no difficulty for the current year.
('62', 124, 6, 18, 238506) Fresh effort will be necessary for the next year.
('62', 124, 6, 19, 238556) But I think that the workers should be told that they may not expect any guarantee regarding the maintenance money.
('62', 124, 6, 20, 238672) I have adopted this method for all the workers.
('62', 124, 6, 21, 238720) I would also warn you against raising loans.
('62', 124, 6, 22, 238765) That will kill the movement.
('62', 124, 6, 23, 238794) We should not feel helpless for want of funds.
('62', 124, 6, 24, 238841) I would also like you not to raise further funds in regard to the budget now provided for the year.
('62', 124, 6, 25, 238941) You will please show this to Jawaharlal and Jalbhai and get their approval, if you endorse my suggestions.
('62', 124, 6, 26, 239048) On their approval being secured, the money will at once be handed over.
('62', 124, 6, 27, 239120) My personal opinion on the insurance policies is that they should be allowed to lapse.
('62', 124, 6, 28, 239207) In any case, we may not be responsible for them, unless we deliberately adopt the policy of taking out and providing for the policies of all workers.
('62', 124, 7, 29, 239357) 1 Morarji Desai 2 N. S. Hardikar, founder and Secretary General of the Hindustani Seva Dal

('62', 129, 0, 1, 245858) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 130
('62', 129, 1, 2, 245900) 147. SPEECH TO HARIJANS 1
('62', 129, 2, 3, 245926) NALWADI, [Before November 7, 1933] 2
('62', 129, 3, 4, 245963) Vinoba has come here to serve you.
('62', 129, 3, 5, 245998) The Ashram programme is followed here regularly.
('62', 129, 3, 6, 246047) I hope you will take full advantage of it.
('62', 129, 3, 7, 246090) Shethji reminded me just now that no one was prepared to remove the carcass of a bullock, and so the Ashram inmates carried it and buried it.
('62', 129, 3, 8, 246232) The Harijan friends were displeased by this, for they think that others should not do the work allotted to the lowest even among the untouchables.
('62', 129, 3, 9, 246379) Vinoba has made a thorough study of the scriptures.
('62', 129, 3, 10, 246431) He says that nowhere has God enjoined that some are high and others low, some touchable and some untouchable.
('62', 129, 3, 11, 246541) He has been working among Harijans to wipe out these distinctions.
('62', 129, 3, 12, 246608) Dr. Ambedkar is pained and enraged by the oppression of Harijans by caste Hindus.
('62', 129, 3, 13, 246690) Why should he not feel angry at the oppression which caste Hindus have perpetrated on Harijans?
('62', 129, 3, 14, 246786) Why, then, do you make such distinctions of high and low among you?
('62', 129, 3, 15, 246854) If the position that only the Bhangis may remove night soil and dead animals is accepted, the work being done among Harijans will stop Brahmana,Kshatriya, Vaishya and Shudra were the four varnas and some others were regarded as belonging to the fifth varna, or as falling outside the varna system.
('62', 129, 3, 16, 247152) These varnas have not retained their original character.
('62', 129, 3, 17, 247209) What survives is the distinction of high and low.
('62', 129, 3, 18, 247259) God has not made anybody high or low.
('62', 129, 3, 19, 247297) If, living here, we serve you as your Bhangis, you should not be angry.
('62', 129, 3, 20, 247369) How can we serve Harijans ?
('62', 129, 3, 21, 247397) Should we serve the Mahars but not the Bhangis ?
('62', 129, 3, 22, 247446) Shoud we make distinctions among Harijans?
('62', 129, 3, 23, 247489) Hinduism will perish unless these distinctions are wiped out.
('62', 129, 3, 24, 247551) The majority of the population in India consists of Hindus.
('62', 129, 3, 25, 247611) If they perish, what would India be left with ?
('62', 129, 3, 26, 247659) It would of course be a different matter if all Hindus became Muslims or Christians.
('62', 129, 3, 27, 247744) If, however, we feel that Hinduism is good, we must save it from destruc tion.
('62', 129, 3, 28, 247823) It has produced innumerable saints and sages.
('62', 129, 3, 29, 247869) The Gita is one of the greatest scriptures, if not the greatest of all.
('62', 129, 3, 30, 247941) A religioon which has given such a treatise and which has produced great saints like Jnaneshwar, Tukaram and Samartha Ramdas is certainly not

('62', 130, 1, 2, 248290) destined to perish.
('62', 130, 1, 3, 248310) We must realize that it is meant to live for ever, that is is imperishable.
('62', 130, 1, 4, 248386) We must rid it of any imperfections or evil that may have crept into it.
('62', 130, 1, 5, 248459) The evil of untouchability that has entered it should be wiped out.

('62', 130, 4, 15, 249095) 148. ADVICE TO A HARIJAN WORKER 1
('62', 130, 5, 16, 249129) [Before November 7, 1933] From experience I have come to the conclusion that while praying we should not worry about unwanted thoughts and should not feel unhappy if they come.
('62', 130, 5, 17, 249306) If we try to keep them out, they invade us with greater force.
('62', 130, 5, 18, 249369) Fear haunts the frightened.
('62', 130, 5, 19, 249397) The same is true about unwanted thoughts.
('62', 130, 5, 20, 249439) To keep worrying why we get such thoughts, is like devoting oneself to them through enmity.
('62', 130, 5, 21, 249531) If we get unwanted thoughts, we should know that enemies have arrived, but we should not invite them.
('62', 130, 5, 22, 249633) Just as an uninvited guest offended and leaves if he is not welcomed, so also unwanted thoughts will go away if we do not bother about them.
('62', 130, 5, 23, 249774) But at the same time, as we do not neglect the invited guest just becaue some uninvited guest has intruded, so also we should not, just because of the invasion of unwanted thoughts, feel disheartened by them and stop the practice of prayer which we want to keep up.
('62', 130, 5, 24, 250040) The more these thoughts are ignored, the weaker will they grow and the prayer will engage attention more and more.
('62', 130, 5, 25, 250155) The argument that we should stop praying because of unwanted thoughts would be correct if we ourselves invited these thoughts.
('62', 130, 5, 26, 250282) It would be sheer pretence to sit down to pray and invite thoughts at the same time.
('62', 130, 5, 27, 250367) Our mind should non co operate with bad thoughts.
('62', 130, 5, 28, 250417) [From Gujarati]
('62', 130, 6, 29, 250433) Harijanbandhu, 12 11 1993

('62', 132, 7, 10, 252469) 152. SPEECH AT SELU
('62', 132, 8, 11, 252489) November 7, 1933 I believe it to be a happy augury that my tour commences with this sacred act.
('62', 132, 8, 12, 252585) 2 I do not know if I shall be able to go through the programme that has been chalked out for me for the coming nine months.
('62', 132, 8, 13, 252709) Whether it is got through or not, my faith tells me that an undertaking which begins under such good auspices must result in good.
('62', 132, 8, 14, 252840) The idol in the temple is not God.
('62', 132, 8, 15, 252875) But since God resides in every atom, He resides in an idol.
('62', 132, 8, 16, 252935) When rites of consecration are per formed, special sanctitiy is attributed to the idol, and those who believe in temples perform worship by visiting them.
('62', 132, 8, 17, 253090) I hold it a blasphemy to say that the Creator resides in a temple from which a particular class of His devotees sharing the faith in it are excluded.
('62', 132, 8, 18, 253240) Ramdeoji has, therefore, well said that this will be a true temple only from today, when it is declared open to Harijans.

('62', 132, 11, 21, 253418) November 7, 1933 It has been my firm belief for the last 50 years that there is no place in Hinduism for untouchability as we are observing it today.
('62', 132, 11, 22, 253568) I have studied to the best of my ability all the religions of the world,

('62', 133, 1, 2, 253776) and it has led me to the same conclusion.
('62', 133, 1, 3, 253818) I should consider the sacri fice of my life as none too great for the sacred cause of the removal of this curse of untouchability.
('62', 133, 1, 4, 253949) I have not a shadow of a doubt that, if untouchability is not removed root and branch, Hinduism is bound to perish, for no religion can nurture itself on the degradation of its votaries.

('62', 134, 3, 4, 256026) 156. ADVICE TO HARIJANS
('62', 134, 4, 5, 256050) NAGPUR, November 8, 1933 Of course, I have told caste Hindus that they are responsible for whatever evil habits are to be noticed among the Harijans.
('62', 134, 4, 6, 256200) But this does not mean that you should hug your evil habits.
('62', 134, 4, 7, 256261) Harijans should contribute to this movement by cultivating cleanliness, both of mind and body, giving up carrion eating which is looked upon with abhor rence by the whole of humanity, giving up drink, as also the differ ences of high and low that they are observing among themselves.
('62', 134, 4, 8, 256545) When they go to temples, they should observe the rules applicable to all temple goers.
('62', 134, 5, 9, 256632) Harijan, 17 11 1933
('62', 134, 6, 10, 256652) 157. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, NAGPUR 1
('62', 134, 7, 11, 256692) November 8, 1933 I am deeply grateful to you for the manifestation of this great affection.
('62', 134, 7, 12, 256784) Thanks be to God that you have assembled in such numbers to listen to my message.
('62', 134, 7, 13, 256866) The Chairman 2 is right when he says that this Harijan work is essentially religious from my standpoint.
('62', 134, 7, 14, 256971) That it has many other results is equally true.
('62', 134, 7, 15, 257019) There never has been a single truly religious activity but has had its influence on many departments of life.
('62', 134, 7, 16, 257129) That perhaps is one of the tests by which we recognize a great religious movement.
('62', 134, 7, 17, 257212) I would like to say in all humility, but with perfect confidence, that I have taken up this movement in no spirit of antagonism to any other religion or community.
('62', 134, 7, 18, 257376) It would be im possible for any person to point to a single act of mine during the past 50 years which could be proved to have been antagonistic to any person or community.
('62', 134, 7, 19, 257549) I have never believed anyone to be my enemy.
('62', 134, 8, 20, 257594) 1 Gandhiji spoke in Hindi.
('62', 134, 8, 21, 257621) 2 Dr. N. B. Khare.
('62', 135, 0, 1, 257640) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 136
('62', 135, 1, 2, 257682) My faith demands that I should consider no one as such.
('62', 135, 1, 3, 257738) I may not wish all to anything that lives.
('62', 135, 1, 4, 257781) It is my certain conviction that, if the Hindu heart is completely purged of the taint of untouchability, the event will have its inevitable influence not only upon all the communities in India but on the whole world.
('62', 135, 1, 5, 257999) This belief is daily becoming stronger.
('62', 135, 1, 6, 258039) I cannot remove from any heart untouchability regarding several millions of human beings and harbour it towards some other millions.
('62', 135, 1, 7, 258172) The very act of the Hindu heart getting rid of distinctions of high and low must cure us of mutual jealousies and distrust of and among other communities.
('62', 135, 1, 8, 258327) It is for that reason that I have staked my life on this issue.
('62', 135, 1, 9, 258391) In fighting this battle against untou chability.
('62', 135, 1, 10, 258440) I am fighting for unity not only between Hindu touchables and Hindu untouchables but among Hindus, Muslims, Christians and all other different religious communities.
('62', 135, 1, 11, 258606) Do not for one moment believe that I am interested in the numerical strength of Hindus.
('62', 135, 1, 12, 258694) I have never throughout my life laid stress upon quantity.
('62', 135, 1, 13, 258753) I have ever insisted upon quality at the sacrifice of quantity.
('62', 135, 1, 14, 258817) If I collected a million false coins they would be a worthless burden to me.
('62', 135, 1, 15, 258894) One true coin would be its value.
('62', 135, 1, 16, 258928) A religion cannot be sustained by the number of its lipfollowers denying in their lives its tenets.
('62', 135, 1, 17, 259028) This great Hindu religion itself will perish, in spite of its so called millions of followers, if its votaries persist in harbouring the evil of untouchability.
('62', 135, 1, 18, 259189) Not because untouchables can be counted by the millions.
('62', 135, 1, 19, 259246) If would perish even if they were a handful.
('62', 135, 1, 20, 259291) Milk is poisoned and has to thrown away whether you put a little or much arsenic in it.
('62', 135, 1, 21, 259379) If we believe that we are all children of one and the same God and that God is Truth and Justice, how can there be untouchability amongst us, His children ?
('62', 135, 1, 22, 259536) God of Truth and Justice can never create distinctions of high and low among His own children.
('62', 135, 1, 23, 259631) I, therefore, invite all without distinction of race and religion to assist this movement by praying for its complete success, so that we may all live in peace and friendship.
('62', 135, 1, 24, 259807) And if I want concord amongst all the communities professing different faiths, I cannot desire discord between the so called sana tanists and reformers.
('62', 135, 1, 25, 259960) I can harbour no ill will against sanatanists.
('62', 135, 1, 26, 260007) I ask them to extend the same toleration to reformers that they would have the latter extend towards themselves.
('62', 135, 1, 27, 260120) If they tolerate the faith and practice of others, why will they not tolerate the faith and practice of the reformers ?
('62', 135, 1, 28, 260240) They may not help so long as they regard untouch ability as an integral part of Hinduism.
('62', 135, 1, 29, 260330) I and fellow reformers firmly
('62', 136, 0, 1, 260360) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 137
('62', 136, 1, 2, 260407) believe that untouchability is an evil; and if it is so and If the reformers will continue to exercise patience and gentleness, the heart of the sanatanists must melt.
('62', 136, 1, 3, 260575) There can be no room for compulsion or violence in this great movement.
('62', 136, 1, 4, 260647) I endeavour to place before the vast mass of Hindus the results of a belief derived from such prayerful study of the Hindu scriptures as has been possible for me, and from association with those who are learned in them and, what is more, from my practice based upon that belief.
('62', 136, 1, 5, 260926) Surely, that cannot promote internal dissensions.
('62', 136, 1, 6, 260976) I observe that many who oppose this movement have not taken the trouble to understand its implications.
('62', 136, 1, 7, 261080) The object of this tour is to place the position of the reformers clearly before the public.
('62', 136, 1, 8, 261173) And I am hoping that, as the scope of the activities of the Servants of Untouchables Society becomes known, the opposition to it will melt away.
('62', 136, 1, 9, 261318) We want to change the hearts of those who today oppose the movement.
('62', 136, 1, 10, 261387) We want to remove their distrust.
('62', 136, 1, 11, 261421) We do not desire to compel them to act against their belief.
('62', 136, 1, 12, 261482) We want to win them over to the reform by gentlest persuasion, by appealing to their reason and to their hearts.
('62', 136, 1, 13, 261595) Love can never express itself by imposing sufferings on others.
('62', 136, 1, 14, 261659) It can only express itself by self suffering, by self purfication.
('62', 136, 1, 15, 261726) I am convinced that, if the reformers will show in their own lives an increasing purity, self denial, and capacity for suffering, they will be sure to melt the hearts of those who are today saturated with untouchability, believing it to be a desirable part of Hinduism.
('62', 136, 2, 16, 261996) Is is said that untouchables are so because of the evil in them.
('62', 136, 2, 17, 262061) But are the ‘touchables’ better ?
('62', 136, 2, 18, 262095) Are they sinless ?
('62', 136, 2, 19, 262114) Indeed, defenders of untouchability claim that some people are always untouchables and that no amount of pure conduct can pure them of the taint with which they are born.
('62', 136, 2, 20, 262285) They must remain social lepers for ever.
('62', 136, 2, 21, 262326) The fact is that whatever weakness we may notice about untouchables are a reflection of our own weaknesses and sins.
('62', 136, 2, 22, 262443) They are a direct result of the ill treatment that we have heaped upon their devoted heads.
('62', 136, 2, 23, 262535) Their real rise, therefore, depends upon te removing of untouchability root and branch and upon showing a growing purity in our own lives.
('62', 136, 2, 24, 262674) Thus the movement is dependent, not so much upon pecuniary help, as upon correct conduct.
('62', 136, 2, 25, 262764) Pecuniary help is to be an earnest of our deter mination to rid ourselves of the evil and to achieve self purification.
('62', 136, 2, 26, 262884) The question is repeatedly asked whether the reform includes
('62', 137, 0, 1, 262945) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 138
('62', 137, 1, 2, 262987) inter dining.
('62', 137, 1, 3, 263001) Though I have answered this question repeatedly, I must continue to repeat the answer as long as the question continues to be asked.
('62', 137, 1, 4, 263134) Everybody knows what my personal views are.
('62', 137, 1, 5, 263178) Since my youth upward I have consistently dined with all so long as the rules of cleanliness have been observed.
('62', 137, 1, 6, 263291) But that has nothing to do with the present movement.
('62', 137, 1, 7, 263345) Interdining and the rest is a question for each individual to determine for himself.
('62', 137, 1, 8, 263430) The movement organized by the Servants of Untouchables Society stands for simple removal of untouchability in every shape and form, in so far as it is special to the so called untouchables.
('62', 137, 1, 9, 263620) They would have the same public rights and facilities as are enjoyed by every other Hindu, that is to say, they should have access to all public institutions, such as wells, schools, roads, temples, etc.
('62', 137, 1, 10, 263824) One word as to the objections raised against Anti untouchability Bill.
('62', 137, 1, 11, 263895) Sanatanists have contended that they constitute State Interference in matters of religion.
('62', 137, 1, 12, 263986) I suppose by interference is meant that which is undue.
('62', 137, 1, 13, 264042) For it is possible to quote instances where State interference has been sought and has been inevitable in matters of religion.
('62', 137, 1, 14, 264169) What is sought is freedom from external compulsion.
('62', 137, 1, 15, 264221) I am no more in favour of such compulsion in matters affecting religion, than sanatanists.
('62', 137, 1, 16, 264312) These Bills involve no such compulsion, no undue interference.
('62', 137, 1, 17, 264375) The interference sought is beneficial and unavoidable.
('62', 137, 1, 18, 264430) If the State compelled the opening of temples To Harijans, it would without doubt be undue interference, but it cannot be undue when the State is called upon to legalize the voluntary opening by a stated majority of templegoers or the trustees.
('62', 137, 1, 19, 264675) Not to do so would be compulsion.
('62', 137, 1, 20, 264709) The Temple entry Bill merely seeks to legalize the action of a majority.
('62', 137, 1, 21, 264782) The other Bill has been long overdue.
('62', 137, 1, 22, 264820) It does not abolish untouch ability altogether.
('62', 137, 1, 23, 264868) It seeks to rob it of secular consequences.
('62', 137, 1, 24, 264912) To clothe it with such consequences is to constitute an intolerable interference with the free exercise of religion.
('62', 137, 1, 25, 265029) Nobody will deny that to make a religious obligation an obligation in law would be a gross and undue interference by the State.
('62', 137, 1, 26, 265157) The observance of untouc hability requires the voluntary recognition of it by both touchables and untouchables.
('62', 137, 1, 27, 265269) For the State to compel observance by untou chables would be a gross interference in matters of religion.
('62', 137, 1, 28, 265375) The Bill, therefore, seeks to remove the secular recognition of untouchability, without in any way inter 
('62', 138, 0, 1, 265481) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 139
('62', 138, 1, 2, 265528) fering with the religious observance of it or the religious conse quences of the breach of it.
('62', 138, 1, 3, 265623) If the objectors mean, therefore, what they say and on a careful study should find that the Bills involve no compulsion, they should waive their objection.
('62', 138, 2, 4, 265779) The poor man perhaps had nothing else to pay and he seems to have paid his all.
('62', 138, 2, 5, 265859) It is an unsoiled cowrie, as Malaviyaji would call it.
('62', 138, 2, 6, 265914) We attribute our earnings to fate, but what we give in the name of God, and for the service of His creatures bring us merit.
('62', 138, 2, 7, 266039) Looking at it as a symbol of sacrifce, it is more precious than gold.
('62', 138, 3, 8, 266109) Harijan, 17 11 1933

('62', 141, 7, 16, 271013) 161. INTERVIEW TO PRESS
('62', 141, 8, 17, 271037) November 9, 1933
('62', 141, 9, 18, 271054) Questioned whether he would issue a statement to the Press in connection with the all India anti untouchability tour, the Mahatma said that there was nothing to warrant a statement from him.
('62', 141, 9, 19, 271245) All that he wanted to say in that connection had been said by him in his address at the Nagpur public meeting the previous night.
('62', 141, 9, 20, 271375) He said he would be prepared to answer questions but warned them not to improvise questions.
('62', 141, 10, 21, 271468) Q. How many years do you think it will take for complete removal of untouchability at the present rate of progress ?
('62', 141, 10, 22, 271585) A. It is more than I can answer.
('62', 141, 10, 23, 271618) It is a question of a change of the hearts of millions of human beings.
('62', 141, 11, 24, 271690) Q. Will you be prepared to receive swaraj before this curse is removed ?
('62', 141, 11, 25, 271763) A. T he question is badly put.
('62', 141, 11, 26, 271794) There is no meaning in asking whether I shall be prepared to receive swaraj if untouchability is not removed by then.
('62', 141, 11, 27, 271912) Swaraj in not a matter of receiving or taking.
('62', 141, 11, 28, 271959) It is one of evolution .
('62', 141, 11, 29, 271984) We either grow to it from day to day or we go away from it.
('62', 141, 11, 30, 272044) If we, as a nation, are becoming more and more conscious of ourselves if the fundamental unity of millions, then we
('62', 141, 12, 31, 272160) 1 This paragraph is from Hitavada.
('62', 142, 0, 1, 272195) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 143
('62', 142, 1, 2, 272242) are certainly progressing towards it.
('62', 142, 1, 3, 272280) Whereas, if we are dissolving, then we are receding from it.
('62', 142, 2, 4, 272341) Q. Do you not realize that the depressed classes have even now got their own
('62', 142, 3, 5, 272418) superstitions and that they very much hesitate to associate with, for instance,
('62', 142, 4, 6, 272498) Brahmins, even if the are asked to do so ?
('62', 142, 4, 7, 272541) A. No, I do not; because, if what you say is true, it means that they want to remain in their present state of degradation.
('62', 142, 4, 8, 272665) I cannot understand a social leper glorying in his leprosy.
('62', 142, 4, 9, 272725) If the so called de pressed classes are so disgusted with the so called high class Hindus that they want absolutely to cut themselves adrift from Hinduism and Hindus, then they form a separate entity, which means they establish a new religion, or they accept any of the other prevailing religions of India.
('62', 142, 4, 10, 273032) That is a thing which can happen, if the so called higher classes continue to wallow in their imaginary superiority and do not perform the elementary duty of regarding the Harijans as their kith and kin.
('62', 142, 4, 11, 273236) This anti untouchability movement is an attempt to do this elementary duty by the Harijans.
('62', 142, 5, 12, 273328) Q. Harijans seem to be unwilling to mix with caste Hindus.
('62', 142, 5, 13, 273387) Is it not a fact ?
('62', 142, 5, 14, 273406) A. My experience is wholly different.
('62', 142, 5, 15, 273444) I have talked with thou sands of Harijans.
('62', 142, 5, 16, 273487) They are eager to associate with the higher classes, if the latter behave themselves.
('62', 142, 5, 17, 273573) What is true is that they distrust the higher classes, and where they do not distrust them, they are afraid of them.
('62', 142, 5, 18, 273690) And there is this unfortunate additonal fact the the notion of inferiority from birth has been so much injected into them that they consider themselves doomed by God to eternal inferiority.
('62', 142, 5, 19, 273880) This must be a matter of shame and humiliation for every thinking savarna Hindu.
('62', 142, 6, 20, 273961) The best way for the so called caste Hindus was to forget that they were higher
('62', 142, 7, 21, 274041) than anybody else.
('62', 142, 7, 22, 274060) It was all a reflection of what was today a fact among the higher
('62', 142, 8, 23, 274126) classes.
('62', 142, 8, 24, 274135) It ought to cause no surprise to higher classes when they discover that there
('62', 142, 9, 25, 274213) are differences in untouchability and therefore among untouchables.
('62', 142, 10, 26, 274281) Harijan, 1 12 1933, and Hitavada, 12 11 1933
('62', 142, 11, 27, 274326) 1 The following is from the Hitavada.

('62', 143, 1, 2, 274406) 162. SPEECH AT STUDENTS’ MEETING, NAGPUR
('62', 143, 2, 3, 274447) November 9, 1933 I know this tussle between English and Hindi is almost an eternal tussle.
('62', 143, 2, 4, 274538) 1 Whenever I have addressed student audiences, I have been sur prised by the demand for English.
('62', 143, 2, 5, 274635) You know, or ought to know, that I am a lover of the English language.
('62', 143, 2, 6, 274706) But I do believe that the students of India, who are expected to throw in their lot with the teeming millions and to serve them, will be better qualified if they pay more attention to Hindi than to English.
('62', 143, 2, 7, 274913) I do not say that you should not learn English; learn it by all means.
('62', 143, 2, 8, 274984) But, so far as I can see, it cannot be the language of the millions of Indian homes.
('62', 143, 2, 9, 275069) It will be confined to thousands or tens of thousands, but it will not reach the millions.
('62', 143, 2, 10, 275160) Therefore, I am delighted when the students ask me to speak in Hindi.
('62', 143, 2, 11, 275230) You, both the speakers, have spoken of me in terms, which if I believed to be true of myself, I do not know where I would be.
('62', 143, 2, 12, 275356) But I know my place.
('62', 143, 2, 13, 275377) I am a humble servant of India, and in trying to serve India, I serve humanity at large.
('62', 143, 2, 14, 275466) I discovered in my early days that the service of India is not inconsistent with the service of humanity.
('62', 143, 2, 15, 275572) As I grew older in years, and I hope also in wisdom, I saw that the discovery was well made, and after nearly 50 years of public life, I am able to say today that my faith in the doctrine, that the service of one’s nation is not inconsistent with the service of the world, has grown.
('62', 143, 2, 16, 275856) It is a good doctrine.
('62', 143, 2, 17, 275879) Its acceptance alone will ease the situation in the world and stop the mutual jealousies between nations inhabiting this globe of ours.
('62', 143, 2, 18, 276015) You have said truly that in taking up this war against untouchability, I have not confined myself to Hinduism.
('62', 143, 2, 19, 276126) I have said more than once that, if untouchability is removed in its fulness from the Hindu heart, it will have farreaching consequences, in as much as it touches millions of human beings.
('62', 143, 2, 20, 276315) As I said last night to the great meeting in Nagpur, if untouchability is really removed from the Hindu heart, that is, if the high caste Hindus purge themselves of this terrible taint, we shall soon discover that we are all one and not different peoples, Hindus, Muslims, Christians, Parsis, whatever we may call our selves.

('62', 146, 6, 18, 282443) 164. NOTES
('62', 146, 7, 19, 282454) TRUE AHIMSA Jamshed Mehta, a true servant of humanity, sends me a rendering, received by him from a friend, of a discourse on ahimsa in Jnaneshwari Gita 4. Chapter XIII.
('62', 146, 7, 20, 282624) I have taken the liberty of further condensing it and putting it in a form perhaps more easily to be understood, without in any way marring the sense of the original.
('62', 146, 7, 21, 282791) Those who still harbour untouchability in their bosoms will do well to
('62', 146, 8, 22, 282862) 1 These are reproduced from Chandrashankar Shukla’s “Weekly Letter” which says the speeches were delivered before Gandhiji visited Gondia, which he did on November 10. 2 Ibid
('62', 146, 9, 23, 283037) 3 What follows was spoken at a wayside meeting of villagers who made an on the spot collection.
('62', 146, 9, 24, 283133) 4 Jnaneshwar’s Marathi commentaryon the Bhagavad Gita.
('62', 147, 0, 1, 283188) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 147, 1, 2, 283230) test it on the touchstone provided by the great saint of Maharashtra.
('62', 147, 1, 3, 283300) Is untouchability compatible with his definition of ahimsa ?
('62', 147, 1, 4, 283361) Let the extract speak for itself : Before considering what is real ahimsa, it is necessary to see what it is not.
('62', 147, 1, 5, 283475) In order to secure a good rainfall, people perform what they call sacrifices in which they kill animals.
('62', 147, 1, 6, 283580) This is not ahimsa.
('62', 147, 1, 7, 283600) Is it not like cutting off one’s own hands so that they may be cooked and served as food ?
('62', 147, 1, 8, 283691) Is it wise to cut off all the branches of a tree, in order to put a fence round it, with those branches?
('62', 147, 1, 9, 283796) Then, again, to save many people from diseases, people cut away whole trees, or take out all the bark, or make extracts of living animals and take out secretions from other creatures.
('62', 147, 1, 10, 283980) Is it not like pulling down a house in order to build a verandah or shed for the house, and burning your clothes in order to have a fire to warm yourself ?
('62', 147, 1, 11, 284136) Real ahimsa or love originates in one’s heart and is known by one’s conduct even as gold is known by its qualities.
('62', 147, 1, 12, 284252) A man who is full of love never forgets that the world is full of life like his and takes great care that he does not harm any living thing.
('62', 147, 1, 13, 284393) He sees his love reflected in the eyes of those whom he meets.
('62', 147, 1, 14, 284456) He is the friend of all.
('62', 147, 1, 15, 284481) As a cat holds her kittens between her teeth without hurting them, so does a man of love deal with all with whom he comes in contact.
('62', 147, 1, 16, 284615) He walks gently and noiselessly lest his footsteps may disturb the sleep of others.
('62', 147, 1, 17, 284699) He always makes room for those who need it.
('62', 147, 1, 18, 284743) He so regulates his voice as not to jar on others.
('62', 147, 1, 19, 284794) He is silent when he need not speak.
('62', 147, 1, 20, 284831) His speech is never intended to offend anyone.
('62', 147, 1, 21, 284878) He does not want to up set other people’s plans or to frighten them.
('62', 147, 1, 22, 284947) He never utters words which lead to discussions and disputations, or which hurt the feelings of others.
('62', 147, 1, 23, 285051) There is no deceit in his talk, nor doubt not ambiguity.
('62', 147, 1, 24, 285108) He never stares lest his stare may offend people.
('62', 147, 1, 25, 285158) He does not move his hands aimlessly as he has no desire to harm even a mosquito.
('62', 147, 1, 26, 285240) He does not carry even a stick, not to speak of other weapons.
('62', 147, 1, 27, 285303) His hands are used only for salutation or service.
('62', 147, 1, 28, 285354) These are but the outward signs of the inner abiding love as a plant is of the seed that has borne it.
('62', 147, 1, 29, 285457) His mind is the Master of all the organs.
('62', 147, 1, 30, 285499) Thus, real ahimsa is an attitude of the mind expressed through the different sense organs.
('62', 147, 1, 31, 285590) He alone who is
('62', 148, 0, 1, 285606) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 149
('62', 148, 1, 2, 285653) filled with love for all that lives and whose mind, speech and action are in full union is truly noble.
