('62', 148, 2, 4, 285777) 165. A COMMON PLATFORM
('62', 148, 3, 5, 285800) A correspondent sends me an essay by Sir C. V. Kumaraswamy Sastriar, ex High Court Judge, Madras.
('62', 148, 3, 6, 285898) It occupies three sides of a foolscap in print.
('62', 148, 3, 7, 285946) It is written on behalf of ‘Sanatanists’.
('62', 148, 3, 8, 285988) It is an attempt to show that untouchability has existed from time immemorial and that the legislation such as is contemplated is futile.
('62', 148, 3, 9, 286126) It, however, concludes with this significant paragraph :
('62', 148, 4, 10, 286183) Several social inequalities and exclusive outlooks are being softened or removed by time and education.
('62', 148, 4, 11, 286287) The old order is changing, and with it the older conception of humanity.
('62', 148, 4, 12, 286360) Several communities once considered depressed or servile have, owing to rise in education and material well being, become possessed of rights and privileges.
('62', 148, 4, 13, 286518) No lover of India would claim that communties and castes should be in a state of antagonism, or that social injustice and inequalities should not be adjusted.
('62', 148, 4, 14, 286677) But nobody can view without pain and alarm the methods adopted and the aids sought, which will only accentuate the ill feeling between the caste Hindus and the depressed classes, without any considerable material advntage to the latter.
('62', 148, 4, 15, 286914) Their state of depression lies in other and deeper causes and its removal lies in combined effort by the caste Hindus to improve their material and educational state.
('62', 148, 4, 16, 287081) This paragraph, in my humble opinion, vitiates the prior rea soning in support of untouchability as a sacrosanct religious insti tuion, It seems to admit that it is a social evil which the learned ex Judge will gladly see uprooted.
('62', 148, 4, 17, 287313) And every reformer will agree with him when he says “nobody can view without pain and alarm the methods adpoted and the aids sought, which will only accentuate the ill feeling between the caste Hindus and the depressed classes, without any considerable material advantage to the latter.” Only, the reformer must add that Sir Kumaraswamy’s fears are imaginary.
('62', 148, 4, 18, 287673) Reformers have adopted no method and sought no aid so as to accentuate ill feeling.
('62', 148, 4, 19, 287757) Sir Kumaraswamy has not given himself time to study what the reformers are doing and how they are doing it.
('62', 148, 4, 20, 287865) Indeed, I can show him that they are even postponing the material advantage to the Harijans where ill feeling, already existing, is likely to grow into a fight with blows.
('62', 148, 4, 21, 288037) Thus, for instance, reformers have been postponing summary action even regarding the use of certain public wells to
('62', 149, 0, 1, 288153) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 149, 1, 2, 288195) which Harijans are beyond doubt entitled in law.
('62', 149, 1, 3, 288244) As for the aids sought, reformers will readily agree that social prejudices cannot be removed by summoning the assistance of law.
('62', 149, 1, 4, 288374) But they do invoke and insist on legal and legislative aid when the law is interpreted to uphold untouchability.
('62', 149, 1, 5, 288487) No reform in respect of an evil can succeed in the teeth of legal protection thereof.
('62', 149, 1, 6, 288573) It is hardly necessary to state the legislative obstacles can only be removed by legislative hindrance and nothing more.
('62', 149, 1, 7, 288694) What they desire is that untouchability should have no legal sanction.
('62', 149, 1, 8, 288765) They recognize that, even when that is withdrawn, as a social evil it will demand attention for a long time to come.
('62', 149, 1, 9, 288882) I welcome the last sentence of the paragraph.
('62', 149, 1, 10, 288928) When there is “a combined effort by the caste Hindus to improve their (the Harijans’) material and educational state”,untouchability will not be long indis appearing from the land.
('62', 149, 1, 11, 289109) If the sanatanists distrust the reformers, let them work independently.
('62', 149, 1, 12, 289181) Will Sir Kumaraswamy move the ‘sanata nists’ to action ?If he succeeds, there will be no ill feeling left.
('62', 149, 1, 13, 289288) Does he know that in the name of sanatana dharma its so called represen tatives have burned the crops of innocent Harijans, assaulted them and otherwise molested them when in the exercise of their just and legal rights ?
('62', 149, 2, 14, 289509) Harijan, 10 11 1933
('62', 149, 3, 15, 289529) 166. FOR HARIJAN TEACHERS
('62', 149, 4, 16, 289555) One who is responsible for the management of over twenty five Harijan schools writes a long letter stating the difficulties experienced in the management of the school and asks how I would conduct them if I had the direct management thereof.
('62', 149, 4, 17, 289797) I need not recount his difficulties which he has described carefully.
('62', 149, 4, 18, 289867) What I am about to say is an attempt to answer them.
('62', 149, 4, 19, 289920) While we are bound to give scholarships and other help to those Harijan boys and girls who attend the established schools, there is no reason whatever slavishly to reproduce the mode and methods of those schools in the ones under our own management.
('62', 149, 4, 20, 290170) We have to recognize that we get Harijan children with great difficulty to attend any school at all.
('62', 149, 4, 21, 290271) We cannot expect any degree of regularity in them and, thanks to our past criminal neglect, they are so unkempt that we have, in the beginning stages, to handle them in a manner wholly different from the ordinary.
('62', 150, 0, 1, 290485) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 151
('62', 150, 1, 2, 290532) On first adimission their bodies have to be minutely examined and thoroughly cleaned.
('62', 150, 1, 3, 290618) Their clothes might have to be cleaned and patched.
('62', 150, 1, 4, 290670) The first daily lesson, therefore, will for some time consist of applied hygiene and sanitation and simple needle work.
('62', 150, 1, 5, 290790) I should use no books probably for the whole of the first year.
('62', 150, 1, 6, 290854) I should talk to them about things with which they are familiar and, doing so, correct their pronunciation and grammar and teach them new words.
('62', 150, 1, 7, 290999) I should note all the new words they may learn from day to day so as to enable me to use them frequently till they have them fixed in the their minds regularly.
('62', 150, 1, 8, 291160) The teacher will not give discourses but adopt the conver sational method.
('62', 150, 1, 9, 291235) Through conversations he will give his pupils pro gressive instruction in history, geography and arithmetic.
('62', 150, 1, 10, 291344) History will begin with that of our own times, and then, too, of events and of persons nearest us, and geography will begin with that of the neigh bourhood of the school.
('62', 150, 1, 11, 291515) Arithmetic will begin with the sums appli cable of the pupil’s homes.
('62', 150, 1, 12, 291585) Having tried the method myself, I know that infinitely more knowledge can be given to the pupils through it, and without strain on them, than can be given through the orthodox method, within a given time.
('62', 150, 1, 13, 291790) Knowledge of the alphabet should be treated as a separate subject altogether.
('62', 150, 1, 14, 291868) The letters should be treated as pictures which the children will first be taught to recognize and name.
('62', 150, 1, 15, 291973) Writing will follow as part of the drawing lesson.
('62', 150, 1, 16, 292024) Instead of making daubs of their letters, pupils should be able to make perfect copies of the models placed before them.
('62', 150, 1, 17, 292145) They would not, therefore, be called upon to draw the letters till they had acquired control over their fingers and the pen.
('62', 150, 1, 18, 292270) It is criminal to stunt the mental growth of a child by letting him know as much only as he can get through a book he can incoherently read in a year.
('62', 150, 1, 19, 292421) We do not realize that, if a child was cut of from the home life and was merely doomed to the school, he would be a perfect dunce for several years.
('62', 150, 1, 20, 292570) He picks up information and language unconsciously through his home, not in the schoolroom.
('62', 150, 1, 21, 292662) Hence do we experience the immense difference between pupils belonging to cultured homes and those belonging to uncouth homes, which are no homes in reality.
('62', 150, 1, 22, 292820) In the scheme I have adumbrated, the schoolmaster is expected to treat his occupation seriously and feel one with his pupils.
('62', 150, 1, 23, 292946) I know that, in putting the scheme into operation, the want of schoolmasters of the right type is the greatest difficulty.
('62', 150, 1, 24, 293069) But we shall not get the right type till we have made the right beginning.
('62', 151, 0, 1, 293144) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 151, 1, 2, 293186) I must postpone the consideration of the stage when we have to arm the pupils with books.

('62', 155, 2, 3, 299169) November 11, 1933 2
('62', 155, 3, 4, 299189) I am essentially a lover of peace.
('62', 155, 3, 5, 299224) I do not have the slightest wish to create dissensions among the Hindus.
('62', 155, 3, 6, 299297) It would be best for the sana tanists and reformers to confer among themselves and make an effort to arrive at an understanding.
('62', 155, 3, 7, 299426) But if that effort fails, both parties should resort to peaceful and honourable methods and both should learn to tolerate one another.
('62', 155, 3, 8, 299561) I believe myself to be both a sanatanist and a reformer.
('62', 155, 3, 9, 299618) I have tried to gather in me all the goodwill which caste Hindus can have towards Harijans.
('62', 155, 3, 10, 299710) God alone knows how far I have succeded in the effort.
('62', 155, 3, 11, 299765) I am also trying, as best as an imperfect human being like myself can, to see with Harijans’ eyes and to realize what is going on in their hearts.
('62', 155, 3, 12, 299912) It is not given to man to know the whole truth.
('62', 155, 3, 13, 299960) His duty lies in living up to the truth as he sees it and, in doing so, to resort to the purest means, i.e, to non violence.
('62', 155, 3, 14, 300085) I do not want to hurt the feelings of the sanatanists.
('62', 155, 3, 15, 300140) I want to convert them to my view in the gentlest manner.
('62', 155, 3, 16, 300198) I want, if I can, to steal into their hearts.
('62', 155, 3, 17, 300244) I would love to melt their hearts by my suffering.
('62', 155, 3, 18, 300295) I firmly believe that untouchability as we practise it today has no sanction in the Shastras.
('62', 155, 3, 19, 300389) But I do not wish to enter into a discussion of what the Shastras support and what they do not.
('62', 155, 3, 20, 300485) I only put before you, as humbly as I can, the truth as I see it, and am prepared to sacrifice my life, if need be, in an unceasing effort to live up to that truth.
('62', 155, 3, 21, 300650) It is clear to my mind, beyond the shadow of a doubt, that, if untou chabi lity is not eradicated, both Hinduism and the Hindus are bound to perish.
('62', 155, 3, 22, 300799) Ever since I was a child of ten I have considered untoucha bility as a sin.
('62', 155, 3, 23, 300875) My heart has never been able to reconcile itself to untouchability based on birth.
('62', 155, 3, 24, 300958) I tried to study the Shastras to the best of my ability.
('62', 155, 3, 25, 301015) I consulted as many pundits as I could.
('62', 155, 3, 26, 301055) And a majority of them have supported my view.
('62', 155, 3, 27, 301102) But truth is not to be found in books.
('62', 155, 3, 28, 301141) Truth resides in every human heart, and one has to search for
('62', 155, 4, 29, 301203) 1 Gandhiji had gone to Deoli to open a temple to Harijans but some sanatanists opposed the plan.

('62', 157, 8, 13, 304144) RAMESHWARDAS, Ganga has certainly committed a grave lapse but she repents of it now.
('62', 157, 8, 14, 304229) One who repents deserves to be forgiven.
('62', 157, 8, 15, 304270) Do not say a word [of reproach] to Ganga; receive her with love.
('62', 157, 8, 16, 304335) The ornaments have to be brought back, that she will do.
('62', 157, 8, 17, 304392) You can send her back afterwards.
('62', 157, 8, 18, 304426) Remain calm, chant Ramanama.
('62', 157, 8, 19, 304455) We are all prone to errors but those who confess theirs are blessed.
('62', 157, 8, 20, 304524) Let us all wish that Ganga’s repentance proves sincere.

('62', 158, 1, 2, 304711) 177. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI
('62', 158, 2, 3, 304753) WARDHA, November 13, 1933
('62', 158, 3, 4, 304779) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, I cannot reply immediately to your letters.
('62', 158, 3, 5, 304844) I don’t have time even today, but have found some to write this letter as Kishorelal told me the substance of your letter to Nanabhai.
('62', 158, 3, 6, 304979) If I could, I would cer tainly have tried to guide you in regard to the dispute among you there.
('62', 158, 3, 7, 305076) 1 But I really cannot judge in such matters unless I see all the people concerned.
('62', 158, 3, 8, 305159) However, why do you always feel dependent on me ?
('62', 158, 3, 9, 305209) Go on doing fearlessly what you feel to be the right thing.
('62', 158, 3, 10, 305269) Don’t mind if you make mistakes.
('62', 158, 3, 11, 305302) Whenever you realize that you have made a mistake, rectify it unhesitatingly without thinking of the conse quences.
('62', 158, 3, 12, 305418) If you always act thus, you will be able to judge what the right course is in every matter.
('62', 158, 3, 13, 305510) I shall not live for ever.
('62', 158, 3, 14, 305537) You should try to swim with your own strength.
('62', 158, 3, 15, 305584) That is the right thing to do.
('62', 158, 3, 16, 305615) Don’t mind if you drown while trying to swim.
('62', 158, 3, 17, 305661) If you realize that you have made a mistake in adopting the course which you are following at present, you should abandon it.
('62', 158, 3, 18, 305787) If you don’t see any mistake, you must cling to it no matter even if you die or become a pauper in con sequence.
('62', 158, 3, 19, 305900) But, while doing that, do not get angry with anybody or adopt untruthful means or lose your peace of mind or patience.
('62', 158, 3, 20, 306019) Bear the hardships which may follow.
('62', 158, 3, 21, 306056) Instead of seeking the protection of an imperfect father, seek that of the Father of all, of Omnipotent God.
('62', 158, 3, 22, 306165) That will make you strong.
('62', 158, 3, 23, 306192) This is the only lesson I wish to teach you.
('62', 158, 3, 24, 306237) If you have learnt it, you may rest assured that you have received perfect education.
('62', 158, 3, 25, 306323) You will read accounts of my tour in papers and elsewhere.
('62', 158, 3, 26, 306382) I don’t have time to give you other news either.
('62', 158, 4, 27, 306431) Blessings from
('62', 158, 6, 28, 306446) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 4811
('62', 158, 7, 29, 306490) 1 Vide “Letter to Vallabhbhai Patel”, 25 12 1933.

('62', 159, 2, 3, 306614) WARDHA ASHRAM, November 13, 1933 Hindus are in grave error.
('62', 159, 2, 4, 306674) They have become cowards.
('62', 159, 2, 5, 306700) They are not prepared for sacrifice; they do not wish to purify temselves nor do they want to give up their bad habits.
('62', 159, 2, 6, 306820) What else can you expect ?
('62', 159, 2, 7, 306847) 1 In these circumstances, those of us who are awakened should do their duty by purifying themselves through sacrifice and have the faith that therein lies the ultimate solution of the problem.

('62', 160, 1, 2, 307869) 180. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('62', 160, 2, 3, 307901) Unrevised CHANDA, November 13, 1933
('62', 160, 3, 4, 307937) DEAR JAWAHARLAL, I have just arrived in Chanda and whilst the others are coming, I have taken up your letter.
('62', 160, 3, 5, 308047) It is now 9 p.m.
('62', 160, 3, 6, 308064) The programme is fairly strenuous.
('62', 160, 3, 7, 308099) I was in Hinganghat at 6 p.m.
('62', 160, 3, 8, 308129) Tiwari has handed me your letter.
('62', 160, 3, 9, 308163) I have also read yours to J 1. So far as he knows there is probably very little left in A.I.C.C. a/c.
('62', 160, 3, 10, 308265) The books are not with him.
('62', 160, 3, 11, 308293) He has sent for the accounts.
('62', 160, 3, 12, 308323) Meanwhile I have suggested that Rs. 500 might be sent at least on a/c.
('62', 160, 3, 13, 308394) If the funds are exhausted, I do not know what is to be done.
('62', 160, 3, 14, 308456) I have an earmarked a/c at my disposal.
('62', 160, 3, 15, 308496) I am loath to part with that fund.
('62', 160, 3, 16, 308531) I am drawing upon it for Hardikar and I want to do likewise for the list of workers you have sent me.
('62', 160, 3, 17, 308633) It too will be soon exhausted.
('62', 160, 3, 18, 308664) In the circumstances, the office staff has to be reduced if not given up altogether, i.e., if the civil resistance movement is to continue.
('62', 160, 3, 19, 308804) The more I look about me, the more convinced I feel that those who are in the fight will have to do without funds except such as may remain in hands such as mine.
('62', 160, 3, 20, 308967) I have just managed for Gujarat and Karnatak.
('62', 160, 3, 21, 309013) The lady who was to have paid Rs. 50,000 has just sent the message that she would like to pay Rs. 10,000 to you.
('62', 160, 3, 22, 309126) If she does, I shall expect you to pay the U.P. workers out of this.
('62', 160, 3, 23, 309195) Anyway I think it is best for you to confer with Jamnalalji and if necessary with me as to the management of the funds that are still available.
('62', 160, 3, 24, 309340) I have sent notices everywhere that no more help need be expected through me.
('62', 160, 3, 25, 309418) I am trying to run through what ever is at my disposal.
('62', 160, 3, 26, 309474) Now about the informal meeting.
('62', 160, 3, 27, 309506) You will see from the pro gramme herewith that I am in Delhi between 10 and 14 December.
('62', 160, 3, 28, 309595) Thakkar Bapa says I can take up the bulk of 14th for our meeting.
('62', 160, 3, 29, 309661) I am supposed to entrain for Andhra on 14th immediately after 4 p.m.
('62', 160, 3, 30, 309730) Ansari who was with me on Sunday suggested Delhi.
('62', 160, 3, 31, 309780) You will now make your choice—24th inst., 4th Dec.
('62', 160, 3, 32, 309831) or 14th Dec., i.e., if the conference is to come off at all.
('62', 160, 4, 33, 309892) 1 Jamnalal Bajaj who was the treasurer of the A.I.C.C. at this time.
('62', 161, 0, 1, 309961) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 161, 1, 2, 310003) As to the Harijan tour, I am not worrying at all over the pro posed boycott in U.P. I am finding no difficulty here.
('62', 161, 1, 3, 310120) Congressmen and non Congressmen are co operating in arranging for the tour.
('62', 161, 1, 4, 310196) You are unnecessarily hard on the liberals whom I would include among non Congressmen.
('62', 161, 1, 5, 310283) We have to get work even from them.
('62', 161, 1, 6, 310319) They work according to their lights.
('62', 161, 1, 7, 310356) In any case, I do not want a single Congressman to work for this movement who would go to jail.
('62', 161, 1, 8, 310452) I have said this to everyone who has come to me.
('62', 161, 1, 9, 310501) I am sending back some of the best workers who have just come out.
('62', 161, 1, 10, 310568) Ba I hope is going soon and so is Manibehn Patel.
('62', 161, 1, 11, 310618) Kakasaheb, Swami, Surendra are going.
('62', 161, 1, 12, 310656) Those Congressmen who are too weak to go or who have lost faith in civil disobedience and who are anxious to work for the Harijan cause I am taking, but not those who want Harijan work as a mere cloak.
('62', 161, 1, 13, 310858) This movement, if it is to become universal, must be able to continue even if every Congressman is in jail or it must perish.
('62', 161, 1, 14, 310984) I feel too that congressmen should not handle this movement to strengthen the C. D. movement or the Congress hold on the people.
('62', 161, 1, 15, 311113) It would be going about it the wrong way.
('62', 161, 1, 16, 311155) Such an attitude will damage both the Con gress and the Harijan cause.
('62', 161, 1, 17, 311226) Cases of this type have come under my notice.
('62', 161, 1, 18, 311272) I have expressed strong disapproval of any such work.
('62', 161, 1, 19, 311326) I think I have now sufficiently answered all your questions.
('62', 161, 1, 20, 311387) If not, please ask again.
('62', 161, 1, 21, 311413) You will have noticed that the Sarkar Salaam 1 in Hijli has stopped.
('62', 161, 1, 22, 311482) Shall I write to Sir Tej about the Frontier treatment ?
('62', 161, 1, 23, 311538) I had a nice letter from Krishna.
('62', 161, 1, 24, 311572) She seems to be happy in her new home.
('62', 161, 1, 25, 311611) I hope Mother’s progress continues.

('62', 164, 1, 2, 314886) 184. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL
('62', 164, 2, 3, 314919) CHANDA, November 14, 1933
('62', 164, 3, 4, 314945) BHAI VALLABHBHAI, I must have your letters regularly.
('62', 164, 3, 5, 314999) You have made me grow accustomed to them.
('62', 164, 3, 6, 315041) We are in Chanda today.
('62', 164, 3, 7, 315065) it is four o’clock just now.
('62', 164, 3, 8, 315094) At six we leave for Saoli.
('62', 164, 4, 9, 315121) I didn’t like the manner in which things were done regarding Vithalbhai.
('62', 164, 4, 10, 315194) All the same, I have learnt much from here, from the way in which people attended in large crowds.
('62', 164, 4, 11, 315293) They don’t worship the man.
('62', 164, 4, 12, 315321) They worship, in their own way and on their own terms, the image of the man which they have formed in their minds and which they love.
('62', 164, 4, 13, 315456) I have not read the accounts in papers and do not know details.
('62', 164, 4, 14, 315520) But I have got a complete picture in my mind of the whole thing.
('62', 164, 4, 15, 315585) I learnt from The Times [of India] about eggs having been thrown during the students’ meeting 1 in Nagpur.I didn’t see anything in the hall.
('62', 164, 4, 16, 315726) I didn’t even see any commotion anywhere.
('62', 164, 4, 17, 315768) Nor do I know anybody else in the hall having noticed anything.
('62', 164, 4, 18, 315832) Chandra shankar told me only this, that an egg had fallen on Om.
('62', 164, 4, 19, 315897) Nobody knows whether it was aimed at her or the ex president sitting by her side or at me.
('62', 164, 4, 20, 315988) The truth is that the paper has magnified the incident out of all proportion.
('62', 164, 4, 21, 316066) The students’ love was beyond words.
('62', 164, 4, 22, 316103) They even gave me a purse of Rs. 700. It is the same in the case of U.P. Ansari came and saw me on Sunday.
('62', 164, 4, 23, 316210) [His] health is a little better.
('62', 164, 4, 24, 316243) [He] wished to see Vithalbhai, but could not.
('62', 164, 4, 25, 316289) During the last days he had become very restless.
('62', 164, 4, 26, 316339) Ansari had nothing in particular to say.
('62', 164, 4, 27, 316380) He had come only to pay a formal visit.
('62', 164, 4, 28, 316420) He has gone to see some patients in princely families.
('62', 164, 4, 29, 316475) He left the same evening.
('62', 164, 4, 30, 316501) I w as observing silence then, though not when he arrived.
('62', 164, 4, 31, 316560) So far I have experienced no difficulty in the tour.
('62', 164, 4, 32, 316613) It is now time for my meal and then to get into a car.
('62', 164, 4, 33, 316668) So I must stop here today.
('62', 164, 4, 34, 316695) Ba and Swami left Wardha yesterday.
('62', 164, 4, 35, 316731) Ba will go to Ahmedabad via Akola.

('62', 165, 5, 7, 317016) 185. LETTER TO MANIBEHN PATEL
('62', 165, 6, 8, 317046) CHANDA, November 14, 1933
('62', 165, 7, 9, 317072) MANI, I got your long letter.
('62', 165, 7, 10, 317102) You did well to speak out your mind.
('62', 165, 7, 11, 317139) You would only harm yourself if you hide your thoughts from me.
('62', 165, 7, 12, 317203) After a man’s death, we must not remember his shortcomings, but should remember only his virtues.
('62', 165, 7, 13, 317301) My absence had nothing to do with his actions.
('62', 165, 7, 14, 317348) It is not that I fail to appreciate his virtues.
('62', 165, 7, 15, 317397) I did not go there because I could not have taken part in anything.
('62', 165, 7, 16, 317465) 2 I feel that at present I should be either in Yeravda or among Harijans.
('62', 165, 7, 17, 317539) When I say that I am out of prison only for the sake of Harijans, I do so not only for the benefit of the Government of the world but because that is how I relly feel in my heart.
('62', 165, 7, 18, 317719) I simply cannot take part in any other activity.
('62', 165, 7, 19, 317768) People also seem to have understood this.
('62', 165, 7, 20, 317810) I could not have tolerated the restrictions imposed by the Government and would not have been able to have things according to my own way.
('62', 165, 7, 21, 317949) I would not have been able to advise you or Dahyabhai.
('62', 165, 7, 22, 318004) And so I bore the attacks in silence.
('62', 165, 7, 23, 318042) Apart from this, there is another thing, too, in my life which you should know.
('62', 165, 7, 24, 318122) Rasik 3 was on his death bed and he even wished that I should be by his bedside.
('62', 165, 7, 25, 318203) But I did not go to Delhi, Ba did.
('62', 165, 7, 26, 318238) Rasik died.
('62', 165, 7, 27, 318250) I did not shed a single tear.
('62', 165, 7, 28, 318280) I was taking my meals when I received the wire.
('62', 165, 7, 29, 318328) I finished my meal and resumed my work.
('62', 165, 7, 30, 318368) There have been many such incidents in my life.
('62', 165, 7, 31, 318416) I have formed certain views about death and they are becoming stronger as the years pass.
('62', 165, 8, 32, 318506) 1 Rami Kunverji Parekh, daughter of Harilal Gandhi 2 The addressee had asked why Gandhiji did not attend Vithalbhai Patel’s funeral.
('62', 165, 8, 33, 318639) 3 Harilal Gandhi’s son who died on February 8, 1929; vide “Letter to Mirabehn”, 9 2 1929
('62', 166, 0, 1, 318728) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 167
('62', 166, 1, 2, 318775) not look upon death as a calamity.
('62', 166, 1, 3, 318810) Marriage may be that, death never is.
('62', 166, 1, 4, 318848) Does this set your doubt at rest ?
('62', 166, 1, 5, 318883) If not, ask me again.
('62', 166, 1, 6, 318905) You have given a good description of the events there.
('62', 166, 1, 7, 318960) It was very painful.
('62', 166, 1, 8, 318981) We should understand the meaning of people’s love.
('62', 166, 1, 9, 319032) That love is not of the individual but of the virtues which they want to see in, and, therefore, attribute to him.
('62', 166, 1, 10, 319147) Their love, therefore, is a pure thing.
('62', 166, 1, 11, 319187) It is a sign of the popular awakening and an eye opener for the world.
('62', 166, 1, 12, 319258) Nobody can doubt that Vithalbhai was a lover of freedom.
('62', 166, 1, 13, 319315) Now about Ba.
('62', 166, 1, 14, 319329) If I had had time, I would have explained the point more clearly in that letter.
('62', 166, 1, 15, 319410) 1 Ba’s mind has weakened.
('62', 166, 1, 16, 319436) She wants and yet does not want to court arrest.
('62', 166, 1, 17, 319485) Deep down in her heart she knows that it is her duty to do so, and cannot forsake that duty, but she does not like to go as I am out.
('62', 166, 1, 18, 319619) I have not put any pressure.
('62', 166, 1, 19, 319648) I have left her free to do as she wishes.
('62', 166, 1, 20, 319690) What I wanted to say was that you should urge her and strengthen her resolution to do her duty, for she believes in you and loves you.
('62', 166, 1, 21, 319825) Anything I might say is likely to be regarded as an order and might kill her individuality.

('62', 172, 2, 3, 328373) AMRAOTI, (AS AT WARDHA) November 16, 1933
('62', 172, 3, 4, 328415) MY DEAR AGATHA, I had your long letter.

('62', 172, 3, 10, 329089) Sir Samuel Hoare has made up his mind about everything.

('62', 172, 3, 14, 329318) The immediate needs of the Britishers blind him to the realities.

('62', 172, 3, 17, 329633) Hijli affair seems to have been satisfactorily settled.

('62', 173, 1, 2, 330373) That the people are today helpless and unable to help themselves does not affect their mentality.

('62', 174, 6, 24, 334630) I have seen young love so often disappointed in after years.

('62', 175, 0, 1, 334931) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 176
('62', 175, 1, 2, 334973) and from her own standpoint perhaps naturally so, that the progeny should be brought up in the Roman Catholic faith.
('62', 175, 1, 3, 335090) I do not mind it at all.
('62', 175, 1, 4, 335115) But, even though Manu may have no objection, his parents and his people whom he loves dearly will never be able to reconcile themselves to their grandchildren being brought up in a faith other than their own.
('62', 175, 1, 5, 335324) Then there is the question of the whole Hindu culture.
('62', 175, 1, 6, 335379) I see, even at the present moment, a conflict going on between Hindu culture and the Christianity of Indians; the latter are being torn between two almost opposite attractions.
('62', 175, 1, 7, 335556) Somehow or other, Christ ianity has become synonymous with Western culture.
('62', 175, 1, 8, 335632) Perhaps rightly so, for, the religion of the Western people is predominantly Chris tianity and therefore Western culture may be fittingly described as Christaian culture as Indian culture would certainly be described as Hindu culture.
('62', 175, 1, 9, 335867) The progeny of Elizabeth must be brought up in en tirely different surroundings unless Manu decides to tear himself away from his own surroundings and lives an exclusive life or decides to settle down in the West.
('62', 175, 1, 10, 336081) I think that, spiritually considered, Elizabeth herself should not be a party to the possibility of Manu having to tear himself away.
('62', 175, 1, 11, 336215) Then there is the question of Elizabeth herself.
('62', 175, 1, 12, 336264) She would be hard put to it to accommodate herself to Indian surroundings.
('62', 175, 1, 13, 336339) Her constitution may be undermined or she would have to live a life out of all correspondence to her surroundings.
('62', 175, 1, 14, 336454) There is ample justification for Europeans saying that they cannot possibly exist in India without incurring expenses out of all proportion to the Indian average.
('62', 175, 1, 15, 336617) It is difficult enough even for Mira, in spite of her tremendous love for India, in spite of her iron will, to bend herself to the Indian simplicity, and Mira is the general average.
('62', 175, 1, 16, 336800) But even she has to be protected against herself and compel [led] to give herself facilities which her associates are not given.
('62', 175, 1, 17, 336929) She would have become bed ridden long ago if I had not laid down the law from the very first and I know that she has extraordinarliy accommodated herself to the Indian life.
('62', 175, 1, 18, 337103) But, even she would have failed completely if she had married an Indian and made the futile attempt of bringing up her children after the Indian style.
('62', 175, 1, 19, 337255) No body who has not lived in India like Indians can possibly have a conception of what I am writing.
('62', 175, 1, 20, 337356) India is the poorest country in the world.

('62', 175, 1, 22, 337548) I do not recall a single Indian who has taken a

('62', 176, 1, 12, 338642) Now, I think, I have given you a long enough letter and ample matter for thought.

('62', 183, 2, 5, 352546) 202. THE UTILIZATION OF DONATIONS
('62', 183, 3, 6, 352580) Workers desire further elucidation than I have already given in these columns as to the mode of using the donations that are being received during the Harijan tour.
('62', 183, 3, 7, 352745) I have conferred with Thakkar Bapa on the point and I can announce definitely that not less than 75 per cent will be used for Harijan service in the places where they are received, provided that a satisfactory budget is presented and the Central Board approves of it.
('62', 183, 3, 8, 353013) Indeed, even the full amount will be surrendered wherever it is found necessary to do so.
('62', 183, 3, 9, 353103) The only thing, therefore, to do is for workers in each centre to prepare businesslike schemes and produce honest and industrious persons for the due execution of the schemes, and the money will be forthwith coming as soon as needed.
('62', 183, 3, 10, 353337) There is no desire to lock up the donations or to deflect them without cause from the places where they are collected.
('62', 183, 3, 11, 353456) It is intended to keep a certain portion for the Central Board, but there, too, not for overhead charges, but for constructive work directly handled by it.

('62', 192, 2, 3, 370999) November 18, 1933 Before I come to our main subject today it is necessary to say something about the incident which took place while I was on my way here.
('62', 192, 2, 4, 371154) Some persons who have come from Kashi are accompanying me.

('62', 192, 2, 13, 371850) Hence, I sent for the Swami who is their leader and tried to reason with him.
('62', 192, 2, 14, 371928) 1 It is because of this that I am late.

('62', 192, 2, 16, 372069) As the author of the modern technique of satyagraha I told him that their action did not amount to satyagraha, that this kind of action would tire them.

('62', 194, 1, 29, 377699) Hatred or contempt has no place in Hinduism.

('62', 194, 1, 31, 377852) However, even if it is there, we shall have to reject it; otherwise we shall have to give up the claim that Hinduism is basically a non–violent and tolerant faith.
('62', 194, 1, 32, 378016) This movement of ours is being carried on before the eyes of the world, not in seclusion.

('62', 194, 1, 35, 378294) I find no civility in the attempt to stop me car.

('62', 204, 2, 3, 395095) November 21, 1933 These differences 1 are verily offshoots of the curse of untou chability, for they proceed from a sense of superiority and inferiority.
('62', 204, 2, 4, 395249) The fourfold division of varna is based on duty and not on right.
('62', 204, 2, 5, 395315) Dharma does not confer rights but lays down obligations.
('62', 204, 2, 6, 395372) Where all perform the duties that have fallen to their lot, no one is higher than the others.
('62', 204, 2, 7, 395466) Once we are able to purge ourselves of untouchability, and with it the spirit of high and low, we shall realize the unity underlying all races and religions.
('62', 204, 2, 8, 395624) In spite of the differences of races and reli gions, we shall learn to tolerate and respect one another and consider all human beings as children of one God and, therefore, brothers and sisters of one another.
('62', 204, 2, 9, 395834) God is the Creator of all life; all his creatures are, therefore, equal in His eyes.
('62', 204, 2, 10, 395919) Humanity is a gigantic tree having innumerable branches and leaves, and the same life throbs through them all.
('62', 204, 2, 11, 396030) The realization of unity in diversity is implied in the removal of untouchability.

('62', 208, 1, 2, 400878) 226. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI
('62', 208, 2, 3, 400907) Unrevised RAIPUR,
('62', 208, 3, 4, 400925) November 23, 1933
('62', 208, 4, 5, 400943) MY DEAR MAHADEV, On getting up at 3 a.m.
('62', 208, 4, 6, 400984) I found your letter to Mira lying on the little stool which is being carried from place to place as a footboard for me to stretch my legs on.
('62', 208, 4, 7, 401126) It took me nearly 40 minutes to go through it and yet without reading your comments on the translation of the verses specified.
('62', 208, 4, 8, 401254) 1 It would take me at least twelve hours to read up my translation [of] the original and think out what I should say.
('62', 208, 4, 9, 401372) It will take at least another three hours to reduce them to writing.
('62', 208, 4, 10, 401441) That time I cannot give just now.
('62', 208, 4, 11, 401475) Then there is the question—shall I help you much ?
('62', 208, 4, 12, 401526) I fear, not.
('62', 208, 4, 13, 401539) For what you say is quite true.
('62', 208, 4, 14, 401571) I ought not to have yielded to Swami’s demand for my own translation except perhaps for private circulation among friends.
('62', 208, 4, 15, 401694) I realized my unfitness for the task as I was proceeding but I continued.
('62', 208, 4, 16, 401768) The defects you have noticed are there.
('62', 208, 4, 17, 401808) How can I give what I have not—scholarship ?
('62', 208, 4, 18, 401853) Want of good knowledge of Sanskrit was a great drawback.
('62', 208, 4, 19, 401910) The remedy is clear.
('62', 208, 4, 20, 401931) You should go on with your translation taking such help as my translations can give to bring out my thought but not always following my translation.
('62', 208, 4, 21, 402080) Give that rendering which is acceptable to you.
('62', 208, 4, 22, 402128) Ignore the notes where they are useless.
('62', 208, 4, 23, 402169) Give your own where they are nece ssary.
('62', 208, 4, 24, 402210) Having done that, take up the Gujarati, correct the translation where it is defective and polish the language where it needs polishing.
('62', 208, 4, 25, 402346) Re write and add notes where necessary.
('62', 208, 4, 26, 402386) That will complete your task.
('62', 208, 4, 27, 402416) Then when the whole result comes into my hands, I shall work on it and make such changes as I may deem fit in order to bring out my meaning.
('62', 208, 4, 28, 402557) This I can do easily.
('62', 208, 4, 29, 402579) We must then bring out a revised version of the Gujarati and publish your translation in English.
('62', 208, 4, 30, 402677) 2 So doing, you do not need to stop your work for want of my detailed reply to your comments.
('62', 208, 4, 31, 402771) I shall circulate your comments among friends and get their opinion and let you have it all.
('62', 208, 4, 32, 402864) Your other messages will be attended to.

('62', 211, 1, 2, 406761) 229. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETTING, RAIPUR 1
('62', 211, 2, 3, 406802) November 23, 1933 I have repeatedly said that this work can be done only by those who sincerely believe untouchability to be a stain on Hinduism.
('62', 211, 2, 4, 406948) This is a movement requiring the change of heart of millions.
('62', 211, 2, 5, 407010) It cannot be led to success by any political manoeuvres.
('62', 211, 2, 6, 407067) It can be done only through self–purification.
('62', 211, 2, 7, 407114) This is a great sacrificial fire in which we have to burn our load of sins and come out purified.
('62', 211, 2, 8, 407212) Those who do not take to this work with faith and spirit will fail to move the hearts of millions.
('62', 211, 2, 9, 407311) We shall be nowhere if we deceive ourselves or the Harijans.
('62', 211, 2, 10, 407372) The success or failure of this movement depends on our getting the right type of workers.
('62', 211, 2, 11, 407462) We are on our trial today.
('62', 211, 2, 12, 407489) If we miss today the oppportunity that God has given us, we may never hope to get the opportunity again in this generation.
('62', 211, 2, 13, 407613) What we refuse to do voluntarily today we shall have to do in future per force, and we shall repent for having lost this opportunity.
('62', 211, 2, 14, 407747) I pray to God that we may come out suc cessful from this trial and save Hinduism and ourselves from des truction.
('62', 211, 3, 15, 407861) Harijan, 1–12–1933
('62', 211, 4, 16, 407880) 230. SPEECH AT ALL–INDIA SWADESHI EXHIBITION, RAIPUR
('62', 211, 5, 17, 407933) November 23, 1933 In a country where 95 per cent of the population live on the land, even if all the processes of cultivation were carried on through machines, there would still be need for a supplementary cottage industry.
('62', 211, 5, 18, 408157) The spinning wheel supplied that supplementary industry to the Indian peasant from time immemorial.
('62', 211, 5, 19, 408257) Many minor industries are nowadays suggested for the purpose, but none of them can be universalized as the production of khadi can be.
('62', 211, 5, 20, 408392) I consented to open this exhibition, for I know that thousands of Harijans get their living through khadi, which has saved them from destitution.
('62', 211, 5, 21, 408538) We may revive
('62', 211, 6, 22, 408552) 1 According to Chandrashankar Shukla’s report, the speech was addressed to Harijan workers.
('62', 211, 6, 23, 408644) However, according to The Bombay Chronicle, 29–11 1933, and Hitavada, 3–12–1933, this was in reply to addresses presented by the Municipality, the Local Board and other institutions.
('62', 212, 0, 1, 408827) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 213
('62', 212, 1, 2, 408874) many other indigenous industries, may even start new ones, but we may not lose sight of khadi as the centre of all swadeshi.

('62', 212, 3, 4, 409018) 231. EXTRACTS FROM SPEECHES 1
('62', 212, 4, 5, 409048) [Before November 24, 1933] 2
('62', 212, 5, 6, 409077) Injustice is being done all the world over, but we have given to it the sanction of religion.
('62', 212, 5, 7, 409171) These distinctions have not been created by God.
('62', 212, 5, 8, 409220) The Harijans are on the lowest rung of the ladder not because of any inherent defects but only because they have been kept down by the so–called higher castes.
('62', 212, 5, 9, 409380) God had bestowed on them the same talents that He had given us, but we deny them the opportunities for using them.
('62', 212, 5, 10, 409495) They should surely have the same rights and privileges and the same opportunities of growth that we enjoy.
('62', 212, 5, 11, 409602) We are now awake to the wrong we have done to them, and the least we can do by way of penance now is to contribute money for their uplift and to share with them all the amenities of life that we have created for ourselves.
('62', 212, 5, 12, 409825) We are all creatures of the same God and, therefore, equal in His eyes.
('62', 212, 6, 13, 409897) From the money that you give for this cause, you will reap a hundredfold, for it is like grain sown in good, manured soil.
('62', 212, 6, 14, 410020) The money spent after luxury and lust is, on the other hand, wasted like grain sown in barren soil.
('62', 212, 7, 15, 410120) I am told you have suffered heavily.
('62', 212, 7, 16, 410157) But you should know that no nation has ever come to its own without having passed through the severest fire of suffering.
('62', 212, 7, 17, 410279) Voluntary suffering only adds to our strength.
('62', 212, 7, 18, 410326) I, therefore, congratulate you for having suffered.
('62', 212, 7, 19, 410378) But I should also like to remind you that one of the causes that add to our sufferings is this curse of untouchability.
('62', 212, 7, 20, 410498) We have oppressed the weak.
('62', 212, 7, 21, 410526) We reap as we have sown.
('62', 212, 7, 22, 410551) It is for us now to undo the wrong we have done to the Harijans and remove the yoke of serfdom from their

('62', 213, 1, 2, 410902) shoulders.
('62', 213, 2, 3, 410913) Caste Hindus must first ask you to forgive the wrongs they have done to you.
('62', 213, 2, 4, 410990) But I should also tell you, as a Harijan by choice, that you should give up your evil habits, especially carrion and beef– eating.
('62', 213, 2, 5, 411121) The whole world looks upon carrion with abhorrence.
('62', 213, 2, 6, 411173) And beef–eating should be given up because that is a sine qua non for a Hindu.
('62', 213, 2, 7, 411252) The cow is the giver of plenty, and by killing her we kill ourselves.
('62', 213, 2, 8, 411322) Then, I would urge you not to accept leavings.
('62', 213, 2, 9, 411369) And, above all, you should abolish the distinctions of high and low that have crept in among yourselves.
('62', 213, 2, 10, 411474) And these things you should do, not in a bargaining spirit but because they are good in themselves.
('62', 213, 2, 11, 411574) I would, therefore, ask you also to give up drink, irrespective of the fact that many other Hindus drink.
('62', 213, 2, 12, 411680) Harijan, 1–12–1933
('62', 213, 3, 13, 411699) 232. CIVIL RESISTANCE AND HARIJAN SERVICE A friend writes : 2
('62', 213, 4, 14, 411761) I observe that there are some people in the Harijan service organizations not working in the spirit in which you want them to, that is, merely for the sake of serving Harijans.
('62', 213, 4, 15, 411938) They are seeking its shelter in order to satisfy other ambitions.
('62', 213, 4, 16, 412004) .I know that you do not desire civil resistance to be mixed up with Harijan service organizations.
('62', 213, 4, 17, 412103) If you propose to make any public use of this letter you may emphasize this last point and make it clearer.
('62', 213, 4, 18, 412211) I am thankful to the friend for giving me the benefit of his experience.
('62', 213, 4, 19, 412284) It is a most difficult task to keep a big organization like the Servants of Untouchables Society with branches all over India free of all self–seekers and time–servers.
('62', 213, 4, 20, 412453) I have discussed the subject fully with Seth Ghanshyamdas and Thakkar Bapa.
('62', 213, 4, 21, 412529) I know that they are both anxious to keep the organization as pure as possible.
('62', 213, 4, 22, 412609) Personally I can do no more.
('62', 213, 4, 23, 412638) It was because of my utter helplessness that I undertook the fast of 21 days.
('62', 213, 4, 24, 412716) On discovering impurities amongst Harijan servants, I saw that it was no use merely writing about impurities.
('62', 213, 4, 25, 412826) I was searching for a way out of the difficulty.
('62', 213, 4, 26, 412875) The reader should believe me when I tell him that the fast was the last thing in the world that I was thinking of, but as I have described in these pages, it came to me all of a sudden and gave me great relief.
('62', 213, 4, 27, 413086) I know that it did much good.
('62', 213, 4, 28, 413116) But, how far could the fast of a single mortal go ?
('62', 213, 5, 29, 413168) 1 What follows was addressed to Harijans.
('62', 213, 5, 30, 413210) 2 Only extracts from the letter are reporduced here.
('62', 214, 0, 1, 413263) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 215
('62', 214, 1, 2, 413310) it was that I developed the idea of a chain of such purificatory fasts.
('62', 214, 1, 3, 413382) The idea has by no means been dropped.
('62', 214, 1, 4, 413421) It comes to me again and again.
('62', 214, 1, 5, 413453) But it does not admit of a mechanical organization.
('62', 214, 1, 6, 413505) Several co– workers are ready to inaugurate or take part in the chain after it is inaugurated, but I have not yet found the way to begin it.
('62', 214, 1, 7, 413646) The proper way will have to come to me or to the co–workers before the chain can be begun.
('62', 214, 1, 8, 413737) Meanwhile I can only reiterate my conviction that untouchability will not be removed root and branch except through the service of men and women who take it up for its own sake and in a religious spirit.
('62', 214, 1, 9, 413941) Unless we have a fair number of such servants throughout the length and breadth of India, we will never succeed in changing the hearts of millions of human beings.
('62', 214, 1, 10, 414105) The savarna Hindus are at one end, Harijans at the other, and the evil custom of ages, which has assumed the dignity of religious tenet, will not be uprooted without penance and purification.
('62', 214, 1, 11, 414297) Whilst it gladdens my heart that thousands of people flock to the meetings that are being held in towns and villages and that they willingly give their pices as a token of their approval of the movement, I am painfully conscious of the fact that, if the thousands were suddenly called upon to enforce in their own lives what they seem to approve by their attendance at these meetings, they would fail to respond, not from want of will, but from sheer inability.
('62', 214, 1, 12, 414759) I have discovered this again and again amongst my closest associates who have frankly confessed their inability to enforce immediately in their conduct what they knew was the right thing and what they knew had to be done immediately.
('62', 214, 1, 13, 414993) They had to put up a brave fight against their traditional repugnance.
('62', 214, 1, 14, 415064) The mere intellectual grasp that untou chability is an evil, corroding Hinduism, and that belief in it is tanta mount to disbelief in God, His goodness and His Fatherhood, is not enough to destroy the monster.
('62', 214, 1, 15, 415274) The vicarious penance of the com paratively pure is needed to bring about a change in the hearts of both savarnas and Harijans.
('62', 214, 1, 16, 415402) A movement, so grand and so pure, so religious and so humanitarian, must not be exploited by anybody for his own end.
('62', 214, 1, 17, 415520) Certainly, not for its political consequences.
('62', 214, 1, 18, 415567) It will be discovered, as the movement progresses, that the political approach can only end in accentuating the strife.
('62', 214, 1, 19, 415687) It can only add to the confusion already existing and add one more, if not many more warring parties, to the existing ones.
('62', 214, 1, 20, 415811) May God save us and save the movement from such a calamity !
('62', 214, 1, 21, 415872) So far as the connection of civil resistance with the movement is
('62', 215, 0, 1, 415938) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 216
('62', 215, 1, 2, 415980) concerned, I am as emphatic as ever that Congressmen who desire to offer active civil resistance should not accept office in the various organizations, and much less can they be used for serving the purpose of civil resistance.
('62', 215, 1, 3, 416208) Civil resistance is a unique weapon, it does not admit of alloy.
('62', 215, 1, 4, 416273) It is a weapon of the fearless and, therefore, needs no shelter; but it has to be wielded in the open daylight.
('62', 215, 1, 5, 416385) Therefore, whilst Congressmen who are also civil resisters on active service may do, as they are bound to do, such service to the cause as they can, they may not belong to the Servants of Untouchables Society or any of its branches.
('62', 215, 1, 6, 416618) By holding office in the organizations they will harm both civil resistance and the Harijan cause.
('62', 215, 1, 7, 416717) It would be like a man going to a temple to pray and using the act of worship for advancing civil resistance.
('62', 215, 1, 8, 416827) Neither God nor man will be cheated in that manner and, as I have said often enough in these columns, the great reformation of Hinduism will not be brought about, if it is to depend purely upon Congressmen.
('62', 215, 1, 9, 417034) For, much as I would like to think that every Indian is Congressman, I know that such is not the case.
('62', 215, 1, 10, 417137) Nor is every Hindu a Congressman, if only because every Harijan is not a Congressman.
('62', 215, 1, 11, 417223) Therefore, a Harijan organization must in the very nature of things be strictly non–political and non–party and should contain in it both Congressmen and non–Congressmen, office–holding being restricted to those who are not active civil resisters and who will not exploit the office secretly or openly to advance the cause of civil resistance.
('62', 215, 1, 12, 417567) Harijan, 24–11–1933
('62', 215, 2, 13, 417587) 233. HARIJAN WORKER’S DUTY
('62', 215, 3, 14, 417614) A correspondent sends me the following questions for answering :
('62', 215, 4, 15, 417679) (1) In the propaganda against untouchability, should a worker make use of the Hindu Shastras and religious texts to show that Hinduism does not sanction untouchability as we practise it today ?
('62', 215, 5, 16, 417873) (2) Should a Harijan sevak, even in his private capacity, take part in inter– dining functions ?
('62', 215, 6, 17, 417970) (3) Should a Harijan who is employed as a domestic servant sit at meals alongside all the members of the family ?
('62', 215, 6, 18, 418084) These three questions, the correspondent says, have been seriously discussed in the columns of a newspaper and the readers have been advised that Harijan workers ought not to make use of religious texts in advocating the abolition of untouchability, and that,
('62', 216, 0, 1, 418344) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 217
('62', 216, 1, 2, 418391) in the larger interest of the movement, the workers should not enforce their views about inter–dining and the rest, even in their private matters.
('62', 216, 1, 3, 418538) I hold totally different views on these matters.
('62', 216, 1, 4, 418587) For me, the removal of untouchability is fundamentally a religious question.
('62', 216, 1, 5, 418664) Hinduism could not hold me if I believed that untouchability, as it is practised today, was an integral part of it.
('62', 216, 1, 6, 418780) That it has been handed down to us as a custom is an undoubted fact, but so are many other bad customs among which untouchability is the worst.
('62', 216, 1, 7, 418924) It becomes necessary, therefore, to show that it has no sanction in religion.
('62', 216, 1, 8, 419002) Whilst the Servants of Untouchables Society has very wisely limited the scope of its corporate activities, it does not regulate or restrict individual practice about inter–dining.
('62', 216, 1, 9, 419182) The removal of untou chability does not require inter–dining with Harijans.
('62', 216, 1, 10, 419258) Inter–dining is not a universal obligation.
('62', 216, 1, 11, 419302) A Harijan worker must be left free to dine with whomsoever he pleases, and, therefore, with Harijans, without in any way being regarded as being on that account a less effective worker.
('62', 216, 1, 12, 419488) My own practice is well known, and I should personally feel a hypocrite if I suppressed it ‘in the larger interests of the reform’.
('62', 216, 1, 13, 419620) I should undoubtedly refrain, if inter–dining were a mere matter of convenience or indulgence for me.
('62', 216, 1, 14, 419722) Far from being either, I regard it as a desirable and an inevitable social reform.
('62', 216, 1, 15, 419805) But it should not be mixed up with the drive against untouchability.
('62', 216, 1, 16, 419874) The central point in the untouchability movement is the removal of social and religious injustice towards those who, being regarded as untouchables, are debarred from public utilities and spiritual comfort within the religion to which they belong.
('62', 216, 1, 17, 420122) I should feel no deprivation if no one in the world took food that might be cooked or touched by me.
('62', 216, 1, 18, 420223) But it would be a great deprivation to me if I could not send my children to the public school, or could not rent a house in any locality open to the other members of the public, or could not seek spiritual comfort in a temple designed for the other members of my faith.
('62', 216, 1, 19, 420494) As to the Harijan employee, if the members of a family employing a Harijan drew a line between him and non–Harijan ser vants, they would undoubtedly be guilty of observing untouc hability.
('62', 216, 1, 20, 420683) But I very much fear that we are a long way from that bright and happy day when we shall be all masters and no servants, or all servants and no masters, all members of the human family, regarding ourselves as blood–brothers and blood–sisters.
('62', 216, 1, 21, 420926) Harijan, 24–11–1933

('62', 219, 7, 24, 425221) 238. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, RAIPUR
('62', 219, 8, 25, 425259) November 24, 1933 Ever since I came to your province you have been showering love on me and I am still bathing in it.
('62', 219, 8, 26, 425377) Here also you have further delighted me by presenting me this purse.
('62', 219, 8, 27, 425446) You would be right if you believe that you should give me money to please me, and especially so if you fulfil one condition.
('62', 219, 8, 28, 425571) It is that those who have given money should feel that they have contributed to a yajna of self–purification.
('62', 219, 8, 29, 425681) The money that is given can only be a token of your contribution to that yajna.
('62', 219, 8, 30, 425761) But if they think that they have done all that they need to by giving the money, it would be the worst characteristic of a clever Bania.
('62', 219, 8, 31, 425898) It would be as if by giving that money they had bought the right to enjoy themselves as they wished.
('62', 219, 8, 32, 425999) Such charity can be of no
('62', 220, 0, 1, 426025) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 221
('62', 220, 1, 2, 426072) benefit to the Harijans.
('62', 220, 1, 3, 426097) I do not deny that money is very badly needed for Harijan work; but it is more important for their service that you should accept the Harijans with your heart.
('62', 220, 1, 4, 426257) The real purpose of this tour is that you should discard the notion of untouchability from your heart and banish feelings of high and low.
('62', 220, 1, 5, 426396) If you give me no help in realizing that aim and give me only money, it would be difficult even to use that money.
('62', 220, 1, 6, 426511) If you do not know it, please note that at least 75 per cent of the money collected from this place will be used for the Harijan work here.
('62', 220, 1, 7, 426651) There are two conditions, however, and they are also meant for the success of this work.
('62', 220, 1, 8, 426740) In the first place, a good scheme for the use of that amount should come from you, and along with that there should be an indication of the persons who would carry out the scheme.
('62', 220, 1, 9, 426920) A scheme may be good on paper, but it will be useless and will fail if there was nobody to implement it.
('62', 220, 1, 10, 427025) That is why I said that, if your heart is not behind your contribution, the money you have given will be as good as useless.
('62', 220, 1, 11, 427150) And if this happens, it would be diverted to other places where better workers and better schemes are forthcoming.
('62', 220, 1, 12, 427265) You would not be happy if this happens.
('62', 220, 1, 13, 427305) We who have come here do not wish to do any such thing.
('62', 220, 1, 14, 427361) Our intention is to use at least 75 per cent of the money in the place from where it is collected.
('62', 220, 1, 15, 427460) If, however, you do not give your full co–operation in this work, nothing can be done with the money alone.
('62', 220, 1, 16, 427568) It is a matter of joy for the country and for Hindus that at every place people gather in such large numbers.
('62', 220, 1, 17, 427678) I am working in the faith that all these people come to the meetings to help me in my work of removing untouchability.
('62', 220, 1, 18, 427797) If they come because they think that I have served the country in the past, and in order to praise my past services, they are guilty of great deception.
('62', 220, 1, 19, 427950) I think of no other work just now.
('62', 220, 1, 20, 427985) I have undertaken this tour only for Harijan work, and not to hear my praises.
('62', 220, 1, 21, 428064) Hence, only those who wish to help me in this work or criticize it should attend the meetings.
('62', 220, 1, 22, 428159) Those who wish to oppose the work should express their opposition courteously and in a becoming manner.
('62', 220, 1, 23, 428263) In a religious cause, forgetting courtesy means forsaking dharma itself.
('62', 220, 1, 24, 428336) Rudeness and lack of courtesy go ill with religion.
('62', 220, 1, 25, 428388) Religion must be accompanied with gentleness, courtesy, culture and compassion.
('62', 220, 1, 26, 428468) I do not wish to waste my time.
('62', 220, 1, 27, 428500) It would no doubt pain me to know that the Hindu masses are not with me.
('62', 220, 1, 28, 428573) But it would pain me all the more if they attend the meetings to deceive me and themselves.
('62', 220, 1, 29, 428665) I have got to follow my dharma even if everybody deserts me.
('62', 220, 1, 30, 428726) The scriptures say that you
('62', 221, 0, 1, 428754) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 222
('62', 221, 1, 2, 428796) need not have anyone on your side for following dharma, that you need God alone.
('62', 221, 1, 3, 428877) Following dharma is a matter for each individual himself.
('62', 221, 1, 4, 428935) One must do one’s duty to the best of one’s ability.
('62', 221, 1, 5, 428988) God will look after the rest.
('62', 221, 1, 6, 429018) The dharma of fighting untouchability is precious like a gem.
('62', 221, 1, 7, 429080) I have placed it before you.
('62', 221, 1, 8, 429109) This is no ordinary gem which can be used only by one person or which would wear off by use.
('62', 221, 1, 9, 429202) Millions can use the gem of dharma ; the more the people use it, the brighter will it shine.
('62', 221, 1, 10, 429295) There is no doubt at all that unless we wipe out the blot of untouchability from Hinduism, both Hinduism and Hindu society will perish.
('62', 221, 1, 11, 429431) Peoples and their religions are being compared and judged all over the world.
('62', 221, 1, 12, 429509) We are living in an age when we can travel to distant places in a few days by train and go round the world by sea.
('62', 221, 1, 13, 429624) And now aeroplanes too are coming into use.
('62', 221, 1, 14, 429668) In an age like this, all religions are exposed to the eyes of the world.
('62', 221, 1, 15, 429741) If we fail in this scrutiny we may be sure that we are doomed.
('62', 221, 1, 16, 429804) The world has a right to make such a comparison.
('62', 221, 1, 17, 429853) That which cannot be placed before the world and which is not acceptable to reason and the heart cannot be sanatana dharma.
('62', 221, 1, 18, 429977) Sanatana dharma means imperishable Truth.
('62', 221, 1, 19, 430019) I was glad when I was told that Bharatdasji intends to throw open his temple to Harijans.
('62', 221, 1, 20, 430109) The site of the temple is very beautiful.
('62', 221, 1, 21, 430151) I performed the opening with God as witness.
('62', 221, 1, 22, 430196) The Harijans had cheerfully come in large numbers.
('62', 221, 1, 23, 430247) The scriptures have laid down two or three conditions for the Harijans or other people who visit a temple.
('62', 221, 1, 24, 430354) They must enter the temple with a pure heart and body.
('62', 221, 1, 25, 430409) Observing rules of personal cleanliness is as necessary in the case of Harijans as in that of the other Hindus, and, therefore, they should be duly observed by them.
('62', 221, 1, 26, 430575) The second condition is that they should give up eating beef and carrion.
('62', 221, 1, 27, 430649) The latter is prohibited in every religion.
('62', 221, 1, 28, 430693) I am not aware of civilized and religious–minded people eating carrion, anywhere in the world.
('62', 221, 1, 29, 430788) It is abhorred by all mankind.
('62', 221, 1, 30, 430819) Harijans must give up these two things irrespective of whether or not they are accepted by the caste Hindus.
('62', 221, 1, 31, 430928) If they consider themselves Hindus, they must give up beef also.
('62', 221, 1, 32, 430993) Now there is a fourth thing, which I cannot describe as an inseparable part of Hinduism, though it is so according to me.
('62', 221, 1, 33, 431115) And that is abstention from intoxicating drinks.
('62', 221, 1, 34, 431164) Other Hindus may or may not give them up, but you should definitely do so.
('62', 221, 1, 35, 431239) It is a very bad habit.
('62', 221, 1, 36, 431263) A bad habit should not be copied.
('62', 221, 1, 37, 431297) Moreover, you want to progress, and so you must give up drinking.

('62', 224, 2, 3, 435231) November 25, 1933
('62', 224, 3, 4, 435249) Gandhiji declared open to Harijans a private temple, saying that the temple had on that day become a true abode of God with the Harijans’ entry into it.
('62', 224, 3, 5, 435402) Asking Harijans to observe three conditions of temple–entry, which apply equally to all temple–going Hindus, he said : I request you to contribute your full share to this movement of self–purification, not by money but by a thorough cleansing of the heart and body and by removing the evil habits that have crept in amongst you.
('62', 224, 3, 6, 435731) Though I admit with shame that the caste Hindus are responsible for many of these evil habits, I should like you to do your own part by giving up carrion and beef–eating and observing the common rules of cleanliness.
('62', 224, 3, 7, 435948) These three conditions apply equally to all Hindus who want the right of worship in Hindu temples.
('62', 224, 3, 8, 436047) I should like you to give up drink also, irrespective of the fact that even some caste Hindus indulge in that intoxication.
('62', 224, 3, 9, 436171) You may not imitate their vices.
('62', 224, 3, 10, 436204) Drink is one of the most degrading of vices, reducing man to the state of brute.
('62', 224, 3, 11, 436285) It vitiates both body and soul.
('62', 224, 3, 12, 436317) It spells utter ruin of the moral and domestic life.
('62', 224, 3, 13, 436370) I would, therefore, request Harijans in all earnestness to give up that vice and set a noble example of self purification not only to caste Hindus but perhaps to the whole world.

('62', 224, 5, 15, 436568) 241. SPEECH AT BILASPUR 2
('62', 224, 6, 16, 436594) November 25, 1933 You may know, if you do not know already, that I have been closely assoicated with labourers ever since I went to South Africa.
('62', 224, 6, 17, 436740) Whenever I have gone among labourers, in South Africa, India or whatever part of the world, they have recognized me as a fellow– labourer and received me as one of themselves.
('62', 224, 6, 18, 436916) You will perhaps be surprised to know that even labourers in Lancashire instinctively
('62', 224, 7, 19, 437002) 1 This appeared in Harijan under the title “Conditions for Temple–entry”.
('62', 224, 8, 20, 437076) 2 Delivered at the B. N. Railway Labourers’ Federation.

('62', 225, 0, 1, 437236) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 226
('62', 225, 1, 2, 437278) recognized me as one of themselves and flocked around me in hundreds and thousands.
('62', 225, 1, 3, 437362) The only difference between us is that I have become a labourer by choice whilst you have been made labourers by force of circumstances and would perhaps love to be masters if you could.
('62', 225, 1, 4, 437549) I early gave up the ambition of becoming the master for I would then have belonged to an inconsiderate class and could not have identified myself, as I do today to the best of my ability, with the penniless pauper, the half–starved and the naked, the lowliest and the lost.
('62', 225, 1, 5, 437823) I want labourers not to deplore, much less to despise, their lot and to realize the dignity of labour.
('62', 225, 1, 6, 437926) It is meet that you have come forward with your purse as a token of your sympathy with the Harijans.
('62', 225, 1, 7, 438027) Who has suffered so much as they ?
('62', 225, 1, 8, 438062) They are at the lowest rung of the ladder.
('62', 225, 1, 9, 438105) The terrible hardships and privations they have to undergo can never be imagined by those who have not been victims to them.
('62', 225, 1, 10, 438230) Other labourers may aspire to a mass wealth and to become masters some day and thus to rise in the scale of social prestige; but the Harijans can never entertain that ambition.
('62', 225, 1, 11, 438407) The stigma of untouchability attaches to them from the mother’s womb.
('62', 225, 1, 12, 438477) They are born outcastes and remain outcastes till death.
('62', 225, 1, 13, 438534) They have to live in segregated areas and are denied the amenities of life that the others enjoy.
('62', 225, 1, 14, 438632) Even water, that free gift of God, is denied to them.
('62', 225, 1, 15, 438686) I ask the Labour Federation to abolish all distinctions between Harijans and yourselves.
('62', 225, 1, 16, 438775) I make the appeal deliberately for, being in direct touch with the mill–hands in Ahmedabad, I know that labourers do observe the distinction between Harijans and non–Harijans.
('62', 225, 1, 17, 438951) I expect labourers, more than all others, to efface these distinctions.
('62', 225, 1, 18, 439023) It has been my deep faith that we shall some day achieve communal unity through labourers.
('62', 225, 1, 19, 439114) I consider labour to be a powerful unifying agent.
('62', 225, 1, 20, 439165) It is a great equalizer.
('62', 225, 1, 21, 439190) It should be a matter of shame to have communal divisions among labourers, who all earn their bread by the sweat of their brow and, therefore, belong to one vast brotherhood.
('62', 225, 1, 22, 439365) Let them, therefore, begin with a thorough removal of untouchability.
('62', 225, 1, 23, 439435) It will be a great step towards communal unity.
('62', 225, 1, 24, 439483) Once the bar sinister against Harijans is removed, the way will be open for a wider unity among Hindus, Mussalmans and other sister communities.
('62', 225, 2, 25, 439628) A Mussalman friend asked why Gandhiji, a national leader, had chosen for the time being to work only among a section of the nation.
('62', 225, 2, 26, 439760) This question drew the following reply from Gandhiji.
('62', 225, 2, 27, 439814) I am trying to serve all communities today through this work.
('62', 225, 2, 28, 439876) They are branches of one big family.
('62', 225, 2, 29, 439913) I have found in the Hindu
('62', 226, 0, 1, 439939) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 227
('62', 226, 1, 2, 439986) branch a disease which, if not removed in time, will spread through the whole family and destroy it.
('62', 226, 1, 3, 440087) The evil of untouchability has travelled far beyond its prescribed limits.
('62', 226, 1, 4, 440162) In trying to root out untouchability among Hindus, I am trying to serve all the communities.
('62', 226, 1, 5, 440255) Though the method of achieving communal unity through conferences has failed, I have not despaired of a heart–unity being achieved in the end.
('62', 226, 1, 6, 440398) God has sent me this work, and I am doing it in the faith that the way to a real communal unity will be paved through it.
('62', 226, 1, 7, 440520) It is thus to my mind a service of the whole nation.
('62', 226, 1, 8, 440573) The effort I made in 1920–21 to achieve Hindu–Muslim unity will go down in history and will serve as the foundation of the edifice of communal unity whenever it is achieved.
('62', 226, 1, 9, 440747) I have never repented for having made that effort.
('62', 226, 1, 10, 440798) For me it was not a matter of expedience.
('62', 226, 1, 11, 440840) I am not aware of having done a single thing in my life as a matter of expedience.
('62', 226, 1, 12, 440923) I have ever held that the highest morality is also the highest expedience.
('62', 226, 1, 13, 440998) Some European friends assure me that I am waging this war against untouchability on behalf of the whole of humanity.
('62', 226, 1, 14, 441115) Once this canker is removed from Hinduism, Hindus, Mussalmans and others will sink their differences and will embrace one another as blood–brothers, and all communities will feel that they are all branches of the same tree.

('62', 231, 4, 12, 448407) 250. LETTER TO JANAKDHARI PRASAD
('62', 231, 5, 13, 448440) AS AT WARDHA, November 26, 1933 DEAR JANAKDHARI BABU, I have your letter.
('62', 231, 5, 14, 448514) I wish that I could have a heart to heart chat with you.
('62', 231, 5, 15, 448571) I shall try to write to you at length in spite of the pressure under which I am working.
('62', 231, 5, 16, 448660) But I know that the letter will never yield the result that a brief conversation can.
('62', 231, 5, 17, 448746) From your letter, I had gathered that you were not fit to seek imprisonment, and knowing your domestic difficulties as I now do, I feel that until those difficulties are satisfactorily solved you ought not to think of imprisonment.
('62', 231, 5, 18, 448978) By labour I mean any kind of physical labour that you may be able to perform.
('62', 231, 5, 19, 449056) Such labour for you is tailoring, shoemaking and any other healthy labour that you can think of.
('62', 231, 5, 20, 449153) Whilst you will not immediately earn much, it will mean a mighty revolution in your life.
('62', 231, 5, 21, 449243) Your children will then be brought up as labourers.
('62', 231, 5, 22, 449295) 2 As such they will not have to struggle so much to live, as you do just now.
('62', 231, 5, 23, 449373) And when your attitude is changed, you will set for yourself and the whole family the labourer’s standard of life.
('62', 231, 5, 24, 449488) Your wife, if she accepts the revolutionary change, will also be doing her share of labour.
('62', 231, 6, 25, 449580) 1 Jayakunvar Doctor 2 Vide also “Letter to Janakdhari Prasad”, 15 10 1933
('62', 232, 0, 1, 449654) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 233
('62', 232, 1, 2, 449701) You will be interested to know that my sister 1, because she will not live in the Ashram, owing to non observance of untouchability, earns about Rs. 15 per month by grinding.
('62', 232, 1, 3, 449876) Giri, who with her three daughters and two sons was in the Ashram for seven years and whom I declined to support on the breaking up to the Ashram, but whom I advised to take to some labour is now earning from the labour of her two daughters nearly Rs. 30 per month by preparing sweetmeats and fritters for a hotel keeper.
('62', 232, 1, 4, 450198) And her son isearning about the same as a carpenter.
('62', 232, 1, 5, 450251) Dal Bahadur Giri was not a labourer.
('62', 232, 1, 6, 450288) He was living an almost aristocratic life.
('62', 232, 1, 7, 450331) I believe that the widow and her daughters are happy.
('62', 232, 1, 8, 450385) They have not cut off all connections with me.
('62', 232, 1, 9, 450432) Two daughters are grown up girls, marriageable, but have no present intention of marrying.
('62', 232, 1, 10, 450523) They can read and write but they have learned the dignity of labour, and therefore are not a burden on society.
('62', 232, 1, 11, 450635) Now I hope you understand what I mean by physical labour.
('62', 232, 1, 12, 450693) Now for the education of your children.
('62', 232, 1, 13, 450733) If you accept the revolution that I have suggested, naturally the children will be brought up by you.
('62', 232, 1, 14, 450835) You will give them not merely a literary training but you will give them also a training for labour with their hands.
('62', 232, 1, 15, 450953) Immediately you begin this life you will find it to be a pleasure and all your difficulties will automatically be solved, and you will be rendering a distinct service to society by setting a wise example.
('62', 232, 1, 16, 451158) I do want you to get out of the mood of despondency and helplessness.
('62', 232, 1, 17, 451228) Do write again if this does not explain all I mean.
('62', 232, 1, 18, 451280) Yours sincerely, BAPU [From Hindi]
