('62', 233, 13, 28, 453286) 1 Published in Harijan under the title “Princes and Untouchability”
('62', 234, 0, 1, 453354) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 235
('62', 234, 1, 2, 453401) their education, will be called upon to bear a great responsibility and burden.
('62', 234, 1, 3, 453481) And it was a matter of great pleasure to me that the Reception Committee was able to set apart one hour for this function.
('62', 234, 1, 4, 453604) I thank you, Sir, for having extended this invitation to me, thereby enabling me to deliver my message to the youths who are at present under your kind care.
('62', 234, 1, 5, 453762) You were thoughtful enough to send a message to my host, Shuklaji 1that, whilst I could address this audience in Hindustani if I so chose, you would appreciate it if I addressed them in English; and you were good enough, when I exchanged a letter with you, to tell me that many of the boys under your care did not know Hindustani.
('62', 234, 1, 6, 454093) I at once decided to address you, in spite of my ordinary practice to the contrary, in English.
('62', 234, 1, 7, 454189) Your Principal inadvertently supplied me also with a text for my message.
('62', 234, 1, 8, 454263) I would like you, sons of Chiefs in these territories, to remember that you would be expected not merely to confine yourselves, in these days of progressive enlightenment and rapid inter–communication, to your comparatively very small territories, but you would be expected to extend your horizon; and if you will do so, as I have no doubt you will be obliged to do by force of circumstances, it will be necessary for you not merely to know the languages of the province in which your lot is cast, but you will be expected to know also the language that is most universally used in this country.
('62', 234, 1, 9, 454859) And you may not know, all of you, I am sure, do not know, that over 22 crores of the people of this country know sufficient Hindi or Hindustani to be able to understand what is spoken to them and to express themselves, however broken their language may be.
('62', 234, 1, 10, 455116) No Indian having to shoulder the responsibility that you will have to shoulder can possibly afford to ignore such a universal language.
('62', 234, 1, 11, 455252) There is a method in my mad love of Hindi.
('62', 234, 1, 12, 455295) I am a lover of the English language, and I would like to speak in the English language as well as is possible for a foreigner to do and compete with Englishmen.
('62', 234, 1, 13, 455457) I know that I am far away from that consummation.
('62', 234, 1, 14, 455507) Whatever English I know is due to my having lived for years among Englishmen and English–speaking men.
('62', 234, 1, 15, 455610) I count hundreds of English men and women as close friends.
('62', 234, 1, 16, 455670) So you will not misunderstand me when I tell you that it is your duty to understand Hindustani and I will beg the Principal and his staff to realize the special condition of this
('62', 234, 2, 17, 455849) 1 Delivered at the B. N. Railway Labourers’ Federation.
('62', 234, 2, 18, 455905) This appeared in Harijan in two parts under the titles “A Great Equalizer” and “On Behalf of Humanity”.
('62', 235, 0, 1, 456009) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 236
('62', 235, 1, 2, 456051) country and to feel with me that it is desirable for the Chiefs of India to understand Hindustani, through which alone they can know the India of the people.
('62', 235, 1, 3, 456209) This brings me to the central point of my message.
('62', 235, 1, 4, 456260) We have been in the midst of Englishmen in various walks of life.
('62', 235, 1, 5, 456326) I have had the painful duty very often of criticizing the policy of the rulers.
('62', 235, 1, 6, 456406) I have not minced words.
('62', 235, 1, 7, 456431) I have spoken straight from my heart, but as I have told you, I claim the closest friendship with hundreds of English men.
('62', 235, 1, 8, 456554) I cannot forget some of their priceless virtues.
('62', 235, 1, 9, 456603) I propose to single out one of them for you.
('62', 235, 1, 10, 456648) In England there is a living family tie between its noblemen and their domestic servants.
('62', 235, 1, 11, 456738) It was a matter of joy to me on visiting them in their homes to find that there was a subtle bond of affection between them and their servants.
('62', 235, 1, 12, 456882) There was no untouchability there.
('62', 235, 1, 13, 456917) What I have told you is literally true of hundreds of the noblemen of England.
('62', 235, 1, 14, 456996) Wherever I went, it was an unexpected pleasure to me at the end of the visit ot be introduced to the domestic staff not as inferior beings but as members of the family.
('62', 235, 1, 15, 457165) I wish that you would copy this virtue in your own lives.
('62', 235, 1, 16, 457223) There is unfortunately among us a feeling that Chiefs are Chiefs and they can never make common cause with the ordinary people and so you find the tragedy—however necessary it may be today—that special schools and colleges have got to be built for you.
('62', 235, 1, 17, 457476) You dare not, you will not,go to common schools and colleges.You may not know that King Edward and the present King, I am speaking subject to correction, worked in the Navy as if they were ordinary sailors and that both father and son shared the hardships of a sailor’s life.
('62', 235, 1, 18, 457752) Will you do that ?
('62', 235, 1, 19, 457771) You are confined as it were to hot houses and are taught to believe that you have been gifted with special divinity by God.
('62', 235, 1, 20, 457895) Believe me there is absolutely no difference whatsoever between you and the common folk except this that you have opportunities that are denied to them.
('62', 235, 1, 21, 458048) But if you do not make use of the opportunities God has given you, it will be counted against you in God’s book of accounts.
('62', 235, 1, 22, 458173) Know that the essence of education lies in drawing out the very best that is in you.
('62', 235, 1, 23, 458258) You and I can take the positive comfort that is in you.
('62', 235, 1, 24, 458314) You and I can take the positive comfort that all of us have an equal potential capacity for being good or bad.
('62', 235, 1, 25, 458425) I, therefore, feel that all your education will be vain, if you do not learn the art of feeling one with the poorest in the land.
('62', 235, 1, 26, 458555) This brings me in the natural course to untouchability.
('62', 235, 1, 27, 458611) In no other part of the world has a patent evil like untouchability been claimed to possess religious sanction as it has in Hindu India.
('62', 235, 1, 28, 458748) But, if you have agreed with me so far, you are bound to regard the Harijan
('62', 236, 0, 1, 458824) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 237
('62', 236, 1, 2, 458871) as an integral part of common humanity.
('62', 236, 1, 3, 458911) You have to realize your oneness even with him.
('62', 236, 1, 4, 458959) It may be that your parents will dispute the proposition that untouchability is an unmixed evil.
('62', 236, 1, 5, 459056) You will then have to show the courage of your conviction even as young Prahlad did.
('62', 236, 1, 6, 459141) The idea of hereditary superiority and inferiority is, in my opinion, repugnant to the spirit of Hinduism which teaches oneness of all life in unequivocal terms.
('62', 236, 1, 7, 459303) The religions of mankind are being examined and tested both analytically and synthetically.
('62', 236, 1, 8, 459395) And I have no doubt that, if Hindus cling to untouchability, Hinduism and Hindus will be swept out of existence.
('62', 236, 1, 9, 459508) I cling to Hinduism because it gives me all the solace I need and because I have found in it no warrant for untouchability as we know it today.
('62', 236, 1, 10, 459652) If I have invited you to copy the virtues of Englishmen, I must with deference to English friends present here warn you against their vices.
('62', 236, 1, 11, 459793) That immortal poet–saint Tulsidas has left us a verse 1 full of deep truth.
('62', 236, 1, 12, 459869) He says that we should live even as the fabled swan does, sift virtue from vice and take the former, leaving the latter alone.
('62', 236, 1, 13, 459996) I would have you, therefore, to leave alone their two national vices, drink and races.
('62', 236, 1, 14, 460083) Many Englishmen de plore them.
('62', 236, 1, 15, 460114) I have seen many an English home being ruined by the craving for liquor and gambling at the races.
('62', 236, 1, 16, 460213) And so have many prin ces been ruined by them.
('62', 236, 1, 17, 460260) I hope that you will learn to shun these two evils.

('62', 240, 5, 8, 465691) 260. LET EVERY CASTE HINDU REMEMBER 1
('62', 240, 6, 9, 465729) That the following resolution was unanimously passed on his behalf by the meeting of his representatives held in Bombay on 15th September, 1931, Pandit Malaviyaji being in the Chair :
('62', 240, 7, 10, 465913) This Conference resolves that henceforth, amongst Hindus, no one shall be regarded as an untouchable by reason of his birth, and that those who have been so regarded hitherto will have the same right as other Hindus in regard to the use of public wells, public schools, roads and all other public institutions.
('62', 240, 7, 11, 466224) This right shall have statutory recognition at the first opportunity and shall be one of the earliest Acts of the Swaraj Parliament, if it shall not have received such recognition before that time.
('62', 240, 7, 12, 466422) It is further agreed that it shall be the duty of all Hindu leaders to secure, by every legitimate and peaceful means, an early removal of all social disabilities now imposed by custom upon the so–called untouchable classes, including the bar in respect of admission to temples.
('62', 240, 7, 13, 466701) Harijan, 1–12–1933
('62', 240, 8, 14, 466720) 261. NOTES
('62', 240, 9, 15, 466731) THE LATE LALA GANGARAM OF SIALKOT It was only through the kind offices of a friend that I came to learn of the recent death of Lala Gangaram.
('62', 240, 9, 16, 466873) He died on the 4th [November] of heart failure, at the age of 60. I had the privilege of meeting him in Lahore at the late Rambhajdutt Chowdhury’s house in 1919 when he was introduced to me as a thorough–going Harijan worker.
('62', 240, 9, 17, 467099) His was a life of dedication to the Harijan cause.
('62', 240, 9, 18, 467150) He was instrumental in founding Harijan colonies.
('62', 240, 9, 19, 467200) His death is a distinct loss to the cause.
('62', 240, 9, 20, 467243) I offer my condolences to the family of the deceased and to the Harijans who were under his special care.

('62', 241, 0, 1, 467488) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 242
('62', 241, 1, 2, 467530) AVOID WASTE Reception Committees have been encouraging the habit of presenting flower garlands and bouquets by everyone who will do so.
('62', 241, 1, 3, 467666) Such presentations are a waste of time and money in a tour undertaken on behalf of the lowliest.
('62', 241, 1, 4, 467763) If garlands must be presented, let them consist of undamaged strands of yarn which can be used for weaving.
('62', 241, 1, 5, 467871) There are Harijan weavers who are idle for want of hand– spun yarn.
('62', 241, 1, 6, 467939) These will not weave mill–spun yarn.
('62', 241, 1, 7, 467976) The best thing is to avoid all garlanding.
('62', 241, 1, 8, 468019) And where reception without garlanding is considered impossible, let the garlands be accompained by money.
('62', 241, 1, 9, 468126) The practice of accompanying garlands with money became a feature after Wun and it has already added a few hundred rupees to the amount of donations received.
('62', 241, 1, 10, 468285) Let the public note what one pice means in this country and in the hands of the hungry and despised.
('62', 241, 1, 11, 468386) It makes the dole that charity gives per head to the famishing in flood– stricken Orissa.
('62', 241, 1, 12, 468476) Let the doubters see the hovels in which the Harijans are living.
('62', 241, 1, 13, 468542) Let them visit the low–lying Harijan lane of Hinganghat, where in the rainy season it is hardly possible to exist.
('62', 241, 1, 14, 468657) They will then understand the value of the pice that goes into the pocket of a Harijan.
('62', 241, 1, 15, 468745) I would like the public to save their pice and give them to me for the sake of Harijans.
('62', 241, 1, 16, 468834) It will be part payment of the heavy debt caste Hindus owe to Harijans.

('62', 241, 2, 18, 468925) 262. SCHOOL BOOKS
('62', 241, 3, 19, 468943) There seems to me to be no doubt that in the public schools the books used, especially for children, are for the most part useless when they are not harmful.
('62', 241, 3, 20, 469101) That many of them are cleverly written cannot be denied.
('62', 241, 3, 21, 469158) They might even be the best for the people and the environment for which they are written.
('62', 241, 3, 22, 469249) But they are not written for Indian boys and girls, nor for the Indian environment.
('62', 241, 3, 23, 469333) When they are so written, they are generally undigested imitations hardly answering the wants of the scholars.
('62', 241, 3, 24, 469444) In this country, wants vary according to the provinces and the classes of children.
('62', 241, 3, 25, 469528) For instance, wants of Harijan children are, in the beginning stages at least, different from those of the others.
('62', 241, 3, 26, 469643) I have, therefore, come to the conclusion that books are required more for the teachers than for the taught.
('62', 241, 3, 27, 469752) And every teacher, if he is
('62', 242, 0, 1, 469780) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 243
('62', 242, 1, 2, 469827) to do full justice to his pupils, will have to prepare the daily lesson from the material available to him.
('62', 242, 1, 3, 469935) This, too, he will have to suit to the special requirements of his class.
('62', 242, 1, 4, 470009) Real education has to draw out the best from the boys and girls to be educated.
('62', 242, 1, 5, 470089) This can never be done by packing ill assorted and unwanted information into the heads of the pupils.
('62', 242, 1, 6, 470191) It becomes a dead weight crushing all originality in them and turning them into mere automata.
('62', 242, 1, 7, 470286) If we were not ourselves victims of the system, we would long ago have realized the mischief wrought by the modern method of giving mass education, especially in a case like India’s.
('62', 242, 1, 8, 470469) Attempts have undoubtedly been made by many institutions to produce their own text–books with more or less success.
('62', 242, 1, 9, 470585) But in my opinion they do not answer the vital needs of the country.
('62', 242, 1, 10, 470654) I lay no claim to originality for the views I have endeavoured to set forth here.
('62', 242, 1, 11, 470736) They are repeated here for the benefit of the managers and teachers of Harijan schools, who have a tremendous task before them.
('62', 242, 1, 12, 470864) They dare not be satisfied with mere mechanical work resulting in simply making the children under their charge indifferently and in a parrot–like manner learn the books chosen anyhow.
('62', 242, 1, 13, 471049) They have undertaken a great trust wich they must discharge courageously, intelligently and honestly.
('62', 242, 1, 14, 471151) The task is difficult enough but not so difficult as one would imagine, provided the teacher or the manager puts his whole heart into the work.
('62', 242, 1, 15, 471295) If he becomes a parent to his pupils, he will instinctively know what they need and set about giving it to them.
('62', 242, 1, 16, 471408) If he has it not to give, he will proceed to qualify himself.
('62', 242, 1, 17, 471470) And seeing that we have started with the idea that the boys and girls have to have instruction in accordance with their wants, no extraordinary cleverness or possession of external knowledge is required in a teacher of Harijan and, for that matter, any other children.
('62', 242, 1, 18, 471739) And when it is remembered that the primary aim of all education is, or should be, the moulding of the character of pupils, a teacher who has a character to keep need not lose heart.
('62', 242, 1, 19, 471921) Harijan, 1–12–1933

('62', 248, 1, 2, 482477) 270. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, JABALPUR
('62', 248, 2, 3, 482517) December 3, 1933 If this effort to abolish root and branch the distinctions of high and low succeeds, it will have a healthy reaction on all spheres of life, and the struggle between capital and labour will cease and give place to co–operation and concord between the two.
('62', 248, 2, 4, 482790) 1 If we have understood the full implications of this war against untouchability, we should have no difficulty in realizing that untouchability based on birth is only one of the countless phases of that curse.
('62', 248, 2, 5, 483000) We should thus be better serving the cause of freedom and communal unity that I have at heart.
('62', 248, 2, 6, 483095) My faith in the movement has grown from day to day.
('62', 248, 2, 7, 483147) I implicitly believe that, if we succeed in abolishing untouchability from Hinduism, all the quarrels between classes and communities that we see today in India will cease.
('62', 248, 2, 8, 483320) The differences between Hindus and Mussalmans and between capital and labour will be composed.
('62', 248, 2, 9, 483415) Once the hearts are purified, it will be found easy to overcome all difficulties in the way of a heart unity.
('62', 248, 2, 10, 483525) The phase we are at present dealing with does not exhaust all the possibilities of the struggle.
('62', 248, 2, 11, 483622) The untouchability as practised today in Hinduism is the worst of all the phases.
('62', 248, 2, 12, 483704) Masquerading under the name of religion, it has contributed most to the degradation of man by man.
('62', 248, 2, 13, 483803) I have said that untou chability is a many–headed monster and appears in many shapes and forms, some of them so subtle as not to be easily detected.
('62', 248, 2, 14, 483952) There are many degrees in untouchability.
('62', 248, 2, 15, 483994) I was conscious of all these im plications when I took up this war and made up my mind to devote my full energy, in the evening of my life, to this work.
('62', 248, 2, 16, 484148) All true scouts have my blessings.
('62', 248, 2, 17, 484183) 2 In my many wanderings over many parts of the world, I have come in contact with thousands of boy scouts.
('62', 248, 2, 18, 484290) True scouts are brave, considerate, courteous, and intelligent.
('62', 248, 2, 19, 484354) They should have a full sense of their duty.
('62', 248, 2, 20, 484399) They have been working to preserve order at the numerous fairs in the country where millions gather.
('62', 248, 2, 21, 484500) I would also like them to give a part of their time to the service of the Harijans.
('62', 248, 2, 22, 484584) Anyone who sees Harijan quarters with my eye will be convinced that there is ample scope for service for all who have the will and the capacity to do it.
('62', 248, 2, 23, 484738) It does not require extraordinary intelligence.
('62', 248, 2, 24, 484786) The only thing required is a sense of identification with the Harijans.
('62', 248, 3, 25, 484858) 1 In an address presented by the local labour union, it was asked why Gandhiji did not work for ameliorating the condition of labourers and protecting them against exploitation by capitalists.

('62', 249, 1, 2, 485157) There is no end of difficulties in the way, but there is not a single difficulty for which there is no remedy.

('62', 249, 1, 7, 485709) These conditions require a thorough observance of truth and non violence and the utmost sacrifices and sufferings.

('62', 252, 1, 2, 489402) 276. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, MANDLA1
('62', 252, 2, 3, 489441) December 6, 1933 I have said that those who come to these gatherings as an appreciation of my political services and not because they believe in removal of untouchability deceive themselves and me.
('62', 252, 2, 4, 489639) I invite only sympathizers and opponents to these meetings, the latter if they wish to signify their opposition.
('62', 252, 2, 5, 489752) I want you to be true to yourselves and reject me if you do not see eye to eye with me in this matter.
('62', 252, 2, 6, 489855) There are two sets of pundits who give opposite interpretations of Shastras.
('62', 252, 2, 7, 489932) The layman then has to make use of his Godgiven reason and choose between the two.
('62', 252, 2, 8, 490015) 2 Untouchability, I have found, appeals neither to the intellect nor to the heart.
('62', 252, 2, 9, 490098) The essential urge of the heart is towards compassion and sympathy for the sinner.
('62', 252, 2, 10, 490181) Temples are meant for sinners, where they can wash away their sins.
('62', 252, 2, 11, 490249) What is the use of temples to a liberated sinless soul, who sees God everywhere ?
('62', 252, 2, 12, 490331) If you believe that Harijans are in their present plight today as a result of their past sins, you must concede that they have the first right of worship in temples.
('62', 252, 2, 13, 490497) God has been described by all the scriptures of the world as a Protector and Saviour of the sinner.
('62', 252, 2, 14, 490597) There is untouchability in the Shastras in a particular sense.
('62', 252, 2, 15, 490660) Anger, lust and other evil passions raging in the heart are the real untouchables.
('62', 252, 2, 16, 490743) It is a prostitution of Shastras to interpret them as sanctioning the distinctions we observe today.
('62', 252, 2, 17, 490844) A true man of piety will consider himself a sinner and, therefore, untouchable.
('62', 252, 2, 18, 490924) We in our haughtiness have hitherto misinterpreted the Shastras and have raised a sin to the status of a religious tenet.
('62', 252, 2, 19, 491046) I claim to be a true sanatanist, because I make the greatest effort I can to live up to the truth as I see it.
('62', 252, 2, 20, 491157) Diversity there certainly is in the world, but it means neither inequality nor untouchability.
('62', 252, 2, 21, 491252) An elephant and an ant are dissimilar.
('62', 252, 2, 22, 491291) Nevertheless God has said that they are equal in His eyes.
('62', 252, 2, 23, 491350) The inner
('62', 252, 3, 24, 491360) 1 Earlier, the meeting was addressed by a sanatanist Swami with Gandhiji’s permission.
('62', 252, 3, 25, 491447) The burden of his speech was that the large gatherings came to pay homage to Gandhiji as a political leader and not because they accepted his views on untouchability.
('62', 252, 3, 26, 491614) 2 In the address presented there was a reference to the debate between Shankara, the reformer, and Mandanmisra, the formalist, which took place in Mahishmati, the ancient seat of learning, now Mandla.
('62', 253, 0, 1, 491815) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 254
('62', 253, 1, 2, 491857) oneness pervades all life.
('62', 253, 1, 3, 491884) The forms are many, but the informing spirit, is one.
('62', 253, 1, 4, 491938) How can there be room for distinctions of high and low where there is this all embracing fundamental unity underlying the outward diversity?

('62', 258, 5, 11, 501242) 284. SPEECH AT LEONARD THEOLOGICAL COLLEGE
('62', 258, 6, 12, 501285) JABALPUR, December 7, 1933 I, who believe in the equality of the great religions of the world and from my early days have learnt to honour other re ligions as my own, have no difficulty in inviting and taking the co operation to the followers of other religions in this movement.
('62', 258, 6, 13, 501565) It is part of my nature.
('62', 258, 6, 14, 501590) This is essentially a matter of repentance on the part of the so called higher classes.
('62', 258, 6, 15, 501678) They have to do re paration for the wrongs they have hitherto done to a portion of themselves on whose backs they have hitherto ridden.
('62', 258, 6, 16, 501814) It is an effort on the part of Hindu reformers to blot out this shame from the face of Hinduism.
('62', 258, 6, 17, 501911) I have not hesitated to say that either untouchability lives and Hinduism perishes, or untou chability goes and Hinduism rises purified.
('62', 258, 6, 18, 502048) It is a life and death struggle bet ween the darkness of superstition and the light of reform.
('62', 258, 6, 19, 502143) If this reform in Hinduism comes about, I have not the shadow of a doubt that it will be a service not only of all the communities of India but of the whole of humanity.
('62', 258, 6, 20, 502313) I am not thinking of achieving this reform by any form of compulsion, including legal.
('62', 258, 6, 21, 502400) It is said that, in trying to seek support for the two Bills now before the Assembly, I am really supporting a policy of legal compulsion.
('62', 258, 6, 22, 502539) I do not want to repeat here the whole argument against that contention; but I want to assure you that there is no compulsion in the Bills; and those who care to study them will endorse my opinion.
('62', 258, 6, 23, 502737) This must be a reform from within.
('62', 258, 6, 24, 502772) It is not a political movement.
('62', 258, 6, 25, 502804) I do not want to deny that it will have great political results, but I have never for a moment thought of achieving through this movement the political rise of the so called upper class Hindus.
('62', 258, 6, 26, 502998) It is to my mind a movement of downright purification.
('62', 259, 0, 1, 503053) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 260
('62', 259, 1, 2, 503095) Having made these introductory remarks, it is easy for me to tell you on what terms you can give your assistance to the movement.
('62', 259, 1, 3, 503225) You should work in co operation with and, if I may say it, in subordination to the Society that has been formed for suppression and eradication of untouchability, namely, the Servants of Untouchables Society.
('62', 259, 1, 4, 503434) That is to say, you should put your talents at the disposal of the Society.
('62', 259, 1, 5, 503510) I do not mean metallic talents.
('62', 259, 1, 6, 503542) These have to come from those who have to make repentance and reparation.
('62', 259, 1, 7, 503616) I have seen during the few days of my tour that millions are ready for the reform.
('62', 259, 1, 8, 503699) They can tangibly signify their support only by giving their coppers.
('62', 259, 1, 9, 503769) But men and women of intelligence are wanted to work for the Harijans in a variety of ways.
('62', 259, 1, 10, 503861) For the so called caste Hindus to serve the Harijans in a constructive manner is to get off their backs, to go down on their knees to them, to treat Harijan children as their own and Harijan men and women as blood brothers and sisters.
('62', 259, 1, 11, 504097) It is almost a superhuman task and cannot be done without Divine aid.
('62', 259, 1, 12, 504167) But Divine aid comes largely through human agency.
('62', 259, 1, 13, 504218) I confess that we have too few teachers and other professional men and women in our ranks.
('62', 259, 1, 14, 504309) We want to cope with the ever increasing demand.
('62', 259, 1, 15, 504358) I invite the aid of agencies like yours in this work.
('62', 259, 1, 16, 504412) You will now understand what I mean by subordination.
('62', 259, 1, 17, 504466) This is the right way.
('62', 259, 1, 18, 504489) But there is also the wrong way.
('62', 259, 1, 19, 504522) You may choose to work independently.
('62', 259, 1, 20, 504560) You may have the conversion of Harijans to Christianity.
('62', 259, 1, 21, 504617) You may see in the movement a chance for propaganda.
('62', 259, 1, 22, 504670) If you work among the Harijans with such an aim, you can see that the very end we have in view will be frustrated.
('62', 259, 1, 23, 504785) If you believe that Hinduism is a gift, not of God but of Satan, quite clearly you cannot accept my terms.
('62', 259, 1, 24, 504892) You and I would be dishonest if we did not make clear to one another what we stand for.

('62', 263, 4, 11, 509609) 293. SPEECH AT LABOURERS’ MEETING 1
('62', 263, 5, 12, 509645) DELHI, December 10, 1933
('62', 263, 6, 13, 509670) [Gandhiji] congratulated the organizers of his programme on the happy
('62', 263, 7, 14, 509740) beginning made with a visit to Harijan quarters and followed by the labourers
('62', 263, 8, 15, 509818) meeting.
('62', 263, 9, 16, 509827) Thanking them for the purse, the Mahatma said he knew that half the amount in the purse was contributed by the employer (Mr. G. D. Birla) and half by the labourers from the Labour Welfare Fund.
('62', 263, 9, 17, 510021) To present such a big sum was the work of rich persons and not of labourers, and besides this, most of them were Harijans and it did not behove him to take money from them to remove the curse of untouchability.
('62', 263, 9, 18, 510232) It was the duty of high caste Hindus like Mr. Birla to contribute money to wipe out untouchability,and he hesitated to accept money from Harijans, but all the same he accepted it, since they voulnteered it, but, added the Mahatma, he would have preferred it if the Harijans had given up liquor or smoking and contributed those savings for Harijan work.
('62', 263, 9, 19, 510585) The money thus contributed would have been more helpful in the noble mission.
('62', 263, 9, 20, 510663) He recalled, in this connection, the contribution raised by Bhopal students yesterday by raising a pie fund.
('62', 263, 10, 21, 510772) Continuing, the Mahatma said the Hindus, in patronizing the Harijan movement, were really doing a penance (prayashchitta) for their age long sins, and this penance must be sincere.
('62', 263, 10, 22, 510953) If they failed to do it, God alone knew what their fate would be.
('62', 263, 11, 23, 511019) 1 About 5,000 labourers and others attended the meeting held in the Birla Mills.
('62', 263, 11, 24, 511100) A purse of Rs. 2,000 and an address on a banana leaf were presented to Gandhiji.
('62', 263, 11, 25, 511181) He remarked : “The idea of presenting the address on a banana leaf is very good, but you should have given me some fruit to eat.” Soon after a basket of fruit was brought.
('62', 264, 0, 1, 511353) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 265
('62', 264, 1, 2, 511400) Referring to the Harijan reform work done in the Birla Mills, Mahatmaji said : It is no news to me that you have wiped out untouchability in the Birla Mills.
('62', 264, 1, 3, 511558) Ghanshyamdasji has merely paid the debt that he owed as a high caste Hindu to the Harijans and as a millowner to labourers.
('62', 264, 2, 4, 511682) It was the religious duty of every Hindu, be he a mill owner or poor man, to root out untouchability from this land.
('62', 264, 2, 5, 511799) In doing so, they were merely doing their duty and did not deserve any thanks.
('62', 264, 3, 6, 511878) Continuing, the Mahatma sounded a note of warning in the following words : Wipe out untouchability or Hinduism will be wiped out from the world.
('62', 264, 4, 7, 512023) Referring to some sanatanists, who did not agree with him in this reform movement, Mahatmaji said : I have tried my best to persuade sanatanists to my view and have given my best attention to their arguments, but they have failed to convince me by a single proof from the Shastras giving sanction to untouchability.
('62', 264, 5, 8, 512339) Continuing, the Mahatma appealed to the labourers to give up liquor, smoking and other evil practices and lead a pure life internally as well as externally.
('62', 264, 5, 9, 512496) He laid stress on God’s worship and added that faith in God alone could put an end to their sorrows.
('62', 264, 5, 10, 512597) He concluded with a prayer for the welfare of labourers, saying that he also regarded himself as a labourer by choice.
('62', 264, 5, 11, 512716) It was better to be a labourer than to be an employer.
('62', 264, 5, 12, 512771) (Cheers)
('62', 264, 6, 13, 512780) The Mahatma humorously remarked : I feel very much tempted to finish the fruit, but give it to Harijan children and they will reach me.
('62', 264, 7, 14, 512916) The Hindustan Times, 11 12 1933
('62', 264, 8, 15, 512948) 294. DISCUSSION WITH HARIJANS
('62', 264, 9, 16, 512978) DELHI, December 10, 1933
('62', 264, 10, 17, 513003) Q. Do you consider temple entry as the only way to solve our troubles ?
('62', 264, 10, 18, 513075) A. It is my firm belief that caste Hindus will not have fulfilled their obligations till they have opened all their temples to Harijans.
('62', 264, 10, 19, 513212) It is immaterial to me whether Harijans come to worship in those temples or not.
('62', 264, 10, 20, 513293) It is a matter of sheer justice and penance for caste Hindus.
('62', 264, 10, 21, 513355) It is repugnant to my sense of justice that Harijans should be excluded
('62', 265, 0, 1, 513427) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 266
('62', 265, 1, 2, 513469) from places of worship which are open to other Hindus.
('62', 265, 1, 3, 513524) I would not consider untouchability as having been eradicated, unless and until the bar against Harijans’ entry into temples is removed altogether.
('62', 265, 2, 4, 513672) Q. Will you not help us in our economic distress ?
('62', 265, 2, 5, 513723) To us economic uplift is the
('62', 265, 3, 6, 513752) chief thing.
('62', 265, 3, 7, 513765) A. The economic uplift has not been overlooked.
('62', 265, 3, 8, 513813) But I should not be satisfied if you were given crores of rupees and yet were still considered untouchables, or if palaces were built for you and you were still kept out of the pale of Hindu society.
('62', 265, 3, 9, 514013) I should be satisfied only when you are put on a par with caste Hindus in every respect.
('62', 265, 3, 10, 514102) Thus economic uplift is only one of the many items in our pro gramme.
('62', 265, 4, 11, 514172) Q. We should not conceal from you our misgivings about the money collected
('62', 265, 5, 12, 514247) by you being properly used for our welfare.
('62', 265, 5, 13, 514291) It depends upon your getting honest
('62', 265, 6, 14, 514327) workers to work out the scheme, of whom there are very few at present.
('62', 265, 6, 15, 514398) Would you not
('62', 265, 7, 16, 514412) then put the funds into our hands to be used according to our discretion ?
('62', 265, 7, 17, 514487) We must tell
('62', 265, 8, 18, 514500) you frankly we do not trust the present workers.
('62', 265, 8, 19, 514549) A. I do not mean to say that no Harijans can take part in the disbursement of the funds.
('62', 265, 8, 20, 514638) But as the whole reform is conceived as a matter of penance and reparation on the part of caste Hindus, they have to find the best way of using them.
('62', 265, 8, 21, 514788) They must be guided by the advice of Harijans, but the actual administration of the funds has to rest with them.
('62', 265, 8, 22, 514901) I may assure you that the least part of these funds will be spent for propaganda.
('62', 265, 8, 23, 514983) By far the greater part will go directly into the pockets of Harijans.
('62', 265, 8, 24, 515054) I have no reason to believe that all those who are doing Harijan service today are actuated by selfish motives.
('62', 265, 8, 25, 515166) There must be a few cases where workers are not as you and I would have them to be, but the majority have taken up this work in the proper spirit.
('62', 265, 8, 26, 515313) Many of them are of unimpeachable character and would do credit to any movement.
('62', 265, 8, 27, 515394) Apart from all this, however, I want you to visualize the conditions of thousands of Harijans who are so suppressed that they have fallen below the average standard of huma nity.
('62', 265, 8, 28, 515573) They are voiceless.
('62', 265, 8, 29, 515593) They consider themselves sub human.
('62', 265, 8, 30, 515629) In Orissa, some years back, 1 an old man came to me with a straw in his mouth.
('62', 265, 8, 31, 515708) I tried to awaken in him the sense that he was my equal as a human being.
('62', 265, 8, 32, 515782) Another Harijan came to me in Cochin all trembling
('62', 265, 9, 33, 515833) 1 In December 1927; vide ,”Our Shame and their Shame
('62', 266, 0, 1, 515886) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 267
('62', 266, 1, 2, 515933) with fear.
('62', 266, 1, 3, 515944) He was considered invisible in those parts and was afraid of coming into the world of touchables.
('62', 266, 1, 4, 516042) These people are a standing reproach to us.
('62', 266, 1, 5, 516086) In the work I am doing, I have these in mind.
('62', 266, 1, 6, 516132) This service, then, has been taken up, not so much to please Harijans as to discharge a peremptory obligation.
('62', 266, 1, 7, 516243) We want to wipe out our shame and to die in that effort if need be.
('62', 266, 1, 8, 516311) We are striving to the best of our ability to render you selfless service, but if Harijans do not accept it, I shall know that we are too late.
('62', 266, 1, 9, 516455) But the month’s experience convinces me that the vast majority gladly accept this service.
('62', 266, 1, 10, 516546) We do not wish to leave a single phase of your life untouched.
('62', 266, 1, 11, 516609) We approach you as servants and not as patrons.
('62', 266, 2, 12, 516657) Q. You have only added a new name ‘Harijan’ to the many names we already
('62', 266, 3, 13, 516730) Even this new name is significant of our separateness from the others.
('62', 266, 4, 14, 516801) this sense of separateness goes, in fact as well as in name, how are we to be satisfied ?
('62', 266, 4, 15, 516891) A. The name ‘Harijan’ was suggested by one of your own class.
('62', 266, 4, 16, 516953) Thousands have welcomed the name as a good substitute for the offensive names ‘untouchable’ and ‘avarna’.
('62', 266, 4, 17, 517059) So long as untoucha bility is not completely removed, a name to distinguish you from others will be required, and an inoffensive name is any day better than one that stinks in the nostrils.
('62', 266, 4, 18, 517249) When untouchability is gone and Harijans are merged into the Hindus, I do not know by what name— Harijan or Hindu—the whole community will choose to call itself, but till that day comes, distinguishing names will have to be used.
('62', 266, 4, 19, 517479) You should know that I have become a Harijan by choice and am trying to serve you as one of yourselves; and I am sure that the sevice will, in the end, be accepted by all Harijans, if I have offered it in a selfless spirit.
('62', 266, 4, 20, 517703) I would plead with you for a little more patience to see what is being done.
('62', 266, 4, 21, 517780) The Harijan Sevak Sangh has no other end in view but your good.
('62', 266, 5, 22, 517844) Harijan, 22 12 1933
('62', 266, 6, 23, 517864) 295. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI
('62', 266, 7, 24, 517906) DELHI, December 10, 1933
('62', 266, 8, 25, 517931) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, I got the letters of you both.
('62', 266, 8, 26, 517983) Which remarks of mine hurt so much ?
('62', 266, 8, 27, 518020) I don’t remember what I said to Kishorelal, but I have never
('62', 267, 0, 1, 518081) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 268
('62', 267, 1, 2, 518123) thought you timid or cowardly.
('62', 267, 1, 3, 518154) On the contrary, I have always been proud of your courage.But I do think that you are too dependent on others, that you do not have sufficient capacity to think for yourself.
('62', 267, 1, 4, 518329) But that is not your fault.
('62', 267, 1, 5, 518357) Partly it may be mine.
('62', 267, 1, 6, 518380) You have nothing to feel ashamed about.
('62', 267, 1, 7, 518420) I wrote a long letter to you by the last mail, from which you will be able to know clearly my views in this regard.

('62', 273, 1, 2, 528724) 304. DISCUSSION WITH SANATANISTS
('62', 273, 2, 3, 528757) DELHI, December 13, 1933 I claim to be a sanatanist as I consider my conduct to be in consonance with the spirit of the scriptures.
('62', 273, 2, 4, 528889) 1 You may, if you like, reject my claim.
('62', 273, 2, 5, 528930) I have studied the Shastras to the best of my ability and have arrived at the conclusion that untouchability is repugnant to the spirit of Hinduism.
('62', 273, 3, 6, 529079) They, however, contended that no one could be called sanatanist who did not believe in untouchability, shraddha, idol worship and other outward observances.
('62', 273, 4, 7, 529236) Gandhiji retorted that the only true test of sanatan dharma was the touchstone of truth.
('62', 273, 5, 8, 529325) He added that the outward observance was nothing if a man lived a crooked life.
('62', 273, 6, 9, 529405) did outward form avail to a man who was a drunkard, rake and gambler ?
('62', 273, 7, 10, 529476) When he was told that the attempt to have temples opened to Harijans was
('62', 273, 8, 11, 529549) bound to lead to bloodshed, he said that was practically impossible, as there was no
('62', 273, 9, 12, 529634) compulsion contemplated by anybody.
('62', 273, 9, 13, 529670) No temple was to be opened where the
('62', 273, 10, 14, 529707) overwhelming opinion of temple goers was not in favour of such opening.
('62', 273, 11, 15, 529779) Harijan, 22 12 1933
('62', 273, 12, 16, 529799) 305. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, ALIPUR
('62', 273, 13, 17, 529837) December 13, 1933 I would ask you to believe me when I say that there is no political motive behind my Harijan work.
('62', 273, 13, 18, 529954) The political consequences of the removal of untouchability have no attraction for me.
('62', 273, 13, 19, 530041) Indeed, I believe that, if we approached this question with a political motive, we should fail to serve the Harijans and we should damage Hinduism.
('62', 273, 13, 20, 530189) That real removal of untouchability will have political consequences is true enough.
('62', 273, 13, 21, 530274) A duty religiously performed carries with it many other important consequences.
('62', 273, 13, 22, 530354) ‘Seek ye first the Kingdom of God and everything else will be added unto you’, is to my mind a scientific truth.
('62', 273, 13, 23, 530467) I must remind you of the pledge given last year in your name.
('62', 273, 14, 24, 530529) 1 The sanatanists had contended that Gandhiji had no right to call himself a sanatanist.
('62', 274, 0, 1, 530618) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 275
('62', 274, 1, 2, 530665) You will remember that a meeting of representatives of Hinduism was held in Bombay in September last year, Pandit Malaviyaji being in the chair.
('62', 274, 1, 3, 530810) Among other things they resolved that untouchability, being a blot on the Hindu religion, had to be removed and that Harijans were entitled to the same public utilities, and in the same manner, as caste Hindus.
('62', 274, 1, 4, 531021) There was in that Resolution a special reference to Hindu temples, and legislation was contemplated if it was found to be necessary for attaining the end.
('62', 274, 1, 5, 531176) It is, therefore, the bounden duty of every caste Hindu to fulfil the pledge by throwing open to the Harijans temples, well and other institutions precisely on the same terms as they are open to caste Hindus.
('62', 274, 2, 6, 531385) The Hindustan Times, 14 12 1933
('62', 274, 3, 7, 531417) 306. DISCUSSION AT SERVANTS OF UNTOUCHABLES SOCIETY MEETING 1
('62', 274, 4, 8, 531479) DELHI, December 13, 1933
('62', 274, 5, 9, 531504) Regarding the utilization of collections made during the tour Mahatma Gandhi
('62', 274, 6, 10, 531581) said that 75 percent of these collections would be spent in the locality concerned so
('62', 274, 7, 11, 531667) far as possible provided a suitable scheme was prepared and approved by the Central
('62', 274, 8, 12, 531751) The Provincial Boards should, however, not neglect their ordinary collections
('62', 274, 9, 13, 531829) in the hope of getting money out of his collections.
('62', 274, 9, 14, 531882) He stressed : You dare not utilize any part of these collections for propa ganda or office administration.
('62', 274, 9, 15, 531989) They can be utilized to the single pie for constructive work alone.
('62', 274, 9, 16, 532057) I am not touring India to finance your offices or to help your propaganda but to raise money enough for constructive work alone.
('62', 274, 9, 17, 532186) You should collect money separately to meet the expenses of your office administration.
('62', 274, 9, 18, 532274) If you do work out of the funds that I raise, the money paid by the public would be returned to them hundredfold.
('62', 274, 9, 19, 532388) It should, therefore, be zealously guarded and cautiously spent.
('62', 274, 10, 20, 532453) Asked as to what opinion he could express about the work done so far, Mahatma Gandhi replied : You cannot get any compliments if you want to get them.
('62', 274, 10, 21, 532604) But I can say that you could have done the work much better and as for the future I can only say that you should do better than in the past.
('62', 274, 11, 22, 532745) 1 Gandhiji had addressed the Central Board of the Society.
('62', 275, 0, 1, 532804) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 276
('62', 275, 1, 2, 532846) Regarding the question of democratization of the constitution of the Society, Mahatma Gandhi said that the present constitution should be worked democratically rather than bringing in a constitution demorcratic in form but autocratic in spirit.
('62', 275, 2, 3, 533091) His Holiness Garmuria Gosain of Assam and Mr. D. N. Sharma explained that ex tea garden coolies belonged to various provincess of India and were mostly Harijans.
('62', 275, 2, 4, 533253) Their population in Assam was 10,50,000 out of whom only 5,000 were literate.
('62', 275, 2, 5, 533331) They were commonly addicted to liquor or other such vices.
('62', 275, 2, 6, 533390) They had been economically exploited by Kabulis and Marwaris.
('62', 275, 3, 7, 533452) Mahatma Gandhi said that he knew about this deplorable state.
('62', 275, 3, 8, 533514) It is a social problem but to me it seems that the harvest is ready but the labourers are few.
('62', 275, 3, 9, 533609) We require workers to solve this question.
('62', 275, 3, 10, 533652) It cannot be solved by law.
('62', 275, 3, 11, 533680) It requires work in the midst of these people from day to day without expectation of immediate result.
('62', 275, 3, 12, 533783) It would be better to prepare statistics of these men by provinces so that a way might be found out to invite workers from other provinces to go there and work.
('62', 275, 3, 13, 533944) Money alone will not give the kind of workers required.
('62', 275, 3, 14, 534000) If I succeed in reaching Assam I will study the conditions and try to raise some local workers.
('62', 275, 3, 15, 534096) If I fail in this, I would have no doubt that Assam is the most backward of all provinces.
('62', 275, 3, 16, 534187) The question is, however, not only of untouchability but of a different type, but if Assam produces the proper type of workers there will be no difficulty in getting funds enough for carrying on that work.
('62', 275, 3, 17, 534393) The Hindustan Times, 16 12 1933
('62', 275, 4, 18, 534425) 307. SPEECH AT STUDENTS ’ MEETING, DELHI 1
('62', 275, 5, 19, 534468) December 13, 1933 It is no exaggeration to say that our relations were as intimate as between blood brothers.
('62', 275, 5, 20, 534578) 2 His burning patriotism, his great sacrifice and his unsurpassable love for his children, whom also he gave to the service of the motherland, ought to be as patent to you as they were to me.
('62', 275, 5, 21, 534770) I had the good fortune to be in the closest touch with him ever since I first knew him up to the moment of his death; and I could see that every moment of his life his thoughts were given to the nation he served so singularly.
('62', 275, 5, 22, 534997) To him swaraj was no distant dream; it was his very life breath.

('62', 277, 1, 6, 538017) To this they would not agree, unless I would first accept their demands.
('62', 277, 1, 7, 538090) My effort having failed, I tried every other resource at my disposal to achieve real unity and hopelessly failed.

('62', 277, 1, 11, 538537) Political unity was desired for a political end which for me, as for any Indian be he Hindu, Muslim, Christian or any other, could only be complete national independence in the fullest sense of the term.
('62', 277, 1, 12, 538741) Muslim demands were presented for arriving at common action.
('62', 277, 1, 13, 538802) Muslim friends in London were playing other minorities against the vital national interest.
('62', 277, 1, 14, 538894) If they accepted me as their ally, as I offered to be in uttermost sincerity, my alliance could only be for combating every force that was inimical to India’s freedom.
('62', 277, 1, 15, 539062) It was, therefore, necessary to fight the spirit of separateness, no matter from what source it arose.
('62', 277, 1, 16, 539165) No Muslim had defended separate electorates as a thing good in itself.

('62', 277, 1, 18, 539347) The doctrine, therefore, did not admit of indefinite extension.
('62', 277, 1, 19, 539411) The demand put forth on behalf of the so called untouchables was clearly anti national.

('62', 277, 1, 22, 539786) But I hold that my resistance was not only not ‘inhuman’ but it was conceived in the best interests of the Harijans.

('62', 278, 1, 3, 540111) Evidently Sir Mohammed Iqbal has had no time to follow what I have done or am doing in this behalf.
('62', 278, 1, 4, 540211) Had he even cursorily followed my doings, he would not have allowed himself to say, as he has said, that “Mr. Gandhi has made it a mission of his life to prevent the fusion of the untouchables with the other communities and to retain them in the fold of Hinduism without any real fusion between them and even the caste Hindus.” He should know that the rooting out of untouchability is the aim of my life which I have persued without interruption for the past fifty years and that I have claimed and am fighting for the same rights without reservation for the Harijans that the caste Hindus have in matters religious, social and political.
('62', 278, 1, 5, 540850) My work about Harijans is purely religious.

('62', 278, 1, 8, 540997) It is a movement of internal reform in Hinduism.

('62', 281, 3, 8, 547207) 311. WHAT I SAW IN ANANTPUR
('62', 281, 4, 9, 547235) Anantpur is a little village in Saugor District, C. P. (Hindi), containing 177 houses with a population, therefore, roughly of 885. It is 35 miles from the nearest railway station.
('62', 281, 4, 10, 547416) It has no Post or Telegraph Office.
('62', 281, 4, 11, 547452) There is a weekly service from the nearest Post Office, Relly, 12 miles from Anantpur.
('62', 281, 4, 12, 547539) It is a typically poor village of poor India.
('62', 281, 4, 13, 547585) The villagers are occupied not more than four months in the year.
('62', 281, 4, 14, 547651) There was hardly any supplementary occupation for the villagers as a whole before an event that happened four years ago.
('62', 281, 4, 15, 547772) It was in 1929 that a young man, with a single minded zeal rarely surpassed, chose Anantpur for his experiment, after a year’s travelling in search of such a village.
('62', 281, 4, 16, 547939) He is khaddar mad.
('62', 281, 4, 17, 547958) He believes in the message of khaddar even as much as perhaps I do.
('62', 281, 4, 18, 548026) I doubt if he would not replace ‘perhaps’ by ‘if not more than’.
('62', 281, 4, 19, 548091) I would submit to his correction, if he made it.
('62', 281, 4, 20, 548140) His faith in himself would put to shame the tallest among us.
('62', 281, 4, 21, 548202) He believes that the only permanent cure for the enforced idleness of the peasantry of India and their consequent chronic poverty is the universal adoption of the spinning wheel.
('62', 281, 4, 22, 548381) His name is Jethalal Govindjee.
('62', 281, 4, 23, 548413) He does not know English.
('62', 281, 4, 24, 548439) He is no Gujarati scholar.
('62', 281, 4, 25, 548466) Himself a town bred man, by dogged pertinacity he has inured himself to the hardships of village life and lives like, and in the midst of, villagers.
('62', 281, 4, 26, 548616) He has three companions with him.
('62', 281, 4, 27, 548650) He is a thorough believer in one thing at a time and, therefore, will not pursue other social service, no matter how tempting it may be.
('62', 281, 4, 28, 548787) If the spinning wheel is well established in every cottage, he thinks that all the other problems that puzzle and drag down villagers will solve themselves.
('62', 281, 4, 29, 548944) He will say : ‘I shan’t preach temperance or thrift to the villager, for no drunkard will take to the wheel if he will not give up his drink, and to preach thrift to a pauper is a mockery.
('62', 281, 4, 30, 549133) It will be time
('62', 282, 0, 1, 549149) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 283
('62', 282, 1, 2, 549196) to preach it, when I have put a few coppers in his pocket.
('62', 282, 1, 3, 549255) Since I believe that every revolution of the wheel will mean a revolution in his daily life, I am going to be patient with his vices and many drawbacks.
('62', 282, 1, 4, 549408) And I have faith that, if I am a clean man, my cleanness cannot but touch both the inside and the outside of the villager.’ With varying fortunes, but with an unvarying faith, he and his companions have plodded for the past four years.
('62', 282, 1, 5, 549644) Their formula is Self dependence writ large.
('62', 282, 1, 6, 549689) Khadi must support itself.
('62', 282, 1, 7, 549716) The way to make it do so is for the villagers to spin, and weave too if possible, for their own use.
('62', 282, 1, 8, 549817) They may sell only the surplus, as they do with the grain they grow.
('62', 282, 1, 9, 549886) No cloth can be cheaper than that spun and woven in one’s home, even as no bread can be cheaper than home baked from grain grown in one’s own field and ground in one’s own home.
('62', 282, 1, 10, 550064) The business of these servants of the villagers is merely to instruct and help.
('62', 282, 1, 11, 550144) They visit every cottage and offer to teach them ginning, spinning, carding, weaving and dyeing.
('62', 282, 1, 12, 550241) They improve their wheels and manufacture new ones for sale only from the material available in the village.
('62', 282, 1, 13, 550350) This has given extra work to the village carpenter and the village blacksmith.
('62', 282, 1, 14, 550429) Every item is well thought out.
('62', 282, 1, 15, 550461) They have an almost complete record of the condition of every cottage and its dwellers.
('62', 282, 1, 16, 550549) They have made a fairly accurate study of the villagers’ wants and woes, customs and manners, and have published their report in Hindi.
('62', 282, 1, 17, 550685) Their workshop is a busy hive.
('62', 282, 1, 18, 550716) Work is being done in a neat and methodical manner.

('62', 282, 1, 20, 550859) I have mentioned only four foundation workers.
('62', 282, 1, 21, 550906) Needless to say they have raised workers in seventeen villages they are serving within a five mile radius of Anantpur.

('62', 282, 1, 24, 551133) I may not omit to mention that the Harijans have been found to be the readiest to take to the message.

('62', 282, 1, 26, 551296) There was no ventilation in them worth mentioning, no boxes, hardly any metal pots.

('62', 284, 1, 3, 554076) I have known nothing simpler, cheaper and yet more effective than this experiment of village uplift through khaddar.

('62', 284, 3, 6, 554331) 312. THINGS TO REMEMBER
('62', 284, 4, 7, 554355) During the past month of touring there has been a great deal of waste of time, a great deal of anxiety to the organizers and a great and unnecessary strain on my very limited physical resources, owing to the mad rush made towards the passing car.
('62', 284, 4, 8, 554602) I cannot recall occasions when people near me have not trodden on my naked toes or scratched my legs.
('62', 284, 4, 9, 554704) God has saved me from serious injury hitherto.
('62', 284, 4, 10, 554751) But the crowds can take no credit for the immunity.
('62', 284, 4, 11, 554803) Their affection is mad.
('62', 284, 4, 12, 554827) And madness can do nobody any good.
('62', 284, 4, 13, 554863) The thing can be easily managed if the volunteers will act in a business like manner and will not themselves, like crowds, go mad as they often do.
('62', 284, 4, 14, 555011) People cannot be instructed on anything all of a sudden.
('62', 284, 4, 15, 555068) Leaflets containing detailed instructions should, therefore, be issued to the public and read and explained to them by volunteers as they come to the venue of meetings.
('62', 284, 4, 16, 555237) The very best arrangement of the kind was made at Harda.
('62', 284, 4, 17, 555294) Although the party was taken through a crowded and decorated bazaar, it took no more than ten minutes to pass through.
('62', 284, 4, 18, 555413) In other places the same distance has often taken more than half an hour.
('62', 284, 4, 19, 555487) Success at Harda was due not merely to previous preparations, but also to volunteers with one continuous rope held by them being posted at regular intervals, thus making it impossible for anyone to break through the lines.
('62', 284, 4, 20, 555710) Let me now without further comment tabulate the instructions which I suggest for general adoption.
('62', 284, 4, 21, 555809) (1) Leaflets containing detailed instructions should be issued to the villagers in simple language easily to be understood by them.
('62', 284, 4, 22, 555941) These should be read to the parties as they stream in from villages.
('62', 284, 4, 23, 556010) (2) Crowds that gather at stations awaiting my arrival should stand in rows upon rows without causing inconvenience to the passengers and without moving from their places when the train steams in.
('62', 285, 0, 1, 556207) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 286
('62', 285, 1, 2, 556249) (3) A few minutes before the arrival time, volunteers should be posted in front of the crowd with a continuous rope, held waist high in their hands in order to avoid the people behind unconsciously moving towards me and the train.
('62', 285, 1, 3, 556480) (4) Volunteers should on no account fall prostrate before me.
('62', 285, 1, 4, 556542) (5) Volunteers should never lead or take part in the various cries.
('62', 285, 1, 5, 556610) Apart from its interfering with efficient service, their leading or participating in them robs the cries of spontaneity.
('62', 285, 1, 6, 556731) (6) Volunteers should not shout their instructions to the public, but should pronounce them with deliberation and gentleness.
('62', 285, 1, 7, 556857) Only one volunteer detailed for the purpose should pronounce them.
('62', 285, 1, 8, 556924) (7) The public should be requested not to crowd round the cars.
('62', 285, 1, 9, 556988) (8) Volunteers should not board my or any other car, except when asked to do so by a responsible member of the Reception Committee.
('62', 285, 1, 10, 557120) (9) The public should not gather at the stations which I may be passing through between 8 p.
('62', 285, 1, 11, 557213) and 6 a.
('62', 285, 1, 12, 557222) m., and in no case should they shout the usual cries at night.
('62', 285, 1, 13, 557285) Such shouting during night betrays want of consideration for the passengers and the party whom they profess to respect.
('62', 285, 1, 14, 557405) (10) Those who gather at stations whether by day or night would do well to remember that I am not conducting a tour for receiving addresses.
('62', 285, 1, 15, 557546) It is intended to be wholly a call for self purification, an invitation to the so called high class Hindus to repent of the wrong done by them to Harijans and for making collections on behalf of the cause.
('62', 285, 1, 16, 557752) Therefore, those who gather at the stations are naturally expected to bring or collective donations for Harijan service.
('62', 285, 2, 17, 557873) Harijan, 15 12 1933

('62', 289, 1, 2, 562959) 319. DISCUSSION WITH A SANATANIST 1
('62', 289, 2, 3, 562995) [Before December 16, 1933] You should realize that there are shastris who claim to be sana tanists and who support the reformers’ contention.
('62', 289, 2, 4, 563137) How am I to reject their testimony as false?
('62', 289, 2, 5, 563182) They fortify me in my opinion that untouchability has no sanction in the shastras.
('62', 289, 2, 6, 563265) I do believe in the Vedas, the Upanishads, the Smritis and the Puranas.
('62', 289, 2, 7, 563337) But to me the Gita is the key to a knowledge of the Shastras.
('62', 289, 2, 8, 563399) It enunciates the principles on which all conduct must be based.
('62', 289, 2, 9, 563464) It sums up the whole of the Shastras and, therefore, absolves laymen from having to explore the other books.
('62', 289, 2, 10, 563573) But I go a step further.
('62', 289, 2, 11, 563598) The Vedas are not the four books known as such.
('62', 289, 2, 12, 563646) They contain only fragments of the originals.
('62', 289, 2, 13, 563692) Eternal truth cannot be buried in or confined to printed books.
('62', 289, 2, 14, 563756) The Vedas are, therefore, indefinable and unwritten.
('62', 289, 2, 15, 563809) They reside in one’s heart.
('62', 289, 2, 16, 563837) And our Shastras tell us what discipline and study are necessary for opening out the heart for receiving the truth.
('62', 289, 2, 17, 563953) One’s experience, therefore, must be the final guide.
('62', 289, 2, 18, 564007) The written word undoubtedly helps, but even that has to be interpreted and, when there are conflicting interpretations, the seeker is the final arbiter.
('62', 289, 2, 19, 564161) I had to make my choice.
('62', 289, 2, 20, 564186) Years ago I made it and came to the conclusion that the Shastras did not countenance untouchability as we practise it today.
('62', 289, 3, 21, 564311) Harijan, 22 12 1933
('62', 289, 4, 22, 564331) 320. SPEECH AT HARIJAN WORKERS’ MEETING
('62', 289, 5, 23, 564371) VIJAYAWADA, December 16, 1933
('62', 289, 6, 24, 564401) It gave him great pleasure, [Gandhiji] said, to have met them all and witnessed the evidences of their literary powers.
('62', 289, 6, 25, 564521) He had always known, he said, that the people of Andhradesha were good at composing poems and rendering them sweetly and as such he could not help feeling that the recitations witnessed that evening were to some extent useless.
('62', 289, 6, 26, 564749) Poetry and art should be the vehicle of truth and never be utilized for flattery.
('62', 289, 6, 27, 564831) For, such a use of poetry would not only make for degeneration of the art but would also be a violation of truth.
('62', 289, 6, 28, 564945) Now that they were all engaged in a movement for the purification of Hinduism, he expected everyone so engaged to tread the path of
('62', 289, 7, 29, 565077) 1 Who met Gandhiji on the way to Vijayawada, formerly known as Bezwada.
('62', 289, 7, 30, 565149) Gandhiji reached there on December 16.
('62', 290, 0, 1, 565188) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 291
('62', 290, 1, 2, 565235) He had great expectations of Andhradesh and he knew she could rise equal to them.
('62', 290, 2, 3, 565317) Be you caste Hindu or Harijan, let what contribution you are making to the Harijan cause be absolutely unalloyed.
('62', 290, 2, 4, 565431) There can be no room for selfishness, hypocrisy, untruth and violence in such a movement.
('62', 290, 2, 5, 565521) As a religious movement it ought to touch the hearts of Harijans and savarnas alike.
('62', 290, 2, 6, 565606) For hundreds of years considerations of high and low have gone deep into our hearts.
('62', 290, 2, 7, 565691) Religious weapons alone kill untouchability.
('62', 290, 2, 8, 565736) An array of Hindu saints and sages have taught us that penance was the only way to protect and purify religion.
('62', 290, 2, 9, 565848) Needless to say that there can be place for selfishness and egoism in a penance.
('62', 290, 2, 10, 565929) I hope and pray that those engaged in Harijan service will be guided by the purest of motives.
('62', 290, 3, 11, 566024) He appealed to all those savarnas and avarnas who were engaged in this work to realize the paramount importance of self purification and to look upon this work as a shuddhiyajna.
('62', 290, 4, 12, 566203) Mr. Shambu Sastri asked if Gandhiji accepted the authority of the Vedas.
('62', 290, 4, 13, 566276) Most certainly.
('62', 290, 5, 14, 566292) You respect them and abide by them?
('62', 290, 5, 15, 566328) Certainly.
('62', 290, 6, 16, 566339) The next question was whether he would accept the position that Harijans if admitted to temples should also abide by the injunctions of Shastras by which temples were regulated.
('62', 290, 6, 17, 566517) All Shastric rules that apply to savarnas when observed by Harijans must enable them to get entry into temples.
('62', 290, 7, 18, 566629) All my past and present actions have been in accordance with religion as I have understood it.
('62', 290, 7, 19, 566724) I have no doubt that the present endeavour for the removal of untouchability has Vedic authority behind it.
('62', 290, 7, 20, 566832) I must, however, admit that there are two schools of thought on this question.
('62', 290, 7, 21, 566911) Both claim to be sanatanists and base their opinions on the Hindu scriptures.
('62', 290, 7, 22, 566989) I hold that those who are conducting this drive against untouchability as a religious movement must treat their opponents
('62', 290, 8, 23, 567111) 1 What follows is from The Bombay Chronicle.

('62', 291, 3, 8, 567788) 321. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, VIJAYAWADA

('62', 291, 5, 10, 567848) After apologizing for his inability to make himself heard by them all, Gandhiji acknowledged with thanks the several addresses presented to him and their monetary accompaniments.
('62', 291, 5, 11, 568027) But would it not have been better if all the purses had been pooled into one ?

('62', 293, 1, 2, 571662) 323. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU” 1
('62', 293, 2, 3, 571694) SIDDHANTHAM, December 17, 1933
('62', 293, 3, 4, 571725) May I ask a few questions on some points that strike me as worthy of being brought to your notice ?
('62', 293, 3, 5, 571825) [GANDHIJI :] Most certainly, I am ready.
('62', 293, 3, 6, 571866) Go ahead.
('62', 293, 4, 7, 571876) In a recent meeting which he addressed in Madras Mr. M. K. Acharya has stated that 95 per cent of the Harijan do not want ‘ the Gandhian creed‘.
('62', 293, 4, 8, 572021) What is your view on the matter ?
('62', 293, 4, 9, 572055) I do not know what ‘the Gandhian creed’ is.
('62', 293, 4, 10, 572099) If I do not know it, how do the Harijans know it or Mr. Acharya himself?
('62', 293, 4, 11, 572172) I do not claim anything special to me.
('62', 293, 4, 12, 572211) There is no such thing as ‘Gandhian creed’ so far as I know.
('62', 293, 4, 13, 572272) I know only this.
('62', 293, 4, 14, 572290) I am engaged in giving Harijans clean water.
('62', 293, 4, 15, 572335) I am engaged in giving them facilities for education.
('62', 293, 4, 16, 572389) I am engaged in finding accommodation for them in public caravanserais where they cannot get it.
('62', 293, 4, 17, 572486) I am engaged in weaning them from drink and carrion.
('62', 293, 4, 18, 572539) Do they not like all these?
('62', 293, 4, 19, 572567) I am engaged in teaching them the elementary rules of hygiene.
('62', 293, 4, 20, 572630) Do they not want it ?
('62', 293, 4, 21, 572652) I am engaged in telling them what the fundamentals of Hinduism are and in having public temples thrown open to them.
('62', 293, 4, 22, 572769) Mark the distinction.
('62', 293, 4, 23, 572791) They may not want to enter these temples and if somebody said that they do not want to, I will not be able to prove conclusively to the contrary, though the prima facie evidence that I have is all in my favour.
('62', 293, 4, 24, 573002) Whenever they find temples are thrown open to them, they are simply delirious with joy, as I found them to be today when I opened two temples 2 and entered them with them.
('62', 293, 4, 25, 573174) I do not care whether they want to go to the temples or no.
('62', 293, 4, 26, 573234) I simply feel that savarnas should do their duty.
('62', 293, 4, 27, 573284) There is nothing ‘Gandhian’ about it.
('62', 293, 4, 28, 573322) Every Hindu who believes that untouchability must go must understand this work.
('62', 293, 5, 29, 573402) It was observed by another person that Gandhiji being a believer in varnas hrama, which was but a graded system of untouchability, he was not qualified to tackle this problem.
('62', 293, 5, 30, 573578) What do you think of this view ?
('62', 293, 5, 31, 573611) For me varnashrama does not mean a graded system of untouchability.
('62', 293, 5, 32, 573679) I have explained what I mean by varnadharma.
('62', 293, 5, 33, 573724) It does
('62', 293, 6, 34, 573732) 1 Its special correspondent met Gandhiji in the afternoon.
('62', 293, 6, 35, 573791) 2 Vide the preceding item.
('62', 294, 0, 1, 573818) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 295
('62', 294, 1, 2, 573865) not mean to me grades at all.
('62', 294, 1, 3, 573895) It is not a vertical division.
('62', 294, 1, 4, 573926) It is a hori zontal one.
('62', 294, 1, 5, 573951) In my view, all varnas stand absolutely on the same plane, i.e., of equality.
('62', 294, 1, 6, 574029) Hence there can be no question of untouchability.
('62', 294, 1, 7, 574079) Varnadharma is a mighty economic law which, if we subscribe to it, would save us from the catastrophe that is in store for the world.
('62', 294, 1, 8, 574213) I have sufficient warrant in Hindu scriptures for saying that Brahmins and scavengers are absolutely on a par in the eyes of God.
('62', 294, 2, 9, 574343) It has been suggested in some quarters that the Harijan movement is a form of
('62', 294, 3, 10, 574421) civil resistance propaganda and that by this tour you are promoting civil resistance.
('62', 294, 4, 11, 574507) What is your opinion on this suggestion ?
('62', 294, 4, 12, 574549) Then I am between two crossfires.
('62', 294, 4, 13, 574583) Congressmen accuse me of having damaged the cause of civil disobedience by taking up this whirlwind campaign.
('62', 294, 4, 14, 574693) Those who suspect me of ulterior motives accuse me of strengthening civil disobedience.
('62', 294, 4, 15, 574781) I am unmoved by these charges or insinuations, and can only re declare that I have absolutely no ulterior motive.
('62', 294, 4, 16, 574895) It is a peremptory religious call which I am obeying.
('62', 294, 4, 17, 574949) The tens of thousands who attend the meetings do not even hear the expression ‘civil resistance’ from my lips.
('62', 294, 4, 18, 575060) This is purely a religious revival.
('62', 294, 4, 19, 575096) This does not mean that I have changed my views on civil resistance.
('62', 294, 4, 20, 575165) The very science of civil resistance demands absolute honesty.
('62', 294, 4, 21, 575228) If I use this campaign for furthering civil resistance, I should be guilty of dishonesty.
('62', 294, 4, 22, 575318) Civil disobedience does not need such dubious aids.
('62', 294, 5, 23, 575370) What do you think of the progress of Harijan uplift work in the provinces you have toured so far ?
('62', 294, 5, 24, 575469) My impressions are altogether happy and, if they are continued in the other provinces, I would have no hesitation in saying that untouchability is fast dying out.
('62', 294, 5, 25, 575632) On no other basis can I account for the tens of thousands of people who flock to the meetings and give me their coppers, well knowing what these are to be used for.
('62', 294, 6, 26, 575797) The Hindu, 18 12 1933
('62', 294, 7, 27, 575819) 324. SPEECH AT MASULIPATAM
('62', 294, 8, 28, 575846) December 17, 1933
('62', 294, 9, 29, 575864) Replying to the addresses and acknowledging the purses and other presents,
('62', 294, 10, 30, 575939) Gandhiji said that on reaching Masulipatam his first thought was of Dr. Pattabhi
('62', 294, 11, 31, 576020) Sitaramayya.
('62', 294, 11, 32, 576033) He was sure the Doctor’s spirit was pervading at the meeting though he
('62', 295, 0, 1, 576104) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 296
('62', 295, 1, 2, 576146) was not physically present in their midst.
('62', 295, 1, 3, 576189) He thanked the District and Taluk Boards
('62', 295, 2, 4, 576230) and the people of the district for the work they were doing on behalf of the Harijans.
('62', 295, 2, 5, 576317) But he felt that so long as there was even a single temple which admitted savarnas but
('62', 295, 3, 6, 576404) remained closed to Harijans, which benefited the former but did not equally benefit the
('62', 295, 4, 7, 576492) latter, there would be no rest for him nor should there be any for them.
('62', 295, 4, 8, 576565) If distinction
('62', 295, 5, 9, 576580) of high and low, touchable and untouchable continued amongst Hindus, he was sure
('62', 295, 6, 10, 576661) Hinduism would slowly die out.
('62', 295, 7, 11, 576692) We shall dig our own grave if we do not purge ourselves of this curse of untouchability, we shall have to pay with bitter tears if we in our pride miss the God given opportunity today.
('62', 295, 7, 12, 576877) We should have no peace till this monster is buried and those whom we have hitherto kept under our heels are put on a par with us in every respect.
('62', 295, 7, 13, 577025) Let us awake to the sense of this sin and save, before it is too late, ourselves and our religion from going to perdition.
('62', 295, 8, 14, 577148) The Hindu, 18 12 1933, and Harijan, 29 12 1933

('62', 303, 4, 11, 589004) MR. MAYOR, COUNCILLORS AND FRIENDS, I deeply appreciate the honour you have done me this morning by presenting me for the second time with an address.
('62', 303, 4, 12, 589155) 1 It is always a matter of great pleasure to me to visit the South because, as you know, I have relations with the South of a very long stand ing.
('62', 303, 4, 13, 589302) I came in closest touch with the indentured Indian people in Natal as early as 1893 and some of you may recollect that my first contact in Natal was not only with the South Indians but with the Tamil Indians, and the very first case of distress that I had the good fortune to handle was one in connection with a Tamil.
('62', 303, 4, 14, 589621) 1 Ever since that the South has bound me with ties not to be surpassed by any other part of India.
('62', 303, 4, 15, 589720) You, Sir, may not know, but some of the Councillors and some of the other citizens will perhaps recall the fact that when I first had the honour of receiving an address at the hands of this great Corporation, among the several names that I registered for myself was that of an expert scavenger.
('62', 303, 4, 16, 590015) It was at that time that I referred to the condition of your public streets and how those streets were used for insanitary purposes, even by men who should know better.
('62', 303, 4, 17, 590184) I expect that there has been a vast improvement in that direction.
('62', 303, 4, 18, 590251) But today my mission of scavenging is of a special character, a deeper character and, as I found it, of a purely religious character, taking religion in its broadest sense, not in the narrow sectional sense in which we, at the present day, unfortunately use the term.
('62', 303, 4, 19, 590519) The reform I am aiming at today concerns a body of scaven gers belonging to the Hindu society and does not make it none the less religious in the broadest sense of the term.
('62', 303, 4, 20, 590693) I feel that it is a deeply humanitarian mission to which I have not hesitated to invite the co

('62', 308, 3, 7, 601289) I was even at that time known somewhat amongst them, but I remember what a welcome you gave me at that time.

('62', 308, 3, 11, 601930) I want you to serve the cause; I want you to serve the Harijans.

('62', 308, 3, 19, 602750) You will show it in your own lives that to believe in some people being touchable and some untouchable is not only not religion, but it is the reverse of religion.
('62', 308, 3, 20, 602914) Whereas, if you had no character to achieve or lose, naturally people are not going to put any faith whatsoever in you.
