('62', 314, 2, 8, 615753) 346. NOTES
('62', 314, 3, 9, 615764) GARLANDS It is devoutly to be wished that organizers will wean people from presenting me with garlands of flowers.
('62', 314, 3, 10, 615879) If garlands must be presented, they should be of charkha spun, even, strong and fine yarn, which can be used without difficulty for weaving purposes.
('62', 314, 3, 11, 616029) Garlands are not produced without money or, which is the same thing, labour.
('62', 314, 3, 12, 616106) All the money and all the labour available is required for Harijan service.
('62', 314, 3, 13, 616182) And, in any case, I cannot afford to have labour or money spent for my pleasure, vanity or glorification.
('62', 314, 3, 14, 616288) The showering of flowers is an injurious custom.
('62', 314, 3, 15, 616337) The hard stems of yellow flowers, when they are thrown from a distance are calculated to break eye glasses and injure the eyes.
('62', 314, 3, 16, 616465) My eyes have, more than once, narrowly escaped damage from these stems.
('62', 314, 3, 17, 616537) Let the money thus saved be used for adding to the purses collected.
('62', 314, 3, 18, 616606) Indeed, I notice that there is room for economy in most arrangements.
('62', 314, 3, 19, 616676) Motor cars are used too lavishly.
('62', 314, 3, 20, 616710) Only those of the local persons whose presence is necessary should accompany me from place to place.
('62', 314, 3, 21, 616811) Workers are trustees for the Harijan cause, and as such they are expected to guard the Harijan chest with greater care and vigilance than they would bestow upon their own.
('62', 314, 4, 22, 616983) AUCTIONS AND JEWELLERY I have seen a paragraph in a newspaper adversely criticizing my appeal to the women for gifts of jewellery and my auctioning things received as donations.
('62', 314, 4, 23, 617161) Indeed, I would like the thousands of sisters who attend my meetings to give me most, if not all, of the jewellery they wear.
('62', 314, 4, 24, 617287) In this country of semi starvation of millions and insuffi cient nutrition of practically eighty percent of the people, the wearing of jewellery is an offence to the eye.
('62', 314, 4, 25, 617458) A woman in India has rarely any
('62', 315, 0, 1, 617490) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 315, 1, 2, 617532) cash which she can call her own.
('62', 315, 1, 3, 617565) But the jewellery she wears does belong to her, though even that she will not, dare not, give away, without the consent of her lord and master.
('62', 315, 1, 4, 617709) It ennobles her to part with, for a good cause, something she calls her own.
('62', 315, 1, 5, 617786) Moreover, most of this jewellery has no pretension to art, some of it is positively ugly and a harbinger of dirt.
('62', 315, 1, 6, 617900) Such are anklets, heavy necklaces, clasps worn not for adjusting the hair, but purely as a decoration for unkempt, unwashed and often evil smelling hair, or row upon row of bangles from wrist to elbow.
('62', 315, 1, 7, 618102) In my opinion, the wearing of expensive jewellery is a distinct loss to the country.
('62', 315, 1, 8, 618187) It is so much capital locked up or, worse still, allowed to wear away.
('62', 315, 1, 9, 618258) And in this movement of self purification, the surrender of jewellery by women or men I hold to be a distinct benefit to society.
('62', 315, 1, 10, 618388) Those who give do so gladly.
('62', 315, 1, 11, 618417) My invariable condition is that on no account should the jewellery donated be replaced.
('62', 315, 1, 12, 618505) Indeed, women have blessed me for inducing them to part with things which had enslaved them.
('62', 315, 1, 13, 618598) And in not a few cases men have thanked me for being an instrument for bringing simpli city into their homes.
('62', 315, 1, 14, 618708) Now a word about auctions.
('62', 315, 1, 15, 618735) I have seen nothing wrong about them.
('62', 315, 1, 16, 618773) They set up a healthy rivalry and are an innocent method of evoking the generous impulse in man or woman for a noble cause.
('62', 315, 1, 17, 618897) I have resorted to the method now for years without ever noticing the slightest civil effect produced by these auctions.
('62', 315, 1, 18, 619018) Why is it wrong to pay a price beyond its intrinsic value for an article which one prizes, even though it be as a memento, if it is not wrong to pay fabulous prices for worn out manuscripts of authors reputed to be great ?
('62', 315, 1, 19, 619241) Surely, the price of an article is what a man voluntarily pays for it.
('62', 315, 1, 20, 619312) And let it be remembered that people who bid at my auctions do not pay fancy prices for pleasing me.
('62', 315, 1, 21, 619413) I know they do not.
('62', 315, 1, 22, 619433) I can recall occasions when I have not been able to induce bids, even though the audiences have been otherwise as enthusiastic or responsive as anywhere else.
('62', 315, 2, 23, 619592) ABUSE OF FASTING Cases of abuse of fasting have recently come under my observation.
('62', 315, 2, 24, 619676) One person wrote threatening to fast if I did not send my autograph, three if I did not visit their places during the tour and another if his village did not produce Rs. 5,000 for khadi, Harijan and kindred constructive activities.
('62', 315, 2, 25, 619908) I have no doubt that all these are instances of abuse of fasting.
('62', 315, 2, 26, 619974) Why should I give my autograph, or visit
('62', 316, 0, 1, 620015) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 317
('62', 316, 1, 2, 620062) a place or workers find money under threat of a fast ?
('62', 316, 1, 3, 620117) There should be a moral obligation on the one against whom a fast is taken.
('62', 316, 1, 4, 620193) Fasts are legitimately taken in the interest of some public good or for doing service to those for whom they are taken.
('62', 316, 1, 5, 620313) I am well aware that the dividing line between use and abuse is often too thin to be noticeable.
('62', 316, 1, 6, 620410) The better test, therefore, perhaps is whether the person fasting has undergone the requisite discipline for taking fasts calculated to influence conduct other than his own.
('62', 316, 1, 7, 620584) In the cases quoted, so far as I can see, there was utter absence of qualification or previous pre paration.
('62', 316, 1, 8, 620693) Moreover, legitimate fasts, even if repeated by many, should be capable of response.
('62', 316, 1, 9, 620778) In the cases under consideration, if a thousand persons asked for my autograph, or a thousand workers in a thousand village desired my visit to their places or a worker required poor people to pay the money he wanted, it is clear that response might easily be a physical impossibility.

('62', 327, 5, 13, 649055) MADRAS, December 22, 1933
('62', 327, 6, 14, 649081) Asked about his statement 1 that he had given Pandit Jawaharlal a power of attorney to act for him as leader of the Congress.
('62', 327, 6, 15, 649207) Party, Mr. Gandhi said that he had noted the Pandit’s reply and the implication that he was joking when he made the statement.
('62', 327, 6, 16, 649334) That is not wholly true.

('62', 338, 1, 2, 673896) 363. REPLY TO HARIJAN DE`PUTATION 1
('62', 338, 2, 3, 673932) RAJAHMUNDRY, December 24, 1933 One important question that you have raised is that the Harijan Sevak Sangh should be principally manned and managed by you.
('62', 338, 2, 4, 674088) That shows that you have not followed the pages of the Harijan.
('62', 338, 2, 5, 674152) That shows also that you have not understood the origin of the Board.
('62', 338, 2, 6, 674222) The Board has been formed to enable savarna Hindus to do repentance and reparation to you.
('62', 338, 2, 7, 674313) It is thus a Board of debtors and you are the creditors.
('62', 338, 2, 8, 674370) You owe nothing to the debtors, and therefore, so far as this Board is concerned, the initiative has to come from the debtors.
('62', 338, 2, 9, 674497) You have to certify whether the debtors discharge their obligation or not.
('62', 338, 2, 10, 674572) What you have to do is to enable and help them to discharge their obligations; that is to say, you can tell them how they can discharge their obligation, you can tell them what in your opinion will satisfy the great body of Harijans.
('62', 338, 2, 11, 674806) They may or may not accept your advice.
('62', 338, 2, 12, 674846) If they do not, naturally they run the risk of incurring your displeasure.
('62', 338, 2, 13, 674921) A debtor may go to a creditor and say to him, I have brought so much money, will you take it ?’ The creditor may say, ‘Off you go; I want full payment or none.’ Or the creditor may say, ‘What you have brought is not part payment, but worse.’ All these things you, creditors, can do.
('62', 338, 2, 14, 675204) And so, when this Board was established and some Harijan friends wrote to me, I told them that Harijans should form themselves into advisory boards or boards of inspection.
('62', 338, 2, 15, 675377) I want you to understand this distinction thoroughly.
('62', 338, 2, 16, 675431) You will please see that there is no desire not to accept your advice or co operation or help.
('62', 338, 2, 17, 675526) I am only putting before you the true and logical position.
('62', 338, 2, 18, 675586) This is a period of grace that God has given to caste Hindus, and it is during this period of grace that they have to prove their sincerity.
('62', 338, 2, 19, 675727) And I am moving heaven and earth and am going about from place to place, simply in order that this obligation on the part of savarna Hindus may be fully discharged.
('62', 338, 2, 20, 675892) A member of the deputation then suggested that the Board should appoint advisory committees of Harijans of its own selection.
('62', 338, 2, 21, 676018) Do not ask the Board to select a committee of Harijans, but select your own committee and say to the Board you have elected
('62', 338, 3, 22, 676142) 1 A deputation of Harijans from East Godavari District met Gandhiji at Raja hmundry.
('62', 339, 0, 1, 676227) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 339, 1, 2, 676269) these members and it should carry on correspondence with them.
('62', 339, 1, 3, 676332) There is another danger in the suggestion.
('62', 339, 1, 4, 676375) There may be factions and divisions among you.
('62', 339, 1, 5, 676422) Different committees may be appointed by different factions.
('62', 339, 1, 6, 676483) The Board may recognize all of them.
('62', 339, 1, 7, 676520) But that will be unfortunate.
('62', 339, 1, 8, 676550) Let there be no quarrels among you.
('62', 339, 1, 9, 676586) Present a united front to the debtors.
('62', 339, 1, 10, 676625) The debtors may put you against one another, though the Board, if it is worth its name, will not do that.
('62', 339, 1, 11, 676731) The Congress has been able to present a united front.
('62', 339, 1, 12, 676785) Today, the Congress is full of simple men like you and me.
('62', 339, 1, 13, 676844) You should have a body of business like men who will put down with a strong hand all quarrels among you.

('62', 342, 3, 11, 681998) He is ever contented, is self controlled and keeps his vows; he has dedicated his mind and reason to God.
('62', 342, 3, 12, 682104) He causes pain to none and has no fears and worries, desires nothing, is pure in mind and heart and skilful in work, has renounced everything and treats friend and enemy with equal regard, is indifferent to respect and disrespect, bears heat and cold, is unmoved by praise or censure, looks upon wherever he happens to be as his home, that is, has no home of his own, doesn’t speak unnecessarily and has a steady mind.

('62', 352, 8, 21, 699313) 381. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, ELLORE
('62', 352, 9, 22, 699351) December 27, 1933 I wish to thank you all for this great reception which is an exhibition of your great affection.
('62', 352, 9, 23, 699466) I thank you for the various purses and addresses including one from the Municipality and another from the District Board.
('62', 352, 9, 24, 699588) You will not expect me to refer to the details of the various addresses in the too short time before me.
('62', 352, 9, 25, 699693) My first and sacred duty is to unveil the portrait of the “Lion of the Punjab”, the late Lala Lajpat Rai.
('62', 352, 9, 26, 699799) You will not expect me to recount before you his many valuable qualities and services.
('62', 352, 9, 27, 699886) I had the privilege of enjoying his confidence till he died.
('62', 352, 9, 28, 699947) He was the President of the historic session of the Congress in 1920. Today to me and to you the one outstanding quality of his is his unadulterated love for the untouchables.
('62', 352, 9, 29, 700123) He has taught Hindu India to keep to its sense of duty to the so called untouchables, the Harijans.
('62', 352, 9, 30, 700223) Lajpat Rai always
('62', 353, 0, 1, 700241) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 353, 1, 2, 700283) proclaimed that untouch ability was the greatest blot on Hinduism.
('62', 353, 1, 3, 700350) If he had done nothing else, we, Hindus, should revere his sacred memory for his war against untouchability.
('62', 353, 1, 4, 700459) Who can deny his services to the country, his bravery and his fearlessness ?
('62', 353, 1, 5, 700536) It was not by an idle epithet that he was called the “Lion of the Punjab”.
('62', 353, 1, 6, 700611) I must pass on to other things.
('62', 353, 1, 7, 700643) You will be pleased to know that Mulpuri Chukkamma even from Vellore Jail thought of Harijans and out of her poor belongings she sent me this ring.
('62', 353, 1, 8, 700791) Her letter bearing the signature of the Superintendent of the Central Jail is here with me.
('62', 353, 1, 9, 700883) Who can help deriving inspiration from such acts ?
('62', 353, 2, 10, 700934) Wherever I go, I find evidence of enthusiasm on the part of the people, readiness on their part to open out their hearts to the so called untouchables, the Harijans.
('62', 353, 2, 11, 701100) Wherever I go, I find a readiness on the part of the people to part with their possessions, to part with their coppers, with their silver, with their gold and women are not behind men in making their sacrifices.
('62', 353, 2, 12, 701312) I know for certain that they know for what purpose they have given their bangles or their rings or whatever they hold very dear.
('62', 353, 2, 13, 701441) They know that all these moneys and all these ornaments are being given in order that Harijans may be served.
('62', 353, 2, 14, 701551) This cause, the more I think about it the more I feel, is a cause for all humanity and for all time.
('62', 353, 2, 15, 701652) If Hindus succeed in exorcizing this devil of untouchability, if they succeed in transforming their hearts and if they succeed in purifying themselves of this blot, I have no doubt whatsoever that we, all the communities belonging to different religions, will live in happiness, contentment, peace and real friendship of the heart.
('62', 353, 2, 16, 701984) I have no doubt whatsoever that, if we achieve full success in this mission, in this war against untouchability, as I have said, I have no doubt that we shall be able to achieve the heart unity.
('62', 353, 2, 17, 702179) Suspicions will melt away before the sunshine of mutual trust, mutual affection and mutual respect.
('62', 353, 2, 18, 702279) Let us, therefore, you and I and all, pray to God Almighty that He may bless us with sufficient strength and wisdom to see this error and correct it, no matter what it was.
('62', 353, 2, 19, 702452) Let us remember that all these centuries we have suppressed a portion of ourselves and in so doing we have degraded ourselves, and we have depressed ourselves.
('62', 353, 2, 20, 702612) No power on earth has yet succeeded in suppressing any portion of humanity without degrading itself and without depressing itself.
('62', 353, 2, 21, 702743) The more I see, the more I feel that, if we do not drive away this untouchability, Hinduism itself will perish and it will be a loss not only
('62', 353, 3, 22, 702885) 1 What follows is from The Hindu, 29 12 1933
('62', 354, 0, 1, 702930) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 355
('62', 354, 1, 2, 702977) to us but it will be a loss to the world.
('62', 354, 1, 3, 703019) A religion that owes its inspiration to the Vedas, to the Upanishads, to the Puranas, to Ramayana, why should that religion perish—for what purpose, for what reason, except that we did not observe the message of the Upanishads, that we did not observe the grand message, the grand proposition enunciated in the pages of the Vedas, the Upanishads that God alone is and no one else and nothing else ?
('62', 354, 1, 4, 703418) Do you suppose the preachers of that one God, God of Justice, preached that there could be any divisions of high and low amongst ourselves ?
('62', 354, 1, 5, 703559) It is an impossible thing.
('62', 354, 1, 6, 703586) The more one thinks about these things, the more it is surprising that a people so cultured as Hindus are supposed to be, should have hugged untouchability as a part of their religion.
('62', 354, 1, 7, 703771) And remember lastly that all the religions in the world are today in the melting pot.
('62', 354, 1, 8, 703857) They are all being critically examined and tested and public opinion will not forgive you and me if we do not energetically drive away this evil from our midst.
('62', 354, 1, 9, 704018) I must not now take any more of your time on untouchability.
('62', 354, 2, 10, 704079) Mr. Gandhi then said that as he was speaking at Ellore, the headquarters of the
('62', 354, 3, 11, 704159) Andhra Provincial Anti untouchability Association, he wished to draw attention to
('62', 354, 4, 12, 704241) the fact that he had received some complaints against some of its office bearers.
('62', 354, 5, 13, 704323) Gandhi said that he and Mr. Thakkar, the vigilant Secretary of the Central Board,
('62', 354, 6, 14, 704405) found after investigation that there was absolutely no foundation for the charges made.
('62', 354, 6, 15, 704493) He always kept his eyes and ears open for receiving any bona fide
('62', 354, 7, 16, 704559) complaints, but he insisted that anybody who complained should do so on two
('62', 354, 8, 17, 704635) conditions.
('62', 354, 8, 18, 704647) Firstly, he must announce his name to the public instead of sending
('62', 354, 9, 19, 704715) anonymous letters and secondly he must substantiate all his allegations by
('62', 354, 10, 20, 704790) unimpeachable evidence.
('62', 354, 11, 21, 704814) Mr. Gandhi delivered his speech in English and before closing he said that it
('62', 354, 12, 22, 704892) was a great regret to him to have done so, even in Andhradesha where Hindi had
('62', 354, 13, 23, 704971) progressed very much.
('62', 354, 13, 24, 704993) He had to speak in English to facilitate translation.
('62', 354, 13, 25, 705047) It would
('62', 354, 14, 26, 705056) not at all be difficult for the Andhras to learn Hindi as many of the words were derived
('62', 354, 15, 27, 705145) from Sanskrit out of which the Telugu language was formed.

('62', 355, 0, 1, 705288) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 355, 1, 2, 705330) 382. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING, VIZAGAPATAM
('62', 355, 2, 3, 705374) December 28, 1933 The Harijan cause is like fire.
('62', 355, 2, 4, 705424) The more ghee you put into fire, the more it requires.
('62', 355, 2, 5, 705479) So also, the more you give to the Harijan cause, the more it requires.
('62', 355, 2, 6, 705550) Those who give to the cause gain, they never lose; and those who do not give undoubtedly lose.
('62', 355, 2, 7, 705645) What you gain by giving is merit.
('62', 355, 2, 8, 705679) What you lose by not giving is your self.
('62', 355, 2, 9, 705721) For men and women belonging to savarna Hindu castes have been persecuting Harijans now for ages.
('62', 355, 2, 10, 705818) And if we are just now passing through evil times, I am convinced that our treatment of Harijans has not a little to do with it.
('62', 355, 2, 11, 705947) I have, therefore, been asking the women of India to drive away the ghost of untouchability from their hearts.
('62', 355, 2, 12, 706058) It is wrong, it is sinful, to consider some people lower than ourselves.
('62', 355, 2, 13, 706131) On God’s earth nobody is low and nobody is high.
('62', 355, 2, 14, 706180) We are all His creatures; and just as in the eyes of parents all their children are absolutely equal, so also in God’s eyes all His creatures must be equal.
('62', 355, 2, 15, 706337) Therefore I ask you to believe me when I tell you that there is no sanction in religion for untouchability.
('62', 355, 2, 16, 706445) I would, therefore, ask you to give a place in your hearts to all the Harijans around you.
('62', 355, 2, 17, 706536) Welcome Harijan children in your own homes.
('62', 355, 2, 18, 706580) Go to Harijan quarters and look after their children and their homes; speak to Harijan women as to your own sisters.
('62', 355, 2, 19, 706697) This cause of Harijans is essentially for the women of India to tackle; and I hope that you, the Hindu women of this place, will do your duty.
('62', 355, 2, 20, 706840) I hope those of you, who have the wish and the ability to surrender all or any part of your jewellery, will do so.
('62', 355, 2, 21, 706955) There is one condition attached to the gift.
('62', 355, 2, 22, 707000) If you give anything whatsoever, it must not be replaced.
('62', 355, 2, 23, 707058) I want you to feel that you personally have given something to this cause, which you cannot do when you give rupees or notes.
('62', 355, 2, 24, 707184) For they come from either your parents or your husbands.
('62', 355, 2, 25, 707241) But jewellery is your own property.
('62', 355, 2, 26, 707277) When you surrender your jewellery without any intention of having it replaced by your parents or husbands, it is definitely your own sacrifice.
('62', 355, 2, 27, 707421) I want you all who have understood the spirit of the message I have delivered to you to make that definite sacrifice.
('62', 355, 2, 28, 707539) Harijan, 5 1 1934
('62', 356, 0, 1, 707557) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 357
('62', 356, 1, 2, 707604) 383. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, VIZAGAPATAM
('62', 356, 2, 3, 707647) December 28, 1933 You drove me today, on my alighting at the station, through a row of Harijans who were being fed at that time through the charity of some townsman.
('62', 356, 2, 4, 707813) Whilst he may be entitled to thanks for his liberality, I must confess that it was not a soul stirring scene.
('62', 356, 2, 5, 707923) I hung my head in shame as the car was driven through the road along which Harijan men and women were feeding.
('62', 356, 2, 6, 708034) Just imagine how you and I would feel if some insolent person drove his car through the road where we were taking our meals.
('62', 356, 2, 7, 708159) I know the custom under which caste dinners are given.
('62', 356, 2, 8, 708214) All traffic along the road on which dinners are given is entirely prohibited, so that it is possible for diners to have their meals and to be served in perfect peace.
('62', 356, 2, 9, 708381) As I have said repeatedly, this movement of purification goes down to the roots of our hearts.
('62', 356, 2, 10, 708476) I have not asked savarna Hindus to appear as patrons before Harijans and throw the leavings of their dishes to them.
('62', 356, 2, 11, 708593) But I have invited them to open out their hearts to Harijans and to ind there a sanctuary for them.
('62', 356, 2, 12, 708693) But what I saw today was like the act of a patron towards his dependents.
('62', 356, 2, 13, 708767) And do you know, not only my car was driven through the rows of people taking meals, but other cars followed and the crowd also followed these cars.
('62', 356, 2, 14, 708916) And I noticed that it was a hard thing for those poor people to protect their food from dust blowing on it.
('62', 356, 2, 15, 709024) It was not, to say the least, a becoming performance.
('62', 356, 2, 16, 709078) And you can now understand my grief at having been obliged to witness it.
('62', 356, 2, 17, 709152) I know there was no evil intention behind this act.
('62', 356, 2, 18, 709204) I know also that there was not a single person who had any desire to insult these Harijans who were given free meals.
('62', 356, 2, 19, 709322) I understand also that those who took me through that road thought it would please me to drive through the rows of Harijans taking meals.
('62', 356, 2, 20, 709460) I know it was nothing but simple thoughtlessness.
('62', 356, 2, 21, 709510) As we have been told by Shastras, to live a religious life is like walking on the edge of a sword.
('62', 356, 2, 22, 709609) And in a worldwide movement like this of self purification among millions of human beings, a single thoughtless act takes the shape of sin.
('62', 356, 2, 23, 709749) Every act of ours, therefore, in connection with this Harijan movement has to be dictated and dominated by punctiliousness, extreme caution and inward searching.
('62', 356, 2, 24, 709911) Having witnessed this scene, I thought it would be wrong on my part not to make a public reference to it.
('62', 356, 2, 25, 710017) By drawing your attention to it, I have endeavoured to warn the public taking part
('62', 357, 0, 1, 710100) 358 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 357, 1, 2, 710142) in this movement of self purification against a repetition of the scene of this morning.
('62', 357, 1, 3, 710231) This brings me to what we are doing today through the length and breadth of India.
('62', 357, 1, 4, 710314) I have not the shadow of a doubt that untouchability is an unmitigated curse on Hinduism.
('62', 357, 1, 5, 710404) If the Shastras represent the will and wish of God, there can be no warrant whatsoever in them for untouchability, for which you find no parallel in any part of the world save India.
('62', 357, 1, 6, 710587) It is bad enough when dictated by selfish motives to consider ourselves high and other people low.
('62', 357, 1, 7, 710686) But it is not only worse but a double wrong when we tack religion to an evil like untouchability.
('62', 357, 1, 8, 710784) It, therefore, grieves me when learned pundits come forward and invoke the authority of the Shastras for a patent evil like untouchability.
('62', 357, 1, 9, 710924) I have said, and I repeat today, that we, Hindus, are undergoing a period of probation.
('62', 357, 1, 10, 711012) Whether we desire it or not, untouchability is going.
('62', 357, 1, 11, 711066) But if during this period of probation we repent for the sin, if we reform and purify ourselves, history will record that one act as a supreme act of purification on the part of the Hindus.
('62', 357, 1, 12, 711256) But if, through the working of the time spirit, we are compelled to do things against our will and Harijans come to their own, it will be no credit to the Hindus or to Hinduism.
('62', 357, 1, 13, 711434) But I go a step further and say that if we fail in this trial, Hinduism and Hindus will perish.
('62', 357, 1, 14, 711530) Harijan, 5 1 1934
('62', 357, 2, 15, 711548) 384. NOTES
('62', 357, 3, 16, 711559) SOME QUESTIONS It is wonderful how the very same questions are being asked again and again at the different places visited by me and this by those whom one would expect to be readers of Harijan or otherwise to be acquainted with what I have said on those questions.
('62', 357, 3, 17, 711825) But so long as they continue to be asked, I suppose I must deal with them and hope that the readers who are familiar with them will not mind the trespass on these columns.
('62', 357, 3, 18, 711997) I need not repeat the questions.
('62', 357, 3, 19, 712030) The following answers will suggest the kind of questions asked.
('62', 357, 3, 20, 712094) 1. There can be no compulsion in the matter of temple entry.
('62', 357, 3, 21, 712155) 2. No temple wil be opened to Harijans without the approval of a clear majority of trustees or an overwhelming majority of persons believing in temple worship and entitled to use the temple in question
('62', 358, 0, 1, 712357) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 359
('62', 358, 1, 2, 712404) for purposes of worship.
('62', 358, 1, 3, 712429) 3. There is no compulsion whatever in the Temple entry Bill or the Anti untouchability Bill.
('62', 358, 1, 4, 712522) Harijans should be subject to the same rules of admission as are applicable to the other Hindus.
('62', 358, 1, 5, 712619) 4. If anybody satisfies me that the Shastras enjoin untoucha bility as it is observed today, I shall at once give up the agitation.
('62', 358, 1, 6, 712751) 5. But my settled conviction is that modern untouchability is an inhuman institution having its root in selfishness and the desire for exploitation of fellow beings found to be amenable to suppression.
('62', 358, 1, 7, 712953) 6. The untouchables are made and unmade by census enum erators and commissioners as has been abundantly proved in these pages.
('62', 358, 1, 8, 713080) NO TOYS PLEASE Andhradesha easily beats other provinces in presenting toys and the like.
('62', 358, 1, 9, 713169) Some produce little silver cups, some trays, some other fancy things not easily portable.
('62', 358, 1, 10, 713259) I cannot induce buyers on the spot to bid for numerous things and however tempting they may be for the cause, they become a nuisance to carry and keep count of.
('62', 358, 1, 11, 713420) I would, there fore, advise organizers to discountenance, if not forbid, such gifts.
('62', 358, 1, 12, 713505) In several places heavy frames and portraits have been presented.
('62', 358, 1, 13, 713571) They become a positive burden and are unsalable in the market.
('62', 358, 1, 14, 713634) On no account should frames be presented.
('62', 358, 1, 15, 713676) I would like the tour to retain its serious character and be business like involving little or no waste in any matter.
('62', 358, 1, 16, 713795) I may mention incidentally that, in presenting purses, bank notes should be used wherever possible, instead of coins.
('62', 358, 1, 17, 713913) In swift travelling, covering ten to fifteen places in a day, it is difficult to count all the cash from day to day and keep accurate accounts.
('62', 358, 1, 18, 714057) In any case, the accountants, devoted though they are, are over worked and often have to keep late hours in order to keep themselves up to date.
('62', 358, 1, 19, 714202) Big organizations like the All India Harijan Sevak Sangh cannot be effi ciently and yet cheaply conducted without attention to minutest details and without the intelligent co operation of the workers and volunteers taking part in it.
('62', 358, 1, 20, 714436) Harijan,29 12 1933
('62', 359, 0, 1, 714455) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 359, 1, 2, 714497) 385. MARWARI RELIEF SOCIETY
('62', 359, 2, 3, 714525) This Society was established in Calcutta in1923. In the report on the flood relief work in Orissa sent by Sjt.
('62', 359, 2, 4, 714636) Harakhchand and pub lished in the Harijan Sevak, there is a mention of this Society’s valuable services.
('62', 359, 2, 5, 714741) On my way to Bezwada from Delhi the other day, some workers of the above Society met me at Palwal station.
('62', 359, 2, 6, 714848) They are helping the flood victims in the district of Gurgaon.
('62', 359, 2, 7, 714911) At the station they gave me a report containing a detailed account of their work and told me : ‘If you read this, you will know that we made no distinction between untouchables and others; in fact we paid special attention to the poor helpless Harijans.’ The account of the services rendered from November 19, 1933 to December 13, 1933 is to be found in this report.
('62', 359, 2, 8, 715278) The Society’s volunteers worked in 144 villages.
('62', 359, 2, 9, 715327) They distributed 2,809 quilts, 1,846 shirts, 1,256 skirts and 872 maunds, 5 seers of grain among 4,098 flood victims.
('62', 359, 2, 10, 715445) They distributed medicines to 3,052 patients suffering from itch, cholera, cough and other maladies.
('62', 359, 2, 11, 715546) Wherever needed, the sick were given milk, barley, sago and other things.
('62', 359, 2, 12, 715620) Houses damaged by floods are being rebuilt.
('62', 359, 2, 13, 715664) The Society is working in seven places: Palwal, Dighout, Bannikheda, Banchari, Hodal, Hasanpur and Gulabad.
('62', 359, 2, 14, 715772) I thank the Society and the young volunteers who are working in the above seven places.
('62', 359, 2, 15, 715860) The number of Harijans and non Hindus helped by the Society is also separately given in the report.
('62', 359, 2, 16, 715960) As long as this pernicious tendency towards discriminating between man and man persists, even in times of common relief operations, so long, unfortunately, separate mention of Hindus, Harijans and non Hindus is and will continue to be necessary in this unfortunate land.
('62', 359, 2, 17, 716231) [From Hindi] Harijan Sevak, 29 12 1933

('62', 374, 7, 23, 742892) 406. LETTER TO HARIJAN WORKERS,
('62', 374, 8, 24, 742924) CUDDAPAH, January 2, 1934 2
('62', 374, 9, 25, 742952) GANDHIJI : The Harijan movement goes to the root of the evil.
('62', 374, 9, 26, 743014) If untouchability goes, the castes as we know them today go.
('62', 374, 10, 27, 743075) HARIJAN WORKERS : Surely not.
('62', 374, 11, 28, 743105) G. I talk of the extreme form of untouchability.
('62', 374, 11, 29, 743154) But the evil is so widespread that in some form or other it runs through the whole Hindu social system and corrupts it.
('62', 374, 11, 30, 743274) The distinction of high and low is
('62', 374, 12, 31, 743309) 1 Vide, “Letter to Jamnalal Bajaj”, 31 12 1933
('62', 374, 13, 32, 743356) 2 Extracted from Chandrashankar Shukla’s “Weekly Letter” 3 A Harijan worker had asked whether Gandhiji wanted the caste system to
('62', 375, 0, 1, 743486) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 375, 1, 2, 743528) at the bottom of untouchability.
('62', 375, 1, 3, 743561) If the extreme form goes, the rest is bound to go.
('62', 375, 1, 4, 743612) If it does not, our movement will be a mere camouflage.
('62', 375, 1, 5, 743668) So long as the idea of high and low is not abolished, untouchability cannot be said to have been abolished.
('62', 375, 2, 6, 743776) H. W. What, then, of the varna which you seek to defend ?
('62', 375, 3, 7, 743834) But you must know my definition of it.
('62', 375, 3, 8, 743873) It is as different from the present caste system as chalk is from cheese.
('62', 375, 3, 9, 743947) Varna say I understand it is an economic law which operates, whether we know it or not.
('62', 375, 3, 10, 744035) Conformation to it will bring happiness to man kind.
('62', 375, 3, 11, 744088) Disregard for it is disrupting society today all over the world.
('62', 375, 3, 12, 744153) Varna is the antithesis of the doctrine of ‘might is right’.
('62', 375, 3, 13, 744214) It abolishes all distinctions between high and low.
('62', 375, 4, 14, 744266) H. W. But nobody gives the meaning you give to varna.
('62', 375, 4, 15, 744320) G. That may be.
('62', 375, 4, 16, 744336) Evolution of human thought is evolution of the meaning of words.
('62', 375, 4, 17, 744401) I have no difficulty in seeing my meaning in the original mantra from which the theory of varna is derived, 1 nor in the Gita verses referring to varna.
('62', 375, 4, 18, 744554) 2. Regulations about dining and marriage have no direct connection with varna.
('62', 375, 4, 19, 744633) The distinguishing feature of varna is occupation.
('62', 375, 5, 20, 744684) H. W. Then you will restrict everyone to his father’s occupation ?
('62', 375, 6, 21, 744751) G. Neither I nor anybody else can impose the restriction on anyone.
('62', 375, 6, 22, 744819) Varnadharma is not a man made law to be imposed or relaxed at his will.
('62', 375, 6, 23, 744891) It is natural to man in his regenerate state.
('62', 375, 6, 24, 744937) He may disregard it to his cost.
('62', 375, 6, 25, 744970) Everyone is free to follow or disobey it.
('62', 375, 6, 26, 745012) It was discovered in India and followed more or less faithfully and knowingly for centuries.
('62', 375, 6, 27, 745105) It is being followed ignorantly and helplessly even now by the bulk of the people.
('62', 375, 6, 28, 745188) In the eye of that law, Brahmin and Bhangi are absolutely on an equal footing.
('62', 375, 6, 29, 745267) A Bhangi who does his work willingly and faithfully will find favour with God.
('62', 375, 6, 30, 745346) A Brahmin who, no matter how learned he may be, does not follow his calling will incur divine displeasure.
('62', 375, 6, 31, 745453) The law does not confer privileges, it defines duties.
('62', 375, 6, 32, 745508) Truest democracy can be evolved only by a due recognition of and obedience to the law.
('62', 375, 6, 33, 745595) Thus, in my opinion, there is no evil in varna.
('62', 375, 6, 34, 745643) The evil consists in considering one varna as higher than another.
('62', 375, 7, 35, 745710) H. W. Surely, the varna that you describe exists only in your imagination !
('62', 375, 7, 36, 745786) What we see around us is the solid fact of hundreds of castes, each claiming to be higher than some other.
('62', 375, 8, 37, 745893) 1 Rigveda, x, Purushasukta 2 Vide, for instance, Bhagavad Gita, IV.
('62', 376, 0, 1, 745961) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 377
('62', 376, 1, 2, 746008) G. That is unfortunately so.
('62', 376, 1, 3, 746037) I am simply answering your question and showing you the vital difference between caste and varna.
('62', 376, 1, 4, 746135) Castes are a human manufacture, are daily weakening and have to go.
('62', 376, 1, 5, 746203) Varna as defined by me may be said to exist in my imagination.
('62', 376, 1, 6, 746266) Its definition is not imaginary.
('62', 376, 1, 7, 746299) It is inherent in the mantra on which it is based and is given in so many words in the Bhagavad Gita.
('62', 376, 1, 8, 746401) Harijan, 12 1 1934

('62', 378, 2, 11, 751218) 410. EXTRACTS FROM SPEECHES TO WOMEN 2
('62', 378, 3, 12, 751257) [Before January 4, 1934] 3
('62', 378, 4, 13, 751284) The real ornament of woman is her character, her purity.
('62', 378, 4, 14, 751341) Metal and stones can never be real ornaments.
('62', 378, 4, 15, 751387) The names of women like Sita and Damayanti have become sacred to us for their unsullied virtue, never for their jewellery, if they wore any.
('62', 378, 4, 16, 751528) My asking from you your jewellery has also a wider significance.
('62', 378, 4, 17, 751593) Several sisters have told me that they feel all the better for getting rid of their jewels.
('62', 378, 5, 18, 751685) I have called this an act of merit in more ways than one.
('62', 378, 5, 19, 751743) No man or woman is entitled to the possession of wealth, unless he or she has given a fair share of it to the poor and the helpless.
('62', 378, 5, 20, 751876) It is a social and religious obligation and has been called a sacrifice by the Bhagavad Gita.
('62', 378, 5, 21, 751970) He who does not offer this sacrifice has been called a thief.
('62', 378, 5, 22, 752032) 5 The Gita has enumerated many forms of sacrifice; but what greater sacrifice can there be than to serve the poor and the needy ?

('62', 382, 3, 16, 760180) January 4, 1934
('62', 382, 4, 17, 760196) FRIENDS, I am deeply touched by your welcome.
('62', 382, 4, 18, 760242) I do not want all this enthusiasm of yours and all this exhibition of affection towards me to waste away without turning them to good use.
('62', 382, 4, 19, 760381) If you therefore have patience with me for a few brief moments, you will see that I turn all that enthusiasm and affection to good account.
('62', 382, 4, 20, 760521) What I am about to do will also be a test of the genuineness of your enthusiasm and your affection.
('62', 382, 4, 21, 760621) You know the message that I want to tell you.
('62', 382, 4, 22, 760667) I would like us all, every one of us, to purify our heart of the curse of untouchability.
('62', 382, 4, 23, 760757) In one of the many addresses that I had the honour and pleasure of receiving today after entering the border of Mysore State, it was truly stated that this curse of untouchability had permeated Hindu society to such an extent that it almost ruled our lives and the signatories to the address were good enough to say that the message I was trying to deliver to the Hindus of India was producing its effect and went on to admit that, if we could but get rid of this poison of untouchability, all our differences even between different communities would vanish.
('62', 383, 0, 1, 761316) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 383, 1, 2, 761358) There you see what I am asking every one of us to do.
('62', 383, 1, 3, 761412) I am pleading with you that we should get rid of this position of untouchability all along the line, so that we won’t have only a particular class labeled as Harijans but we should all become Harijans, namely, and truly, children of God.

('62', 383, 2, 10, 762451) 417. PLEA FOR CATHOLICITY 1
('62', 383, 3, 11, 762479) During my frequent travels I have noticed that the reception committees are not too mindful of expense in catering for the wants of guests.
('62', 383, 3, 12, 762619) They will insist on producing sweets or other delicacies and a multiplicity of dishes.
('62', 383, 3, 13, 762706) I have firmly discountenanced these at all times, but this time when I am making collections for the Harijan cause, which I regard as a mission of penance and purification, I feel pained when there is any attempt at lavish hospitality.
('62', 383, 3, 14, 762942) In two places I observed that Gujarati cooks were brought in to produce Gujarati dishes.
('62', 383, 3, 15, 763031) I regard this as a wholly unnecessary procedure.
('62', 383, 3, 16, 763080) I believe that we should be able to accommodate ourselves to the food eaten in the provinces other than our own.
('62', 383, 3, 17, 763193) I know that this is not so simple a question as it appears.
('62', 383, 3, 18, 763253) I know southerners who have made a Herculean effort to take to Gujarati food and failed.
('62', 383, 3, 19, 763342) Gujaratis will not take to the southern mode of cooking.
('62', 383, 3, 20, 763399) Bengal produces dainties which the other provinces will not easily relish.
('62', 383, 3, 21, 763474) If we would be national instead of provincial, we would have to have an interchange of habits as to food, simplify our tastes and produce healthy dishes that all can take with impunity.
('62', 383, 3, 22, 763660) This means a careful study of the foods taken by different
('62', 383, 4, 23, 763719) 1 A Gujarati version of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 31 12 1933
('62', 384, 0, 1, 763786) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 385
('62', 384, 1, 2, 763833) provinces, castes and denominations.
('62', 384, 1, 3, 763870) Unfortunately, or fortunately, there are not only different combinations in different provinces, but there are different styles in the same province, among the different communities.
('62', 384, 1, 4, 764053) It is necessary, therefore, for national workers to study the foods and the methods of perparing them in the various provinces and discover common, simple and cheap dishes which all can take without upsetting the digestive apparatus.
('62', 384, 1, 5, 764287) In any case it must be a matter of shame for workers not to know the manners and customs of different provinces and communities.
('62', 384, 1, 6, 764416) In liberal household cooks ought to be able to cook foods eaten in the various provinces.
('62', 384, 1, 7, 764506) Why should not a Gujarati be able to produce dishes which a Tamilian or an Andhra or a Bengali ordinarily eats ?
('62', 384, 1, 8, 764619) I know that we cannot meet at the top.
('62', 384, 1, 9, 764658) Nor is such a meeting necessary or desirable.
('62', 384, 1, 10, 764704) Rich people will have not only provincial combinations but specialities designed for their own households.
('62', 384, 1, 11, 764811) These cannot be universalized.
('62', 384, 1, 12, 764842) What can be and should be aimed at are common dishes for common people.
('62', 384, 1, 13, 764914) This I know is easily possible if we have the mind.
('62', 384, 1, 14, 764966) But to make this possible, volunteers will have to learn the art of cooking and for this purpose they will have also to study the values of different foods and evolve common dishes easily and cheaply prepared.
('62', 384, 1, 15, 765176) I have strayed somewhat from my main purpose which is to ask organizers of the tour in the provinces not to pamper us but to be rigorously simple and economical in catering for us.
('62', 384, 1, 16, 765357) We are or profess to be conducting a mission of self purification and represen ting the cause of the outcastes of Hindu humanity.
('62', 384, 1, 17, 765487) As such we have no right to the satisfaction of any but the barest wants and creature comforts.
('62', 384, 1, 18, 765583) Fried things and sweets must be strictly eschewed.
('62', 384, 1, 19, 765634) Ghee ought to be most sparingly used.
('62', 384, 1, 20, 765672) More than one green vegetable simply boiled would be regarded as unnecessary.
('62', 384, 1, 21, 765750) Expensive fruit should be always avoided.
('62', 384, 1, 22, 765792) I know that I am the culprit in the matter of fruit.
('62', 384, 1, 23, 765845) Friends would pamper me and go out of the way to procure the richest fruit for me.
('62', 384, 1, 24, 765928) I can only assure them that I do not need any other fruit than oranges, which experience has proved to be necessary for me.
('62', 384, 1, 25, 766052) In spite to all my vaunted abstinence,I know that of my party I am the costliest member to feed.
('62', 384, 1, 26, 766149) I am sorry that it should be so, but mother goat to whose milk I owe my bodily strength and sister orange who keeps me fresh cannot compete in cheapness with rice and wheat.
('62', 384, 1, 27, 766323) Let not my numerous hosts, however add to my indebtedness by importing tempting superfluities.
('62', 384, 1, 28, 766418) Let them not pander to my weak nesses, if they will help me to do my duty towards Harijans.

('62', 390, 1, 14, 776783) We are, no doubt, bound to jealously guard their economic and educational welfare.

('62', 390, 1, 16, 777003) They are entitled to precisely the same rights and privileges as any other citizen.
('62', 390, 1, 17, 777087) And as Hindus they are entitled to the same social amenities and religious privileges that any other Hindu is entitled to.
('62', 390, 1, 18, 777210) My mission, therefore, is to invite savarna Hindus to wash themselves clean of the guilt of untouchability.
('62', 390, 1, 19, 777318) And if, during the short period of grace open to savarna Hindus, they fail to do this duty, I have not the shadow of a doubt that Hinduism will perish.
('62', 390, 1, 20, 777470) You can now understand that this cannot be done by a municipality or even the Maharaja Saheb himself.

('62', 390, 1, 22, 777652) It is, therefore, my privilege, as it is my duty, to invite you to cleanse your hearts of untouchability, the distinction of high and low.

('62', 394, 3, 9, 784353) January 7, 1934 I am deeply grateful to the Bangalore City Municipality for presenting me with this address.
('62', 394, 3, 10, 784462) You have reminded me in your address that you were good enough to do me the honour of giving me such an address when I was in your midst last time.
('62', 394, 3, 11, 784610) And it flatters me to see that I still retain a corner of your hearts.

('62', 395, 3, 8, 786931) 432. SPEECH AT TEMPERANCE ASSOCIATION, BANGALORE January 7, 1934
('62', 395, 4, 9, 786996) It is a matter of pleasure to me that you have invited me to meet you and say a few words on the subject of temperance.
('62', 395, 4, 10, 787116) Some of you perhaps know that this is one of the matters that I took up before I was known to anybody and before I had conceived the thought of entering the political arena.
('62', 395, 4, 11, 787290) When as a young man I went to South Africa, I observed that the coolies, indentured Indians, were fast going down owing to the drink habit.
('62', 395, 4, 12, 787430) The law in South Africa made it a crime for indentured Indians to carry drink home.
('62', 395, 4, 13, 787514) They could drink as much as they liked at the canteen.
('62', 395, 4, 14, 787569) The result was that many women were found literally lying in gutters.
('62', 395, 4, 15, 787639) It was not a thing of which any Indian could be proud.
('62', 395, 4, 16, 787694) I pleaded with the Government, but mine was a voice in the wilderness.
('62', 395, 4, 17, 787765) So the thing went on.
('62', 395, 4, 18, 787787) But it made a lasting impression on my mind.
('62', 395, 4, 19, 787832) I knew what I had to do when I came to India after a long exile.
('62', 395, 4, 20, 787897) I am not a temperance man.
('62', 395, 4, 21, 787924) I am a prohibition man.
('62', 395, 4, 22, 787948) I fought with my countrymen in South Africa and said, “We should not fight for an equal right to drink.” I could not persuade them for a long time, but I did succeed in persuading a majority of them that to fight for rights was one thing and to fight for indulgence in vice was another.
('62', 395, 4, 23, 788235) If the whites were not punished by the State for drinking, we could not plead for the same exemption.
('62', 395, 4, 24, 788337) Here, in India, the Government are trading in liquor.
('62', 395, 4, 25, 788391) I know from bitter experience of Harijans that they drink in spite of themselves.
('62', 395, 4, 26, 788473) I have in mind an esteemed co worker in Calcutta, namely, Satis Chandra Das Gupta.
('62', 396, 0, 1, 788556) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 397
('62', 396, 1, 2, 788603) gave up a remunerative job.
('62', 396, 1, 3, 788631) He was and is still considered the right hand man of Dr. Roy.
('62', 396, 1, 4, 788693) He gave up his chemical work and today he lives near bastis.
('62', 396, 1, 5, 788754) He administered pledges to Harijans not to drink.
('62', 396, 1, 6, 788804) These they broke again and again.
('62', 396, 1, 7, 788838) That broke his heart and he fasted for 15 days.
('62', 396, 1, 8, 788886) It had a marvellous effect on the Harijans.
('62', 396, 1, 9, 788930) They said they would not now go back on their pledges.
('62', 396, 1, 10, 788985) Satis Babu had to go through that agony.
('62', 396, 1, 11, 789026) It was a joy for him.
('62', 396, 1, 12, 789048) A worker who fights drink tooth and nail has to go through this.
('62', 396, 1, 13, 789113) Many Harijans have said to me, “Take away this temptation from us and we shall be all right.
('62', 396, 1, 14, 789206) Do not put it in our way.” When we are not able to control ourselves in so many things, how much less can the Harijans and the labourers control themselves ?
('62', 396, 1, 15, 789364) I have lived, eaten and drunk with them.
('62', 396, 1, 16, 789405) They have no places of recreation.
('62', 396, 1, 17, 789440) They live in wretched holes.
('62', 396, 1, 18, 789469) They have no money to spend for creature comforts.
('62', 396, 1, 19, 789520) What little they get, therefore, goes to canteens.
('62', 396, 1, 20, 789571) I only give you the description to show you how keenly and bitterly I feel in connection with the drink evil.
('62', 396, 1, 21, 789681) I have not the shadow of a doubt that we shall not be able to combat this evil successfully till prohibition comes.
('62', 396, 1, 22, 789797) I have fixed views about prohibition.
('62', 396, 1, 23, 789835) I have given you the result of my experience that, without prohibition, it is impossible to bring about sober habits among the labouring population in India.
('62', 396, 1, 24, 789993) And I have observed that the Harijans are most addicted to this vice.
('62', 396, 1, 25, 790063) India is a country in which total prohibition can succeed.
('62', 396, 1, 26, 790122) People are not habitually given to drink.
('62', 396, 1, 27, 790164) It is not a fashionable vice.
('62', 396, 1, 28, 790194) The climate does not demand its use.
('62', 396, 1, 29, 790231) But government revenue is touched by prohibition.
('62', 396, 1, 30, 790281) Therefore they say, “Find other sources of income before you ask us for total prohibition.” I say, “If you get revenue from impure sources and then say, ‘Replace this revenue,’ you cannot be heard.
('62', 396, 1, 31, 790479) There should be no bargaining about it.” Harijan, 19 1 1934

('62', 397, 1, 2, 790581) 433. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BANGALORE 1
('62', 397, 2, 3, 790624) January 7, 1934 It gives me very great pleasure to see Mr. V. P. Madhava Rao 2 present here.
('62', 397, 2, 4, 790717) I had the pleasure of meeting him six years ago when I was in your midst.

('62', 397, 2, 8, 791270) I have a vivid recollection of his many kindnesses and how I wish he had been here at this meeting to greet me as on old friend.

('62', 397, 2, 11, 791496) I was almost going to say a “good purse”, but I have hesitated to use this adjective, because I know that the citizens of Bangalore are quite able to put together a larger purse and I know that by the time I say goodbye to you, I shall have many generous contributions to the cause of Harijans.
('62', 397, 2, 12, 791791) After all, it is the least reparation that we can do to these brothers and sisters whom Hindus have systematically suppressed.
('62', 397, 2, 13, 791918) I have read your address from top to bottom.
('62', 397, 2, 14, 791963) And I congra tulate you and the Maharaja Saheb’s Government on the many things that you have been able to recite in that address.
('62', 397, 2, 15, 792093) But, neither the State nor the people of Mysore nor I can find any cause for satisfaction unless untouchability is entirely rooted out from our hearts.
('62', 397, 2, 16, 792245) While I gratefully acknowledge all that you have done for Harijans, I ask you not to rest content till all Harijans enjoy all the rights that savarna Hindus enjoy in all walks of life.
('62', 397, 2, 17, 792430) Let us undergo this necessary purification, while there is this brief moment of probation still left to us by God.
('62', 397, 2, 18, 792545) Be sure, if you fail in this hour, God’s wrath will swiftly descend on the Hindus.
('62', 397, 2, 19, 792628) But, one word to Harijan brothers and sisters.
('62', 397, 2, 20, 792675) You cannot be free from this self purification.
('62', 397, 2, 21, 792723) You too have to make your sacrifices at the common altar.
('62', 397, 2, 22, 792781) And that consists in the strict observance of

('62', 398, 2, 16, 794144) 434. TALK WITH HARIJAN WORKERS 2
('62', 398, 3, 17, 794177) BANGALORE, January 7, 1934 It is for you to supplement the work done by the State.
('62', 398, 3, 18, 794260) 3 You may find workers to go and live in the midst of Harijans.
('62', 398, 3, 19, 794324) This is merely all illustration.

('62', 398, 3, 21, 794402) The State cannot attend to individuals.
('62', 398, 3, 22, 794442) That is the prerogative of private persons.

('62', 398, 3, 25, 794579) Our work may not be pretentious, but it must be solid.
('62', 398, 3, 26, 794634) We have to come in intimate touch with the people—savarnas as well as Harijans.
('62', 398, 3, 27, 794714) Such contact with the people can never be established by the State.
('62', 398, 3, 28, 794782) That is essentially the work of the Social reformer.
('62', 398, 3, 29, 794835) Temple entry work is to be done by workers specially qualified for that work.
('62', 398, 3, 30, 794913) If they show character, it will move the Harijan mass.
('62', 398, 3, 31, 794968) The workers must not go in the midst of Harijans as strangers or patrons but go as friends and servants.
('62', 398, 3, 32, 795073) Such work is being done in Wardha.
('62', 398, 3, 33, 795108) If there is one true worker, he will mutiply himself.

('62', 400, 1, 23, 797873) And now the discourse.
('62', 400, 1, 24, 797896) Today I will write something about what the Gita says concerning yajna.
('62', 400, 1, 25, 797968) The subject is introduced in Chapter III.
('62', 400, 1, 26, 798010) In that chapter the Lord says that he who eats without performing yajna eats stolen food 2. This is a very serious statement indeed, for eating stolen food is like swallowing raw mercury.
('62', 400, 1, 27, 798198) Nobody can digest it and, if anyone eats it, he will get eruptions all over the body.
('62', 400, 1, 28, 798284) Hence Akho Bhagat has said : “Eating stolen food is like swallowing raw mercury.” If, therefore, a person stops performing yajna even for a while, he becomes a thief.
('62', 400, 1, 29, 798451) All of us should know that this yajna means.
('62', 400, 1, 30, 798496) Fortunately for us, it is easy for all whose heart is in the right place.
('62', 400, 1, 31, 798570) It requires no wealth, no intellect nor education.
('62', 400, 1, 32, 798621) Yajna means any act of service.
('62', 400, 1, 33, 798653) Only about a person whose whole life is a ceaseless yajna can it be said that he does not eat stolen food.
('62', 400, 1, 34, 798760) Hence those who do just a little work as yajna may be said to be not guilty of theft to that extent.
('62', 400, 1, 35, 798861) Looking at the matter from this point of view, we see that all of us are guilty of theft more or less.
('62', 400, 1, 36, 798964) Our yajna can be said to be perfect only when we have shed all selfishness.
('62', 400, 1, 37, 799040) To do this means to give up the sense of ‘I’ and ‘mine’, to cease feeling that this belongs to me and that to somebody else, that this is my son and that somebody else’s.
('62', 400, 1, 38, 799211) There should not be even a trace of such a feeling in one’s heart.
('62', 400, 1, 39, 799278) He alone can do this who offers up his all to Shri Krishna.
('62', 400, 1, 40, 799338) He who has done that does everything with God as witness, as
('62', 400, 2, 41, 799399) 1 Sister of C. R. Das 2 III.

('62', 401, 1, 2, 799470) His servant and in a spirit of service.
('62', 401, 1, 3, 799510) Such a person is always happy and peaceful in mind.
('62', 401, 1, 4, 799562) Happiness and sufferring are the same to him.
('62', 401, 1, 5, 799608) He uses his body, mind, intellect, possessions—all that is his—for the service of others.

('62', 404, 3, 6, 805572) I will send you the literature on the Bills regarding untouchability.
('62', 404, 3, 7, 805642) If I cannot get a whole loaf of bread I shall be willing to accept even a quarter.
('62', 404, 3, 8, 805725) It is only when I am offered instead of bread a stone purporting to be bread that I refuse to accept it.

('62', 404, 3, 13, 806093) 1 The reference to civil disobedience is not proper.
('62', 404, 3, 14, 806146) An element of corruption had certainly crept into it.
('62', 404, 3, 15, 806200) But even a reference to that is completely out of place in this draft.
('62', 404, 3, 16, 806271) Our opponents are bound to take advantage of it.
('62', 404, 3, 17, 806320) We might even take that risk if such reference were relevant.
('62', 404, 3, 18, 806382) Nor was corruption the cause of my suspending that part of civil disobedience which I have done.

('62', 405, 1, 2, 807437) 441. LETTER TO RAMDAS GANDHI
('62', 405, 2, 3, 807466) BANGALORE, January 8, 1934
('62', 405, 3, 4, 807493) RAMDAS, I got both your letters.
('62', 405, 3, 5, 807526) Do not worry about your having opened Manilal’s letter.
('62', 405, 3, 6, 807582) You are free to open any letter.
('62', 405, 3, 7, 807615) How can I possibly keep anything secret from you all.
('62', 405, 3, 8, 807669) You fear your own shadow, fancying a whole lot of misfortunes.
('62', 405, 3, 9, 807732) Both of you have resolved to stay on there and have the necessary experience.
('62', 405, 3, 10, 807810) You should therefore stick to the place now.
('62', 405, 3, 11, 807855) Go on cheerfully doing what you can and be happy.
('62', 405, 3, 12, 807905) If you do that, you will certainly get over your diffidence.
('62', 405, 3, 13, 807966) I may say I have now begun to understand why you suffer.
('62', 405, 3, 14, 808023) Without knowing it, you are trying to appear better than you are, wish to do so, but you should check such a wish.
('62', 405, 3, 15, 808138) One should not feel miserable at what one is.
('62', 405, 3, 16, 808184) One should try to improve oneself but should not worry ifone fails.
('62', 405, 3, 17, 808252) That is the essence of the Bhagavad Gita’s teaching and therein lies true.
('62', 405, 3, 18, 808327) Humility you have in ample measure but you feel sore in your mind fancying that you lack something.
('62', 405, 3, 19, 808427) To do so is the very opposite of humility.
('62', 405, 3, 20, 808470) Humility always makes one contented with what one is.
('62', 405, 3, 21, 808524) Why should you, seeing someone’s palace, pull down your little hut?
('62', 405, 3, 22, 808592) Why should you not think of your hut as much better than a palace?
('62', 405, 3, 23, 808659) It is not true that those who live in palaces are happier than those who live in huts.
('62', 405, 3, 24, 808746) Happiness consists in being contented.
('62', 405, 3, 25, 808785) Why need you feel sore over your inability to overcome your impure thoughts?
('62', 405, 3, 26, 808862) Everyone in this humility world is full of blemishes.
('62', 405, 3, 27, 808916) Out of countless persons who try to overcome their impure thoughts, only one succeeds in doing so.
('62', 405, 3, 28, 809015) The vast majority should be satisfied with doing the best they can and leave the result to God.
('62', 405, 3, 29, 809111) You need not feel the least constraint in writing anything to me.
('62', 405, 3, 30, 809177) You should make it a rule to write to me at least once a week.
('62', 405, 3, 31, 809240) You will feel light in your heart if you do so.
('62', 405, 3, 32, 809288) Never entertain such futile thoughts that you could not write to me because you were unworthy.
('62', 405, 3, 33, 809383) Should you on your own think yourself unworthy, or feel so only if I thought you unworthy?
('62', 405, 3, 34, 809474) Will you try to curb my thoughts?
('62', 405, 3, 35, 809508) If God thinks me worthy, why should I think myself to be unworthy?
('62', 405, 3, 36, 809575) God never regards anyone as unworthy.
('62', 405, 3, 37, 809613) How, then, could parents with feet of clay think their offspring unworthy?
('62', 405, 3, 38, 809688) Are they themselves likely to be so perfect that they can claim the right to judge their offspring and
('62', 406, 0, 1, 809791) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 407
('62', 406, 1, 2, 809838) think them unworthy?
('62', 406, 1, 3, 809859) No one is competent to judge who in this world is worthy and who is not.

('62', 406, 6, 15, 810645) 443. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, PALGHAT 1
('62', 406, 7, 16, 810686) January 10, 1934 Early in the morning, I entered Malabar—with due deference to our friends who call themselves sanatanists—the land of inequalities.
('62', 406, 7, 17, 810835) As I was passing by familiar places the face of a solitary Nayadi, whom I had seen during the previous visit, rose before my eyes.
('62', 406, 7, 18, 810966) 2 It was about ten or eleven in the morning when, in the midst of a discussion about untouchability, unapproachability and invisibility, all forms of which are found in no part of the world except in Malabar, a shrill voice was heard.
('62', 406, 7, 19, 811201) Those who were talking to me said, ‘We can show you a live Nayadi.’ The public road was not for him.
('62', 406, 7, 20, 811302) Unshod, he was walking across the fields with a noiseless tread.
('62', 406, 7, 21, 811367) I went out with the friends and saw the Nayadi.
('62', 406, 7, 22, 811415) I asked him to come and talk to me.
('62', 406, 7, 23, 811451) Evidently he was frightened and he did not know when a blow would descend upon him.
('62', 406, 7, 24, 811535) Trembling he talked to me.
('62', 406, 7, 25, 811562) I told him that the public road was a much for him as for me.
('62', 406, 7, 26, 811624) He said, ‘It cannot be so.
('62', 406, 8, 27, 811651) 1 The meeting, held at 8.15 in the morning, was attended by about 4,000 persons.
('62', 406, 8, 28, 811732) Addresses of welcome were presented to Gandhiji by the Municipality and the Taluk Board.
('62', 406, 8, 29, 811821) 2 Vide, “Speech at Public Meeting, Palghat,15 10 1927
('62', 407, 0, 1, 811875) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 408
('62', 407, 1, 2, 811917) may not walk on the public road’.
('62', 407, 1, 3, 811951) I close that scene and ask the sanatanists or anybody else to show me the authority in defence of this inhuman conduct.
('62', 407, 1, 4, 812071) You will find me smiling with you, laughing with you, and cracking jokes with you, but you may also know that behind all those jokes and smiles and laughs, the face of the Nayadi and that scene will keep haunting me throughout my tour in Malabar.
('62', 407, 1, 5, 812318) As I was coming here, I was greeted by black flag demonstrators mixed with national flag demonstrators.
('62', 407, 1, 6, 812422) I tell you that I appreciated the black flag demonstrators more than the national flag demons trators because I could see untruth in its nakedness behind the black flag.
('62', 407, 1, 7, 812592) What if those who had black flags had smeared themselves as Brahmins do ?
('62', 407, 1, 8, 812666) He is no Brahmin merely because he carries a black flag or red flag and has marks on his forehead.
('62', 407, 1, 9, 812765) Brahminhood is not known by external marks.
('62', 407, 1, 10, 812809) The scriptures I swear by and in whose defence I would love to die tell me that he alone is a Brahmin who knows Brahman.
('62', 407, 1, 11, 812930) Brahminhood is the essence of humanity, self effacement, pity.
('62', 407, 1, 12, 812993) All those virtues which our ancestors have taught us to prize have to incarnate themselves in a Brahmin.
('62', 407, 1, 13, 813098) He is a Brahmin who is a living treasure of scriptures, but not he who makes a demonstration of untruth by carrying a black flag.
('62', 407, 1, 14, 813228) I have come to Malabar to speak out of the very depths of my soul.
('62', 407, 1, 15, 813295) There are many things in Malabar over which, as you know, I have gone into raptures.
('62', 407, 1, 16, 813380) You have scenery which is second to none in the world.
('62', 407, 1, 17, 813435) Man, if he behaves himself, can live an easy life in Malabar.
('62', 407, 1, 18, 813497) Woman in Malabar is the freest in India.
('62', 407, 1, 19, 813538) All the women I have seen in Malabar have a majesty which has always commanded my respect.
('62', 407, 1, 20, 813629) As you know, I had the pleasure of meeting the ex Maharani of Travancore.
('62', 407, 1, 21, 813703) Her simplicity commanded my admiration and at first sight I fell in love with her.
('62', 407, 1, 22, 813786) But there is nothing to be proud of in the Malabar untouchability.
('62', 407, 1, 23, 813853) It is the vilest thing on earth.
('62', 407, 1, 24, 813886) I want you to wipe out this shame of untouchability from Malabar; and if you can do it, the whole of India naturally will follow; and you can do it if you will.
('62', 407, 1, 25, 814047) I have entered Malabar in high hopes.
('62', 407, 1, 26, 814085) It is for you to fulfil it or frustrate it.
('62', 407, 1, 27, 814129) Only write down this prophecy in your hearts that, if untouchability as we practise it today lives, Hinduism perishes.

('62', 407, 1, 29, 814331) You have the opportunity of making your choice.

('62', 411, 5, 16, 822099) 448 SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, GURUVAYUR 2
('62', 411, 6, 17, 822141) January 11, 1934
('62', 411, 7, 18, 822158) FRIENDS, I would like you all to give me perfect silence.
('62', 411, 8, 19, 822216) We have here a forcible illustration of the age old truth that ‘Man proposes but God disposes’.
('62', 411, 8, 20, 822312) I had hoped to be able to speak to you on subjects of the greatest importance to you, to me and to the whole of the Hindu world.
('62', 411, 8, 21, 822441) Instead of being able to do that, I have been obliged to devote precious forty minutes to a scene that I witnessed this morning.
('62', 411, 8, 22, 822570) 4 I found two fellow countrymen lying here, stretched on the platform, one of them bleeding through the mouth and both of them apparently senseless.
('62', 411, 8, 23, 822719) The first thing, therefore, that
('62', 411, 9, 24, 822752) 1 Pierre Ceresole, a Swiss conscientious objector to war, who founded the International Service.
('62', 411, 9, 25, 822849) 2 The meeting was attended by about 2,000 people.
('62', 411, 9, 26, 822899) 3 This sentence has been taken from the Hindu report.
('62', 411, 10, 27, 822953) 4 Just before the meeting started there had been a scuffle between the volunteers and two sanatanists, Radheswara Sastri and Kalpanathji, resulting in serious injuries to both.
('62', 412, 0, 1, 823130) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 413
('62', 412, 1, 2, 823177) fell to me to do was to give the best attention that was possible for me to these fellow countrymen.
('62', 412, 1, 3, 823278) And so they have been sent under the charge of Prof.
('62', 412, 1, 4, 823331) Malkani to the dispensary here for medical attention.
('62', 412, 1, 5, 823385) In so far as a lay nurse like me can judge, I do not think that their lives are in any way in danger.
('62', 412, 1, 6, 823487) And let us all pray that they may soon be up and doing.
('62', 412, 1, 7, 823543) I understand from the two other friends who have come here on behalf of the All India Varnashrama Swarajya Sangh that they had all come here on behalf on this Sangh.
('62', 412, 1, 8, 823709) They had as perfect a right to attend this meeting as any single one of you.
('62', 412, 1, 9, 823786) They had a perfect right to stage a hostile demonstration, if they intended to, on a peaceful footing.
('62', 412, 1, 10, 823889) However repugnant it might appear to me that those who represent sanatan dharma should resort to such demonstration, I perfectly recognized their right to make such a demonstration yester day at Palghat, and I had no hesitation in making public refe rence at the meeting there to their demonstration more than to the demonstration of those who had come to greet me out of affection for me and sympathy for the cause.
('62', 412, 1, 11, 824306) And I gave then and there the reason for my saying that I appreciated this black flag demonstration more than the demonstration of affection.
('62', 412, 1, 12, 824448) I must not repeat the reason here, but I must refer you to the public speech 1 , if at all it finds publication in any of the local journals.
('62', 412, 1, 13, 824590) Here I want only to say that it was a matter of deep grief to me to find that these two countrymen were hurt, no matter for what cause, no matter by whom.
('62', 412, 1, 14, 824745) If any single volunteer or any single person connected with the organization of this meeting had any hand in assaulting these friends, I have no hesitation in saying that he has disgraced the cause and has hurt Hinduism, which he thought he was serving.
('62', 412, 1, 15, 824999) I have said repeatedly that this cause of Hinduism can only be served by men and women who are above suspicion and who have a character to keep and to lose.
('62', 412, 1, 16, 825156) In a movement of self purification there is no room for a hasty word, for a hasty action, for abuse, certainly not for bodily harm.
('62', 412, 1, 17, 825288) And if there are any persons here present who were instrumental in causing hurt to these countrymen of ours, whose lives should be as dear to you and to me as our own blood relations’, then I invite them to purge themselves of that guilt by making a public declaration of their having done this injury and taking the pledge never to repeat such a dishonourable act.

('62', 413, 1, 2, 825739) Keenly and deeply as I feel the taint of untouchability and deeply as I feel convinced that, if this untouchability is not removed root and branch from Hinduism, Hinduism is bound to perish, I would not have untouchability removed by force or show of force or compulsion of any kind whatsoever.
('62', 413, 1, 3, 826034) Removal of untouchability is not a matter of law or of compulsion.
('62', 413, 1, 4, 826101) Removal of untouchability is a matter of change of heart, perfect purification on the part of millions of Hindus.
('62', 413, 1, 5, 826215) And that can only be brought about by the sacrifice of thousands of workers themselves, and not by causing injury to other people.
('62', 413, 1, 6, 826346) Hence has every scripture that I have read pronounced from the house tops that religion can only be defended by tapascharya.
('62', 413, 1, 7, 826471) I will, therefore, beseech every one of you, who crowd round me wherever I go, to remember that this movement is a movement of personal, individual self purification and self conviction.
('62', 413, 1, 8, 826658) And if you cannot approach this question from that point of view, I would far rather that I was deserted by you and that all the meetings were deserted by you.
('62', 413, 1, 9, 826818) And if any man or woman is eager to come and listen to me or to give me an ounce of milk, he or she should do so, provided he or she has got that complete identification with the cause and a perfect spirit of self purification.
('62', 413, 1, 10, 827046) Having said this and having made this declaration of my faith under the shadow of the great temple of Guruvayur, I would like to make this appeal from the bottom of my heart to those who are organizing the activities of the Varnashrama Swarajya Sangh, and kindred bodies also, to understand that they will not defend what they call sanatan dharma by staging demonstrations of the character that they have been doing.
('62', 413, 1, 11, 827463) They sent a body of men throughout the tour in C. P. who wanted to fall prostrate before the car and impede my progress at every stage.
('62', 413, 1, 12, 827599) There were often clashes between volunteers who were looking after me and this body of six or seven young men.
('62', 413, 1, 13, 827710) Fortunately, no serious or untoward event happened, though scratches certainly were inflicted on either side even during the C. P. tour, I quickly made friends with those people who were staging those obstructive demonstrations and told them as earnestly as I could that that was not the way to protect Hinduism.
('62', 413, 1, 14, 828023) 1 Some of them were youngsters who did not even know what they were doing.
('62', 413, 1, 15, 828098) With the exception of one, I doubt if any of them had any idea of the elements of Hinduism.
('62', 413, 1, 16, 828190) And I had hoped here also that, if there were such men

('62', 414, 1, 2, 828331) who wanted to stage demonstrations, I should come in touch with them, discuss with them, understand them and know who they were.
('62', 414, 1, 3, 828460) But I was sorry that hardly had I put my foot in Malabar when I was faced with the scene that I witnessed here.
('62', 414, 1, 4, 828572) It would have been better if I had been able to make their acquaintance before and ascertained what they wanted to do.
('62', 414, 1, 5, 828691) But they chose to take a different course.
('62', 414, 1, 6, 828734) I still invite them to meet me and tell me what they would exactly want me to do; and, short of stopping this tour, I would make every facility for them, and every convenience for them to express their thoughts or even to make whatever peaceful demonstrations that they might want to stage.
('62', 414, 1, 7, 829025) But what I am most anxious to avoid is goondaism in every shape and form on the part of either party.
('62', 414, 1, 8, 829127) I give the same credit to those who call themselves sanatanists for honesty of purpose that I would claim for myself, but both must have an equal right to give expression to their views and mould public opinion.
('62', 414, 1, 9, 829339) After all, sanatan dharm is not the prerogative of one set of people.
('62', 414, 1, 10, 829409) I claim myself to be a representative of sanatan dharma in every sense of the term that they claim.
('62', 414, 1, 11, 829509) I base my vehement oppo sition to untouchability upon the same Shastras by which they swear, and I should stand by my interpretation of the Shastras even though I were the solitary one amongst the millions of Hindus; because the same Shastras tell me that I may not resist the inner call of my fundamental being.
('62', 414, 1, 12, 829822) Thank God, however, that I do not stand alone in the interpretation that I have been placing before you.
('62', 414, 1, 13, 829927) On the contrary, there are learned shastris who have just as much right to interpret the Shastras as those who call themselves the exponents of sanatan dharma.
('62', 414, 1, 14, 830087) And they give precisely the same interpretation that I have placed before tens of thousands of men and women.
('62', 414, 1, 15, 830197) And it is my settled conviction, based upon an unbroken experience extending over a period of nearly fifty years, that untouchability as we practise it today has absolutely no warrant whatsoever in the Hindu Shastras.
('62', 414, 1, 16, 830415) I claim that Harijans have precisely the same common rights of worship, of use of public institutions and in all other walks of life that the tallest of Hindus enjoy in common with the rest of Hindu mankind.
('62', 414, 1, 17, 830623) And, therefore, I have not the shadow of a doubt that caste Hindu will not have performed their elementary duties by Harijans until they have thrown open the gates of Guruvayur and such ancient temples to the Harijans, precisely on the same terms on which they are open to other Hindus.
('62', 414, 1, 18, 830910) But I have infinite patience; and, as you know, although

('62', 415, 1, 2, 831009) Kelappan’s fast had progressed for many days, although many of these reformers were actually in the temple threatening to declare a sym pathetic fast with Kelappan and although the reformers thought that the prize was almost within their grasp, I sent a peremptory tele gram 1 from my own fasting bed, calling upon Kelappan to suspend the fast and to withdraw the men who were inside the Guruvayur temple.
('62', 415, 1, 3, 831415) And I did so because I felt that the fast was premature and I smelt coercion in it.
('62', 415, 1, 4, 831499) I mention this in order to show that I will not be guilty of being party to the opening of a single temple under coercion.
('62', 415, 1, 5, 831622) But I do want temples to be opened where public opinion is absolutely and clearly ripe for the opening of those temples.
('62', 415, 1, 6, 831743) If there is any legal obstruction in the process, I want that legal obstruction to be removed.
('62', 415, 1, 7, 831838) That is the meaning, and the only meaning, of the Temple entry Bill, and no other.
('62', 415, 1, 8, 831921) This Bill simply removes the power lessness that many trustees today feel about opening the temples under their charge because of the legal obstruction.
('62', 415, 1, 9, 832074) There is not the slightest trace of compulsion or coercion about this Temple entry Bill or the kindred Bill called the Anti untouchability Bill.
('62', 415, 1, 10, 832219) But I heard a whisper this morning that behind this temple entry agitation there is a nefarious design, if not on my part, on the part of my co workers, that we should take possession of these temples and own them.
