('62', 415, 1, 17, 833051) This does not mean endorsement of the claim that the Brahmins, so called, may put forth today.
('62', 415, 1, 18, 833146) No man can be accepted as a Brahmin by society merely by reason of his birth.
('62', 415, 1, 19, 833224) The Shastras themselves say that a born Brahmin who does not act according to the requirements of Brahminism will forfeit his right to be called a Brahmin by the people in general.
('62', 415, 1, 20, 833405) There are Brahmins themselves today in this very movement who say that they cannot be called Brahmins unless they carry out the precepts of the Shastras

('62', 416, 1, 2, 833664) referring to them.
('62', 416, 1, 3, 833683) I believe that the Brahmin is the cornerstone of Hinduism, as of every other religion.
('62', 416, 1, 4, 833770) But there you must understand the meaning of the word Brahmin.
('62', 416, 1, 5, 833833) The Brahmin is the person who has realized Brahman.
('62', 416, 1, 6, 833885) If he has not that realization in every act of his, he shows that he is ever after it and nothing else.
('62', 416, 1, 7, 833989) Such a Brahmin demands my ten thousand prostrations every morning, but not the Brahmin who is dictated by self, who is multiplying himself 1 day after day and thinks mostly of himself, rarely of others, nor even the Brahmin who smears himself with ashes from top to toe and can punctiliously and correctly recite the Vedas.
('62', 416, 1, 8, 834313) It may be necessary for him to smear himself with ashes.

('62', 418, 1, 2, 838687) 449. SPEECH AT PATTAMBI 1
('62', 418, 2, 3, 838713) January 11, 1934
('62', 418, 3, 4, 838730) It has given me some surprise that in Malabar, the land of eternal green, you have to use artificial paper flowers.
('62', 418, 3, 5, 838846) I thought that in Malabar, where Nature has been so beneficent to you, you could avoid all artificiality.
('62', 418, 3, 6, 838952) But I suppose that in order to appreciate the beauty of this land you require the help of a person who comes from a treeless desert as I do.
('62', 418, 3, 7, 839093) Just as you have gone in for artificiality in the matter of flowers, you go in for artificiality in the matter of untouchability, and then you think that that artificial product comes from Divinity itself.
('62', 418, 3, 8, 839299) I have come to warn you against the belief that untouchability, unapproachability or invisibility can have any divine sanction.
('62', 418, 3, 9, 839427) In my opinion it is one of the greatest sins that we, Hindus, have been committing against man and God.
('62', 418, 3, 10, 839531) You degrade human beings, as we have been doing in this part of the world, and then to say that they are what they are because of their past deeds is a complete caricature of the law of karma.
('62', 418, 3, 11, 839724) I claim to know somewhat, from first hand evidence, of the working of the law of karma, because practically a period of fifty years I have devoted to find out what this law of karma could be.
('62', 418, 3, 12, 839916) And this much I do know that to apply it to everybody else but ourselves is to distort it altogether; and if I had more time than I have at my disposal, I could show to the satisfaction of every one of you that you can never apply the law of karma as you apply it to the Nayadis and others.
('62', 418, 3, 13, 840207) If we were to apply the law of karma as I have suggested, that is to say, towards ourselves, you would find the land here and elsewhere transformed.
('62', 418, 3, 14, 840356) I have, therefore, come to beseech every one of you to exorcize this ghost of untouchability.
('62', 418, 3, 15, 840450) If you do not, you may be sure that that ghost will eat us up.
('62', 418, 3, 16, 840513) Harijan, 19 1 1934

('62', 420, 1, 2, 843455) that there is no warrant in the Shastras for untouchability as it is practised today.

('62', 424, 1, 2, 851908) 454. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, TELLICHERRY 1
('62', 424, 2, 3, 851953) January 13, 1934
('62', 424, 3, 4, 851970) FRIENDS, I am very much obliged to you for the addresses and the purse you have presented to me.
('62', 424, 3, 5, 852067) You know the nature of the mission at the present moment taking me from one end of India to the other.
('62', 424, 3, 6, 852170) In pursuance of that mission early this morning I have come here to ask you to rid yourselves of the devil of untouchability from your hearts.
('62', 424, 3, 7, 852313) I see in all your addresses there is one note running, namely, that this monster of untouchability might be laid low.
('62', 424, 3, 8, 852431) Let us not make the mistake of supposing that this is a work that has got to be done by somebody else.
('62', 424, 3, 9, 852534) It is essentially a work that has got to be done by everybody—by himself or herself—for it is a matter essentially of a change of heart on the part of the caste Hindus or savarna Hindus as they are called.
('62', 424, 3, 10, 852740) They have to cease to think that they are caste Hindus or that some of them are savarnas and others avarnas.
('62', 424, 3, 11, 852849) This distinction of high and low has destroyed society altogether and as we want to save ourselves from impending destruction, we must cease to think that anybody on earth is lower than ourselves.
('62', 424, 3, 12, 853046) The poison of untouchability has spread so far and so wide that even amongst caste and caste there is a grave degree of untouchabilty.
('62', 424, 3, 13, 853181) In this distinction of high and low, we have gone further, and the poison has enveloped all the communities.
('62', 424, 3, 14, 853290) There is untouc hability not merely amongst Hindus and Hindus, savarnas and avarnas, savarnas and savarnas, but there is untouchability also between Hindus, Muslims, Parsis, and Christians.
('62', 424, 3, 15, 853480) I am convinced that, whilst there may be other reasons for inter communal quarrels, I have no doubt whatsoever that untouc hability is the main and deciding reason for the majority of these quarrels.
('62', 424, 3, 16, 853680) Therefore, if we will exorcize this principal manifestation of the devil of untouchability, I have not even a shadow of doubt that we will be able to right the wrong all along the line.
('62', 424, 3, 17, 853866) One of your addresses mentions that most of the temples are not open to Harijans and that only one temple, opened by the followers of Shri Narayana Guru, is open to Harijans.
('62', 424, 3, 18, 854041) I congratula te the trustees of the temple on their liberality and I hope that their example will be followed by other trustees; but it will largely depend upon the temple going public to bring about that change.
('62', 424, 3, 19, 854254) If the temple goers are sincerely penitent
('62', 424, 4, 20, 854297) 1 The meeting, which was attended by more than 6,000 people, was held at the Tellicherry maidan at 7.30 a.
('62', 425, 0, 1, 854404) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 426
('62', 425, 1, 2, 854446) and feel that hitherto they have done serious wrongs to Harijans by prohibiting them from entering the temples, I have no doubt that their expression of opinion cannot be challenged and the temples will be soon opened.
('62', 425, 1, 3, 854665) I am therefore hoping that you will organize public opinion so that the temples may soon be opened to Harijans precisely on the same terms as they are open to other Hindus.
('62', 425, 1, 4, 854838) I am surprised to discover that there was in some place near here bad blood between untouchables and untouchables, that is between Pulayas and Thiyyas.
('62', 425, 1, 5, 854990) I do hope that the Harijans all over will set their house in order and rid themselves of untouchability within untouchability.
('62', 425, 1, 6, 855117) Now you have given me this purse which I only consider as a token of your determination to deal with this evil in a final manner.

('62', 425, 4, 10, 855323) FRIENDS, I have a peculiar pleasure in being in your midst since you are in a part of French India.
('62', 425, 4, 11, 855423) I had the pleasure of visiting Chandanagore in Bengal more than once.
('62', 425, 4, 12, 855493) But this is my first visit to French India in this part of the country.
('62', 425, 4, 13, 855565) For me whether it is French India or British India it is one and the same country.
('62', 425, 4, 14, 855648) The same blood flows through my veins that goes through yours, the same soil, the same atmosphere, the same manners and customs and many things too numerous to mention are common to all of us.
('62', 425, 4, 15, 855841) But for the difference in the uniform of your police and the French language I read here and there I would notice no difference whatsoever.
('62', 425, 4, 16, 855981) Therefore it is a matter of no surprise to me that you have, whilst I am passing through Malabar, invited me and presented me with a purse for the Harijan cause.
('62', 425, 4, 17, 856143) Indeed I would have been surprised, and painfully surprised, if I had found that, whilst I was actually passing through this road, you took no notice whatsoever of the self styled representative of the Harijans.
('62', 425, 4, 18, 856355) Therefore I am glad to be able to be present in your midst even though it is only for a few minutes.

SPEECH AT OPENING OF DISPENSARY, PAKKANARPURAM January 13, 1934 I have been invited to open the dispensary that you see in front of you in the name of a young brave worker who sacrificed himself for the sake of his country and died some years ago in about 1921. ('62', 426, 2, 22, 859116) Whilst giving medical relief, providing for education and arranging for free water supply are

('62', 447, 0, 1, 902406) 448 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 447, 1, 2, 902448) 475. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, TRICHUR January 17, 1934
('62', 447, 2, 3, 902504) FRIENDS, It gives me very great pleasure to renew my acquaintance with you after so many years.
('62', 447, 2, 4, 902600) But that pleasure is not unmixed with pain because of the fact that in an enlightened State like Cochin untouchability is still flourishing.
('62', 447, 2, 5, 902741) It was perhaps whilst I was driving through the streets of Trichur this morning, to speak a few words to you, that I saw a Nayadi in flesh and blood.
('62', 447, 2, 6, 902891) He was shivering with fear.
('62', 447, 2, 7, 902919) It was a sign of humiliation for you, for me and for all Hindus.
('62', 447, 2, 8, 902984) It is high time that you wipe out that shame.
('62', 447, 2, 9, 903030) It is also a shame for us that there should be even at this stage men—I don’t know anything about women—defending untouchability, unapproachability and invisibility in the name of religion.
('62', 447, 2, 10, 903220) I venture to suggest to you that throughout the civilized world such a sin cannot possibly be hinted at in the name of religion.
('62', 447, 2, 11, 903349) His Highness the Maharaja by himself cannot possibly change your hearts, and I would be wholly wrong were I to go away with the belief that untouchability could be removed by a stroke of the pen.
('62', 447, 2, 12, 903545) Nor can this change be brought about by any sort of compulsion.
('62', 447, 2, 13, 903609) Therefore I would say to our sanatanists, or rather those who call themselves ‘sanatanists’, that they need not fear the propaganda that I am carrying on.
('62', 447, 2, 14, 903764) I have to appeal to your reason and to your hearts and urge you to do your best.
('62', 447, 2, 15, 903845) The Hindus claim to be essentially a nation of toleration.
('62', 447, 2, 16, 903904) And if there is such a thing as untouchability in Hinduism, it will become a religion of intolerance.
('62', 447, 2, 17, 904006) I therefore respectfully put to those who are today intending to do this propaganda against untouchability to wipe out this blot on Hinduism.
('62', 447, 2, 18, 904148) I have received several letters on this matter and most of the pricking letters that I have received on this problem are from Travancore and Cochin.
('62', 447, 2, 19, 904297) One word to reformers.
('62', 447, 2, 20, 904320) If we have sense of our own conviction, if we only understand the sanatanists, we should tolerate what our brethren may say of us.
('62', 447, 2, 21, 904451) After all it will depend upon the character of the reformers as to what is to be the nature of the reform that they are making.
('62', 447, 2, 22, 904579) The goal of this campaign against untouchability depends on the purity of the reformers in this campaign.
('62', 447, 2, 23, 904685) If they stick to their present character and ceaselessly endeavour in their task, then this monster of untouchability will be wiped out.
('62', 447, 2, 24, 904822) But patience is required
('62', 448, 0, 1, 904847) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 449
('62', 448, 1, 2, 904894) on the part of the reformers.
('62', 448, 1, 3, 904924) Surely, they must not lose faith though there is no support from the surroundings.
('62', 448, 1, 4, 905007) One word to Hindi friends.
('62', 448, 1, 5, 905034) I really expected that there would be so much atmosphere in Malabar about Hindi and so many Hindi scholars, that it would be easy for me to speak in Hindi altogether.
('62', 448, 1, 6, 905201) I was astonished, however, to find that there was no translator who would translate my Hindi speech, and there was so much disinclination on the part of the audience to allow a Hindi speech.
('62', 448, 1, 7, 905392) May I suggest to you that this disinclination also bars our way to progress in the campaign against untouchability?
('62', 448, 1, 8, 905508) I shall simply put it in one sentence.
('62', 448, 1, 9, 905547) There must be exchange of workers between North and South.
('62', 448, 1, 10, 905606) Though we have an inexhaustible supply of workers amongst the Hindi speaking people, if workers from the North cannot possibly come here and explain, it becomes an impossible barrier.
('62', 448, 1, 11, 905790) You may retort, ‘what about you when you go to the North?
('62', 448, 1, 12, 905848) Why should not they understand our speech?’ If you will think a little deeper, you will realize that it is an impossible demand.
('62', 448, 1, 13, 905977) Among Malayalam, Telugu, Canarese, Tamil, what speech should the Northerner adopt?
('62', 448, 1, 14, 906060) I am myself a lover of all Indian languages.
('62', 448, 1, 15, 906105) And I have attempted at the age of sixty five to learn all these languages.
('62', 448, 1, 16, 906181) I have become a special lover of Southern languages.
('62', 448, 1, 17, 906234) But my intimate knowledge of this state of affairs demands that, if we are to work for such reform as [eradication of] untouchability, a common knowledge of Hindi is absolutely indispensable, because it is a language spoken by twenty crores out of thirty crores of people, and since we call ourselves Indians we can expect the thirty crores to try to understand the speech of twenty crores of people.
('62', 448, 1, 18, 906635) The Hindu, 19 1 1934
('62', 448, 2, 19, 906656) 476. SPEECH AT KURUKKANCHERI 1
('62', 448, 3, 20, 906687) January 17, 1934 It is a matter of exceedingly great pleasure for me to renew your acquaintance.
('62', 448, 3, 21, 906784) The names Ezhavas and Thiyyas are not new to me at all, nor is the name of Shri Narayana Guru new to me.
('62', 448, 3, 22, 906889) I had the honour of meeting him and having long discussions with him while he was on this earth.
('62', 448, 3, 23, 906986) It was at that time I came in close contact with many Ezhavas and Thiyyas.
('62', 448, 3, 24, 907061) I met the leaders and had many friendly discussions with them.
('62', 448, 3, 25, 907124) 1 have very pleasant recollections of the
('62', 448, 4, 26, 907166) 1 This was in reply to the address of welcome by Thiyya Harijans.
('62', 448, 4, 27, 907232) A report of the speech was also published in The Hindu, 19 1 1934.
('62', 449, 0, 1, 907299) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 449, 1, 2, 907341) affection I received from them without exception.
('62', 449, 1, 3, 907391) Since then constant correspondence has been kept up between them and myself.
('62', 449, 1, 4, 907468) Whilst some have differed from the view I have expressed, their affection has not suffered in any way.
('62', 449, 1, 5, 907571) I treasure that affection.
('62', 449, 1, 6, 907598) Therefore I am glad that I am once more in your midst.
('62', 449, 1, 7, 907653) I have carefully read the whole of your address.
('62', 449, 1, 8, 907702) All the remarks that you have made about the institution of caste, as you have interpreted it, have my fullest sympathy.
('62', 449, 1, 9, 907823) But you know from your experience that the vast majority of questions in this world have at least two sides.
('62', 449, 1, 10, 907932) They appear differently and bear different meanings also.
('62', 449, 1, 11, 907990) Caste, in so far as it is based on untouchability, is an institution of the devil, and we must get rid of it at any cost.
('62', 449, 1, 12, 908112) But I have explained repeatedly that caste expressed as varnadharma is an eternal law which we may not break except at our own risk.
('62', 449, 1, 13, 908245) There are many laws of Nature, which are still hidden from us.
('62', 449, 1, 14, 908308) That does not mean that they are not in existence or that they do not operate in our lives.
('62', 449, 1, 15, 908400) The law of varna was discovered by our ancestors ages ago; and, as I have understood and interpreted it, it has appeared to me a wholly beneficent law.
('62', 449, 1, 16, 908552) But like many laws and institutions of Nature this law of varna has been distorted, and we see it today in its hideous form.
('62', 449, 1, 17, 908677) Man—Hindu man—has disfigured it and made it doubly hideous by tainting it with untouchability.
('62', 449, 1, 18, 908772) Varnadharma is an economic law.
('62', 449, 1, 19, 908804) It is my certain conviction that, if the whole world followed that law, the strife that we see around us would cease at once.
('62', 449, 1, 20, 908930) It is pre eminently a law of concord, never of discord.
('62', 449, 1, 21, 908986) But I have not come here to give you a dissertation on the law of the varna.
('62', 449, 1, 22, 909063) I simply want to say that I am in full agreement with you in your fight against untouchability.
('62', 449, 1, 23, 909159) I entirely endorse your remarks that it has corrupted not Hindu society alone, but has affected other societies also.
('62', 449, 1, 24, 909277) The assumption of superiority of one class over another is a poison slowly killing us.
('62', 449, 1, 25, 909364) When Narayana Guru Swami enunciated his formula of one caste, one religion and one God, he had, in my opinion, no other meaning in his mind.
('62', 449, 1, 26, 909505) He said, ‘I will not tolerate this assumption of superiority on the part of anybody.’ I do not recall in my many discussions with him that he had anything to say against the beneficent interpretation of varnadharma that I have given.
('62', 449, 1, 27, 909739) Let us not, therefore, destroy the tree for its bad or poisonous branches.
('62', 449, 1, 28, 909814) If you know anything whatsoever of gardening, you know that a gardener who finds diseased branches prunes them.
('62', 449, 1, 29, 909926) He deals with the whole tree if he finds the tree rotten at the root.
('62', 449, 1, 30, 909996) He will be considered a foolish gardener deserving summary dismissal who,
('62', 450, 0, 1, 910070) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 451
('62', 450, 1, 2, 910117) because he sees some diseased branches, lays the axe at the root.
('62', 450, 1, 3, 910183) In our society let us act as wise gardeners.
('62', 450, 1, 4, 910228) Let us understand the disease that is corroding Hinduism.
('62', 450, 1, 5, 910286) Let us get rid of untouchability or, in other words, of the evil of superiority and inferiority.
('62', 450, 1, 6, 910383) Let us first get rid of this evil and purify our hearts.
('62', 450, 1, 7, 910440) And when we shall have successfully done so, we shall be able to pronounce opinion on the working of the law of varna as I have explained it.
('62', 450, 1, 8, 910582) Today we know it chiefly as a species of untouchability.
('62', 450, 1, 9, 910639) Lastly, it is my conviction, and I want you to be infected with that conviction, that untouchability as I have described it to you is fast going.
('62', 450, 1, 10, 910785) And if you are fired by that conviction, I want you to put forth your best effort to exorcize that devil.
('62', 450, 1, 11, 910891) Harijan, 9 2 1934
('62', 450, 2, 12, 910909) 477. SPEECH AT UNION CHRISTIAN COLLEGE, ALWAYE January 17, 1934 It is a matter of great pleasure to me to renew acquaintance with the students and professors of this college.
('62', 450, 2, 13, 911084) I have very pleasant recollections of my meeting with the students that were in the college at the time of my first visit.
('62', 450, 2, 14, 911207) It was good of you to think of me while I was passing through this part of the country.
('62', 450, 3, 15, 911295) My message is exceedingly simple.
('62', 450, 3, 16, 911329) It is no new truth that has dawned upon me today.
('62', 450, 3, 17, 911379) I have to the best of my ability striven to live up to it for the past fifty years.
('62', 450, 3, 18, 911463) And the more I have succeeded in living up to it, the greater has been my inward joy.
('62', 450, 3, 19, 911549) Nor is it for the first time that I am delivering this message to India.
('62', 450, 3, 20, 911622) But because of some incidents in the recent past, it comes to the people as a new thing.
('62', 450, 3, 21, 911711) My message is simply this that savarna Hindus, who have been considering themselves superior to those whom they have called untouchables, unapproachables, invisibles or avarna Hindus, should realize that this arrogation of superiority has no sanction whatsoever in the Shastras.
('62', 450, 3, 22, 911990) If I discovered that those scriptures, which are known as Vedas, Upanishads, Bhagavad Gita, Smritis, etc., clearly showed that they claimed divine authority for untouchability as I have described it to you, then nothing on this earth would hold me to Hinduism.
('62', 450, 3, 23, 912251) I should throw it overboard as I should throw overboard a rotten apple.
('62', 450, 3, 24, 912323) My reason is offended and my heart is wounded at the
('62', 451, 0, 1, 912376) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('62', 451, 1, 2, 912418) very thought that God Himself, who has created both savarna Hindus and avarna Hindus, should impose this bar sinister between His children.
('62', 451, 1, 3, 912558) The very thought that the rishis, who gave the Vedas and the Upanishads and who in every mantra that they pronounced taught the unity of God, could ever conceive of any such thing as untouchability as it is practised today in Hinduism must be repugnant to every intelligent person.
('62', 451, 1, 4, 912840) But prejudices and superstitions die hard.
('62', 451, 1, 5, 912883) They cloud the reason, befog the intellect and harden the heart.
('62', 451, 1, 6, 912948) And so you find learned men defending this untouchability.
('62', 451, 2, 7, 913007) But you, students, should know that behind this message there lurks also a much greater message.
('62', 451, 2, 8, 913104) This monster of untouchability has invaded every form of society in India; and the idea behind this message is that there should be not only no untouchability as between Hindus and Hindus, but that there should be no untouchability whatsoever between Hindus, Christians, Mussalmans, Parsis and the rest.
('62', 451, 2, 9, 913408) I am convinced that, if this great change of heart can be brought about among millions of savarna Hindus and their hearts can be purified—as certainly they will be purified—we should live in India as people trusting each other and without any mutual distrust or suspicion.
('62', 451, 2, 10, 913681) It is untouchability with all its subtle forms that separates us from one another and makes life itself unlovely and difficult to live.
('62', 451, 3, 11, 913817) You can now, therefore, understand why I am drawing upon the sympathy of all Indians, to whatever faith they may belong.
('62', 451, 3, 12, 913938) Indeed I have not hesitated to ask the support of the whole world, not by way of pecuniary offering but by their sympathy, their prayers and their study of the question with all its implications.
('62', 451, 3, 13, 914134) I want their heart symp athy, which is infinitely greater than any pecuniary offering.
('62', 451, 3, 14, 914221) I do not stretch out my hand before them for money because they are not debtors to Harijans.
('62', 451, 3, 15, 914314) It is for savarna Hindus to discharge this debt.
('62', 451, 4, 16, 914363) To conclude, this prayerful support and sympathy can only be given by non Hindus, if they have no distrust of this movement and if they are satisfied that this is a movement of inward purification and deeply religious.
('62', 451, 4, 17, 914582) Remember that I have not idly given this message which has come straight from the heart.
('62', 451, 4, 18, 914671) I have gladly taken your purse which is a spontaneous offering from you.
('62', 451, 4, 19, 914744) But I have accepted it as a bond between you and myself and as a token of your
('62', 452, 0, 1, 914823) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1933 17 JANUARY, 1934 453
('62', 452, 1, 2, 914870) determination to give me the fullest support you are capable of giving.
('62', 452, 1, 3, 914942) And since I am a good accountant, I shall ask an account from you and shall want to know from time to time what part you have played in this movement.
('62', 452, 2, 4, 915093) Harijan, 26 1 1934

('62', 454, 22, 34, 917672) (B) CIRCULAR RE : CHANGE IN TOUR PROGRAMME
('62', 454, 23, 35, 917715) CAMP WARDHA, November 7, 1933
('62', 454, 24, 36, 917745) DEAR FRIEND,
('62', 454, 25, 37, 917758) RE: CHANGE IN GANDHIJI’S PROGRAMME
('62', 454, 26, 38, 917793) It has been found necessary, quite unavoidable, to make a substantial alteration in
('62', 454, 27, 39, 917877) the order of the programme of Mahatmaji’s proposed tour, extending over 9 months— November 1933 to July 1934. After touring in the Central Provinces, where the tour has commenced from today, and after attending the Central Board meeting at Delhi— December 10 to 14—he will go directly to Andhra, and the rest of the Madras Presidency, instead of going up to the Punjab, Sind, etc., and will thereafter work his way to Bengal and Assam and then westward.
('62', 454, 27, 40, 918331) The new order will, therefore, be as follows :
('62', 454, 28, 41, 918378) C. P., Delhi, Andhra, Madras City, Mysore States and Malabar District, Cochin
('62', 454, 29, 42, 918456) and Travancore, Tamil Nadu, Orissa, Calcutta, Bengal, Assam, Bihar, U.P., Punjab, Sind and Rajputana, Gujarat and Kathiawar, Bombay City, Maharashtra and Hyderabad Dn., and Karanataka at the end of July 1934.
('62', 455, 0, 1, 918665) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 456
('62', 455, 1, 2, 918707) The dates of the tour in the various provinces and other details are given in the
('62', 455, 2, 3, 918789) sub–joined table.
('62', 455, 2, 4, 918807) The details of the tour in each province will be settled and filled up by the Provincial Secretaries in consultation with their Presidents in accordance with detailed instructions already issued.
('62', 455, 2, 5, 919003) But the four elementary rules to be observed are mentioned below :
('62', 455, 3, 6, 919070) (1)There should be full four hours cessation of public work for meals and
('62', 455, 4, 7, 919144) correspondence in the middle of the day, preferably from 10.0 a.m.
('62', 455, 4, 8, 919211) to 2.0 p.m.
('62', 455, 5, 9, 919223) (2)The day’s work should not begin earlier than 6.30 a.m.
('62', 455, 5, 10, 919281) and not [continue] later
('62', 455, 6, 11, 919306) than 8.0 p.m.
('62', 455, 7, 12, 919320) (3)Railway journey is any day preferable to motor journey, but where the latter is
('62', 455, 8, 13, 919403) unavoidable, it should not exceed 75 miles in one day.
('62', 455, 9, 14, 919458) (4)Mondays and Tuesdays in every week are non–working days and should be
('62', 455, 10, 15, 919531) kept free of any travelling or public engagement.
('62', 455, 10, 16, 919581) To be accurate, the period from 8 p.m.
('62', 455, 10, 17, 919620) on Sunday to 8 p.m.
('62', 455, 10, 18, 919640) on Tuesday is reserved, 24 hours for silence and 24 hours for correspondence and other work.

('62', 456, 17, 18, 921376) APPENDIX II
('62', 456, 18, 19, 921388) MOHAMMED IQBAL’S STATEMENT 1
('62', 456, 19, 20, 921417) LAHORE,
('62', 456, 20, 21, 921425) December 6, 1933
('62', 456, 21, 22, 921442) “The offer made by the Aga Khan to Mr. Gandhi in London in 1931 still holds
('62', 456, 22, 23, 921518) If under Pandit Jawaharlal’s leadership, the Hindus and the Congress agree to the safeguards which the Muslims think necessary for their protection as an all–India minority, the Muslim community will still be ready to serve as camp–followers of the majority community in India’s political struggle” says Sir Mohammed Iqbal in a statement issued today referring to Pandit Jawaharlal’s charges against the communalist Muslim leaders.
('62', 456, 23, 24, 921950) Sir Mohammed Iqbal observes that the Aga Khan made a similar offer to Mr.
('62', 456, 24, 25, 922024) Gandhi in 1932 but Mr. Gandhi would not guarantee acceptance of his position by the Congress and also the Hindu and Sikh delegates did not endorse Mr. Gandhi’s position and further Mr. Gandhi wanted the Muslims not to support the untouchables’ claims.
('62', 456, 24, 26, 922276) After explaining the Muslim attitude towards nationalism and democracy, Sir Mohammed Iqbal puts the straight question to Pandit Jawaharlal, “How is India’s problem to be solved if the majority community neither concedes the minimum necessary safeguards to the minority community, nor accepts a third party’s award ?
('62', 456, 24, 27, 922592) The position can admit of two alternatives only.
('62', 456, 24, 28, 922641) Either, India’s majority community must accept for
('62', 456, 25, 29, 922692) 1 Vide “ Wanted a Manifestation of Christ in Daily Life” , 30 3 1934
('62', 457, 0, 1, 922761) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 458
('62', 457, 1, 2, 922803) itself the permanent position of an agent of British imperialism in the East or India should be redistributed on the basis of religious, historical and cultural affinities so as to do away with the question of electorates and the communal problems in its present form.”
('62', 457, 2, 3, 923073) The Bombay Chronicle, 7–12–1933
('62', 457, 3, 4, 923105) APPENDIX III
('62', 457, 4, 5, 923118) EXTRACTS FROM JAWAHARLAL NEHRU’S STATEMENT 1
('62', 457, 5, 6, 923163) I do not think that the Muslim communal organizations, chief of whom are the
('62', 457, 6, 7, 923240) Muslim All–Parties Conference and the Muslim League, represent any large group of Muslims in India except in the sense that they exploit the prevailing communal sentiment.
('62', 457, 6, 8, 923412) But the fact remains that they claim to speak for Muslims, and no other organization has so far risen which can successfully challenge that claim.
('62', 457, 6, 9, 923559) Their aggressively communal character gives them a pull over the large number of nationalist Muslims who merge themselves in the Congress.
('62', 457, 6, 10, 923698) The leaders of these organizations are patently and intensely communal.
('62', 457, 6, 11, 923770) That, from the very nature of things, one can understand.
('62', 457, 7, 12, 923828) But it is equally obvious that most of them are definitely anti–national and
('62', 457, 8, 13, 923905) political reactionaries of the worst kind.
('62', 457, 8, 14, 923948) Apparently they do not even look forward to any common nation developing in India.
('62', 457, 9, 15, 924031) At a meeting in the British House of Commons last year the Aga Khan, Sir
('62', 457, 10, 16, 924104) Mohammed Iqbal and Dr. Shafaat Ahmad Khan are reported (in The Statesman of December 31, 1932) to have laid stress on “the inherent impossibility of securing any merger of Hindu and Moslem, political, or indeed, social, interests”.
('62', 457, 10, 17, 924336) The speakers further pointed out “the impracticability of ever governing India through anything but a British agency”.
('62', 457, 10, 18, 924455) These statements leave no loophole for nationalism or for Indian freedom, now or even in the remote future.
('62', 457, 11, 19, 924563) I do not think that these statements represent the views of Muslims generally or
('62', 457, 12, 20, 924644) even of most of the communally inclined Muslims.
('62', 457, 12, 21, 924693) But they are undoubtedly the views of the dominant and politically clamorous group among the Muslims.
('62', 457, 12, 22, 924795) It is an insult to one’s intelligence to link these views with those of nationalism and freedom, and of course any measure of real economic freedom is still further away from them.
('62', 457, 12, 23, 924976) Essentially, this is an attitude of pure reaction—political, cultural, national, social.
('62', 457, 12, 24, 925065) And it is not surprising that this should be so if one examines the membership of these organizations.
('62', 457, 12, 25, 925168) Most of the leading members are Government officials, ex–officials, ministers, would–be ministers, knights and title–holders, big landlords, etc.
('62', 457, 12, 26, 925314) Their leader is the Aga Khan, the head of a wealthy religious group, who combines in himself, most remarkably, the feudal order and the politics and habits of the British ruling class, with which he has been intimately associated for many years.
('62', 457, 13, 27, 925560) Such being the leadership of the Muslims in India and at the Round Table
('62', 457, 14, 28, 925633) 1 Vide “ Wanted a Manifestation of Christ in Daily Life” , 30 3 1934
('62', 458, 0, 1, 925702) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1934 17 JANUARY, 1934 459
('62', 458, 1, 2, 925749) Conference it is no wonder that their attitude should be reactionary.
('62', 458, 1, 3, 925819) This reactionary policy went so far as to lead many of the Muslim delegates in London to seek an alliance with the most reactionary elements in British public life—Lord Lloyd and company.
('62', 458, 1, 4, 926007) And the final touch was given to it when Gandhiji offered personally to accept every single one of their communal demands, however illogical and exaggerated they might be, on condition that they assured him of their full support in the political struggle for independence.
('62', 458, 1, 5, 926280) That condition and offer were not accepted and it became clear that what stood in the way was not even communalism but political reaction.
('62', 458, 2, 6, 926419) Personally I think that it is generally possible to co–operate with communalists
('62', 458, 3, 7, 926500) provided the political objective is the same.
('62', 458, 3, 8, 926546) But between progress and reaction, between those who struggle for freedom and those who are content with servitude, and even wish to prolong it, there is no meeting ground.
('62', 458, 3, 9, 926719) And it is this political reaction which has stalked the land under cover of communalism and taken advantage of the fear of each community of the other.
('62', 458, 3, 10, 926871) It is the fear complex that we have to deal with in these communal problems.
('62', 458, 3, 11, 926948) Honest communalism is fear; false communalism is political reaction.
('62', 458, 4, 12, 927017) To some extent this fear is justified, or is at least understandable, in a minority
('62', 458, 5, 13, 927101) community.
('62', 458, 5, 14, 927112) We see this fear overshadowing the communal sky in India as a whole so far as Muslims are concerned; we see it as an equally potent force in the Punjab and Sind so far as the Hindus are concerned, and in the Punjab the Sikhs.
('62', 458, 6, 15, 927338) It was natural for the British Government to support and push on the reactionary
('62', 458, 7, 16, 927419) leaders of the Muslims and to try to ignore the nationalist ones.
('62', 458, 7, 17, 927485) It was also natural for
('62', 458, 8, 18, 927509) them to accede to most of their demands in order to strengthen their position in their own
('62', 458, 9, 19, 927600) community and weaken the national struggle.
('62', 458, 9, 20, 927644) A very little knowledge of history will
('62', 458, 10, 21, 927684) show that this has always been done by ruling powers.
('62', 458, 10, 22, 927738) The Muslim demands did not in
('62', 458, 11, 23, 927768) any way lessen the control of the British in India.
('62', 458, 11, 24, 927820) To some extent they helped the British
('62', 458, 12, 25, 927859) to add to their proposed special powers and to show to the world how necessary their
('62', 458, 13, 26, 927944) continued presence in India was.
('62', 458, 14, 27, 927977) I have written all this about the attitude of the Muslim communalist leaders not
('62', 458, 15, 28, 928058) only to complete the picture but because it is a necessary preliminary to the
('62', 458, 16, 29, 928136) understanding of the Hindu communal attitude.
('62', 458, 16, 30, 928182) There is no essential difference between
('62', 458, 17, 31, 928223) the two.
('62', 458, 17, 32, 928232) But there was this difference that the Congress drew into its ranks most of the
('62', 458, 18, 33, 928312) vital elements of Hindu society and it dominated the situation and thus circumstances did
('62', 458, 19, 34, 928402) not permit the Hindu communalists to play an important role in politics.
('62', 458, 19, 35, 928475) The Hindu
('62', 458, 20, 36, 928485) Mahasabha leaders largely confined themselves to criticizing the Congress.
('62', 458, 21, 37, 928560) however there was a lull in Congress activities, automatically the Hindu communalists
('62', 458, 22, 38, 928646) came more to the front and their attitude was frankly reactionary.
('62', 458, 23, 39, 928713) It must be remembered that the communalism of a majority community must of
('62', 459, 0, 1, 928788) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 460
('62', 459, 1, 2, 928830) necessity bear a closer resemblance to nationalism than the communalism of a minority group.
('62', 459, 1, 3, 928923) One of the best tests of its true nature is what relation it bears to the national struggle.
('62', 459, 1, 4, 929016) If it is politically reactionary or lays stress on communal problems rather than national ones, then it is obviously anti–national.
('62', 459, 2, 5, 929148) I cannot hold the Mahasabha responsible for these statements 1 but as a matter of
('62', 459, 3, 6, 929230) fact they fit in with, and are only a slight elaboration of, the Mahasabha attitude.
('62', 459, 3, 7, 929315) And they bear out that many Hindu communalists are definitely thinking on the lines of co– operation with British imperialism in the hope of getting favours.
('62', 459, 3, 8, 929473) It requires little argument to show that this attitude is not only narrowly communal but also anti–national and intensely reactionary.
('62', 459, 4, 9, 929608) It is perfectly true that Hindu Mahasabha has stood for joint electorates right
('62', 459, 5, 10, 929688) through its career and this is obviously the only national solution of the problem.
('62', 459, 5, 11, 929772) It is also true that the Communal Award is an utter negation of nationalism and is meant to separate India into communal compartments and give strength to disruptive tendencies and thus to strengthen the hold of British imperialism.
('62', 459, 5, 12, 930005) But it must be borne in mind that nationalism cannot be accepted only when it profits the majority community.
('62', 459, 5, 13, 930115) The test comes in the provinces where there is a Muslim majority and in that test the Hindu Mahasabha has failed.
('62', 459, 6, 14, 930229) Nor is it enough to blame Muslim communalists.
('62', 459, 6, 15, 930276) It is easy enough to do so for
('62', 459, 7, 16, 930307) Indian Muslims as a whole are unhappily very backward and compare unfavourably with Muslims in all other countries.
('62', 459, 7, 17, 930423) The point is that a special responsibility does attach to the Hindus in India both because they are the majority community and because economically and educationally they are more advanced.
('62', 459, 7, 18, 930613) The Mahasabha, instead of discharging that responsibility, has acted in a manner which has undoubtedly increased the communalism of the Muslims and made them distrust the Hindus all the more.
('62', 459, 7, 19, 930805) The only way it has tried to meet their communalism is by its own variety of communalism.
('62', 459, 7, 20, 930895) One communalism does not end the other; each feeds on the other and both fatten.
('62', 459, 8, 21, 930976) I cannot say what following the Hindu or Muslim communal organizations have.
('62', 459, 9, 22, 931053) It is possible that in a moment of communal excitement each side may command the allegience of considerable numbers.
('62', 459, 9, 23, 931170) But I do submit that on both sides these organizations represent the rich upper class groups and the struggle for communal advantages is really an attempt of these groups to take as big a share of power and privilege for themselves as possible.
('62', 459, 9, 24, 931415) At the most, it means jobs for a few of our unemployed intellectuals.
('62', 459, 9, 25, 931485) How do these communal demands meet the needs of the masses ?
('62', 459, 9, 26, 931546) What is the programme of the Hindu Mahasabha or the Muslim League for the workers, the peasants and the lower middle classes, which form the great bulk of the nation ?
('62', 459, 9, 27, 931714) They have no programme except a negative one, as the Mahasabha hinted at Ajmer, of not disturbing the present social order.
('62', 459, 9, 28, 931838) This in itself shows that the controlling
('62', 459, 10, 29, 931880) 1 Made by Bhai Parmanand, Dr. Moonje and others
('62', 460, 0, 1, 931928) VOL. 62 : 8 OCTOBER, 1934 17 JANUARY, 1934 461
('62', 460, 1, 2, 931975) forces of these communal organizations are the upper class possessing social groups today.
('62', 460, 1, 3, 932066) The Muslim communalists tell us a great deal about the democracy of Islam but are afraid of democracy in practice; the Hindu communalists talk of nationalism and think in terms of a “Hindu Nationalism”.
('62', 460, 2, 4, 932269) Personally I an convinced that Nationalism can only come out of the ideological
('62', 460, 3, 5, 932349) fusion of Hindu, Muslim, Sikh and other groups in India.
('62', 460, 3, 6, 932406) That does not and need not
('62', 460, 4, 7, 932433) mean the extinction of any real culture of any group, but it does mean a common national
('62', 460, 5, 8, 932522) outlook, to which other matters are subordinated.
('62', 460, 5, 9, 932572) I do not think that Hindu–Muslim or other unity will come merely by reciting [it] 1 like a mantra.
('62', 460, 5, 10, 932671) That it will come I have no
('62', 460, 6, 11, 932699) doubt, but it will come from below, not above, for many of those above are too much
('62', 460, 7, 12, 932783) interested in British domination and hope to preserve their special privileges through it.
('62', 460, 8, 13, 932874) Social and economic forces will inevitably bring other problems to the front.
('62', 460, 8, 14, 932952) They will
('62', 460, 9, 15, 932962) create cleavages along different lines, but the communal cleavage will go.
('62', 460, 10, 16, 933037) I have been warned by friends, whose opinion I value, that my attitude towards
('62', 460, 11, 17, 933116) communal organizations will result in antagonizing many people against me.
('62', 460, 11, 18, 933191) That is
('62', 460, 12, 19, 933199) indeed probable.
('62', 460, 12, 20, 933216) I have no desire to antagonize any countryman of mine for we are in the
('62', 460, 13, 21, 933288) midst of a mighty struggle against a powerful opponent.
('62', 460, 13, 22, 933344) But that very struggle demands
('62', 460, 14, 23, 933375) that we must check harmful tendencies and always keep the goal before us.
('62', 460, 14, 24, 933449) I would be
('62', 460, 15, 25, 933460) false to myself, to my friends and comrades, so many of whom have sacrificed their all at
('62', 460, 16, 26, 933550) the altar of freedom and even to those who disapprove of what I say, if I remained a silent
('62', 460, 17, 27, 933642) witness to an attempt to weaken and check our great struggle for freedom.
('62', 460, 17, 28, 933716) Those, who, in
('62', 460, 18, 29, 933731) my opinion, are helping in this attempt may be perfectly honest in the beliefs they hold.
('62', 460, 18, 30, 933821) I do not challenge their bona fides.
('62', 460, 18, 31, 933858) But none the less, the beliefs may be wrong, anti–
('62', 460, 19, 32, 933909) national and reactionary.
('62', 460, 20, 33, 933935) I write as an individual, and, in this matter, I claim to represent no one but myself.
('62', 460, 21, 34, 934022) Many may agree with me; I hope they do.
('62', 460, 21, 35, 934062) But whether they do so or do not, I must say
('62', 460, 22, 36, 934107) frankly what I have in my mind.
('62', 460, 22, 37, 934139) That is not perhaps the way of politicians, for, in
('62', 460, 23, 38, 934191) politics, people are very careful of what they say and do not say lest they offend some
